title: migration remains at record highs as number of non eu arrivals soars while fewer europeans come after brexit
story: The latest stats from the ONS showed that fewer EU citizens are coming to Britain than any time since , but overall migration numbers are steady.More people came from countries around the world for work and study, leading to the most people coming from outside of the EU since .Meanwhile, EU migration was at its lowest level in a decade at ,, with more EU citizens leaving than coming here.More students are coming than workers too, the data showed.Ministers have said that all EU citizens in the UK should apply to remain after Brexit, but leaving the bloc has left many to leave and travel where.The sliding value of the pound means wages for EU citizens will also be worth less back home too., more people came to the UK than left in the year to September, todays data showed., people in total moved to the UK, but , people left.And separate figures showed the number of EU nationals applying for British citizenship hit an all-time high last year, rising  per cent to around ,.But the PM STILL says shes committed to reducing net migration to the tens of thousands.Jay Lindop, Director of the Centre for International Migration at the ONS said: Due to increasing numbers arriving for work and study, non-EU net migration is now at the highest level since .And Lord Green of Deddington, Chairman of Migration Watch UK, said it was hugely concerning to see that migration remained so high.He said: It is a real concern that non-EU net migration has risen still further to more than a quarter of a million even before the government has implemented its proposals to loosen the work permit system.It’s no surprise that EU net migration has fallen further given the extraordinary uncertainty prevailing over Brexit.Madeleine Sumption, director of the Migration Observatory at the University of Oxford, said: “The overall story the data tell on EU migration is clear: Britain is not as attractive to EU migrants as it was a couple of years ago.Ministers are preparing Britains post-Brexit immigration system ready for when we leave the EU in March.The Government are expected to take another YEAR to make a decision on it.We pay for your stories! title: eu nationals could be allowed to stay in the uk after brexit even if they dont register sajid javid hints
story: The Government has vowed to end free movement and EU nationals who want to stay are expected to apply for settled status by the end of June .But grilled on the scheme, the Home Secretary said Europeans who have failed to sign up could still be allowed to stay.He told the home affairs select committee: “It is my intention and my view thatsomeone for good reason has missed the deadline that they do not lose their rights, and there is a system in place that allows them to continue to protect their rights.”His remarks appear to contradict lawyers who have previously told the committee that Europeans who have failed to register would be “unlawfully resident”.Theresa May has repeatedly promised to end free movement after Britain leaves the EU.And she has stuck to her target – which has never been met – to bring net migration down to the tens of thousands.But some MPs on the committee attacked plans to register EU migrants after Brexit.They warned that many will miss the deadline and may not be able to prove their right to stay here.And they warned this could lead to another Windrush style scandal, which saw migrants who were entitled to stay in Britain wrongly detained and threatened with deportation.

title: labour could force through second brexit referendum vote next week john mcdonnell confirms
story: The Shadow Chancellor said the party could push MPs to vote on whether there should be another isive referendum in a matter of days, after it became official party policy.But one of his own MPs warned the party was not listening to its own voters by chasing mythical unicorns.Last night MPs threw out Labours alternative Brexit plan, which would have forced Theresa May into seeking a customs union with the EU and giving up our right to do trade deals around the world.But the blueprint was overwhelmingly rejected, meaning Labour are now set to officially back a second referendum to stop a damaging Tory Brexit.He confirmed that Labour would now betray millions of voters and push for a referendum which could see Brexit cancelled completely.Mr McDonnell told ITVs Peston last night: When the meaningful vote comes back, and we are told maybe that might be on March , there are rumours today [Wednesday] that it could be next week, we will see.Thats the time when we will have to put the amendment up.However, the party would still be pressing for their alternative deal and fighting for a general election too, he stressed, as the party tries to desperately appease furious MPs in Leave seats.Labours Lisa Nandy slammed him on the same show for refusing to listen to the British people about what they wanted, and warned her it was that which lead to Brexit in the first place.She said options were being cooked up in Westminster even though large numbers of her constituents want to vote for No Deal at all.We are not being clear with people still. Members of the shadow cabinet had deep reservations about this, she said.At this stage instead of chasing mythical unicorns we need to be forcing a path through this that protects jobs.Labours second referendum bid is unlikely to pass as dozens of Labour politicians in areas which voted for Brexit wont back it.And Tories will be very unlikely to get behind a Labour plan too.Mr McDonnell saidthere were a second vote, he would opt to Remain, which several figures have said has to be on the ballot paper in another vote.The Labour party has desperately been trying to keep all sides of its warring party happy, by saying that all options are on the table for how to progress with Brexit.But Remainers have been pressuring Jeremy Corbyn to get behind the vote in a desperate hope to try and stop us leaving on March .

title: television adverts no deal brexit
story: A major advertising campaign is set to begin shortly which will encourage iniduals and companies to work out how No Deal could affect them.The telly blitz will be the first time the Government has put out TV Brexit ads ahead of our scheduled departure on March .It was announced by Cabinet Secretary Mark Sedwill, the UKs top civil servant.He told a Commons committee today: Iniduals and citizens and business are making their own judgments.We have plans to bring through some television advertising as well.The ads are due to start from March , The Sun understands - meaning they could be scrappedMrs May wins Commons approval for her deal in the next fortnight.Previous advertising campaigns have involved radio ads as well as notices in the print media.Sir Mark also told the public administration committee that most iniduals and businesses had done little to prepare for the possibility of No Deal.He said: Everyone is making their own judgments about these things and whether it is urgent or necessary yet.And he suggested the reason was that most Brits dont believe No Deal will ever happen.This week Theresa May promised MPs thatshe doesnt get a deal by March , they will get a chance to delay Brexit rather than leaving on March .

noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThousands of pensioners face cutting down on heating and eating after the Tories axed a vital benefit, campaigners warn. New figures reveal three quarters of people who were on Support for Mortgage Interesthave been left in the lurch since the pound-a-month payment was swapped for a repayable loan. SMI was paid for decades to people on hard times to fund their mortgage interest - saving their homes from repossession. But last April the Tory government changed the benefit to a loan repayable in full, with interest, when claimants die or sell up. Now official figures show , of , former claimantshave chosen to stop SMI rather than take on new debt. Just ,have accepted the loan and ,are undecided. A further , could not be contacted.Labour branded the cut a failure and Age UK warned it may force people to cut down on heating or eating.  Charity Director Caroline Abrahams said: “People are receiving these benefits because they are on a low income. And it is unclear how people are meeting mortgage interest payments now given most have chosen not to take up the loan. We are concerned that older people affected may be facing hardship and cutting down on essentials such as heating and eating.” SMI was worth an average of pound a month for working-age claimants and pound for pensioners in  . To qualy families had to be on Income Support, Pension Credit, income-based jobseekers allowance or income-based disability benefit ESA. Almost half of claimants were pensioners.  Mike Amesbury, Shadow Employment Minister, said: The decision to convert SMI into a loan has clearly been a failure. A high proportion of SMI claimants are elderly or disabled. How they will manage without support for their housing costs is a matter of real concern and there is a real risk that they could be pushed into real hardship. The Government must get a grip and act urgently to make sure that people are not pushed into poverty because of this policy. The Department for Work and Pensions said the loan is still available to people who turned it down, and can be backdated to the date of the cut in April .A DWP spokesman said: “Support for Mortgage Interestchanges provide a safety net for homeowners from repossession and make it fair to the taxpayer who funds it. “Mortgage lenders tell us the majority of claimants who did not take out an SMI loan are meeting their mortgage commitments.”

title: code name prince harry uses
story: NewsCode name Prince Harry uses on nights out so people dont know who he isPrince Harry was once known as the Party Prince, and was often seen leaving nightclubs and bars in London with his friendsShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  FEB NewsPrince Harry leaving the Zefi bar in Kensington"Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBeing a young adult can be tough for anyone, but it must be even more trickyyoure royal. While you can probably get on the guest list for every hip bar and nightclub in the world, you also have to deal with the fact everybody knows who you are. But it turns out Prince Harry had a little trick up his sleeve when he used to go out partying to avoid attention. Instead of introducing himself by his real name, he told people he was called Rob. Well, its definitely less showy than Prince Harry, sixth in line to the throne and the Queens grandson.   Baroness Jessica Heydel, who appeared on MTV reality TV show The Royal World, revealed the code name.She told the Daily Mail: I met Prince Harry once on a night out, probably four or five years ago.His friend introduced him as Rob. I sat there and I thought, That is Prince Harry, everyone knows that is Prince Harry. I had all these things going around my head, so it didn’t turn into a friendship. My mum told me I could’ve been the Duchess of Sussex – she’s still angry!   Rob isnt the only nickname Harry has used to avoid detection over the years, and he reportedly used to have a Facebook account in the name Spike Wells. Strange nicknames are popular among the Royal Family, with the Queen, Kate and Philip all having one. Kate apparently calls hubby William Baldy, while he refers to her as the Duchess of Dolittle, which could be a reference to reports the Queen was worried about her lack of career when they started dating. The Queen has a number of nicknames, including Gary , Lilibetand the young royals call her Gan-Gan.

title: hair transplant doc reveals celebs
story: NewsHair transplant doc reveals celebs whove had secret surgery - including Oscars starThe number of men having hair transplants has tripled thanks to stars like Wayne Rooney, Shane Warne and Jack P ShepherdShareCommentsByJane Lavender:,  FEB NewsDr Bessam Farjo is a leading hair restorative surgeon "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTen years ago it was something men would never have talked about let alone decided to do anything about.But now the final male taboo - baldness - has finally been smashed and more men than ever are opting for hair transplants . High profile patients like Wayne Rooney, cricket legend Shane Warne and Coronation Street star Jack P Shepherd have planted the once secret surgery firmly out in the open.The number of hair transplants has almost triped since  when just , were carried out. In  a total of , people opted to go under the kne to have their hair restored.   But it would seem some chaps are still not comfortable to admit when theyve undergone the innovative op. Dr Bessam Farjo has clinics in both Manchester and London and is one of the leading hair restoration surgeons. Speaking tohe said: There are people in the spotlight who its agreed have had some work done.In my opinion Bradley Cooper has had some very good work done on his hairline.I say the same of Sylvester Stallone and Mel Gibson.   John Travolta, I dont believe, has had any work done but he wears a lot of hair pieces and wigs and has recently been pictured with a shaved head. Dr Farjo believes the huge rise in the number of men opting to have the surgery, which costs around pound, in the UK, is down to a breakdown in stigma. He explained: The rise, in part, has been driven by celebrities and the general public being open about what they’ve had done. Terms like metrosexual are a little old hat now, but what began with that trend has led to procedures like this becoming more commonplace today. We are looking after ourselves more, and there is less stigma around men taking pride in their appearance.  If men don’t like something about their body, and they see ‘normal blokes’ like Wayne Rooney, James Nesbit or Shane Warne doing it, they thing ‘why not ’ And the rise in the success - and the reduction in cost - of hair transplants has also helped to break down the stigma. But the surgeon insists hair loss, or male pattern baldness, is not on the increase. More than a third of men have some kind of hair loss by the time theyre , and up to half of blokes aged . There are two manin types of transplant surgery.  The first involves surgeons reoving inidual hair follicles from the scalp using punches. The the surgeon makes microscopic slits in the receiving area of the patient’s scalp, and the inidual grafts will be placed into these sites by the doctor and his team. This is popular because it doesnt leave a hairline scar, instead just tiny dot scars. The treatment can take up to  hours and can involve , grafts in a single day. Hair starts to grow about four months after surgery and will keep growing for the next  to  months. The second involves using a thin strip skin with hair on it from somewhere  on the scalp known as the permanent area.  This is where hairs are genetically programmed to keep growing for le. It had to be done under local anaesthetic and uses high-powered microscopes to dissect the healthy hair follicles and transplant them into the area affected by hair loss. The surgery can take up to  hours and again it can take the hair four months to start to grow. But there can be risks when it comes to hair transplants, especially when people opt for a cheaper transplant abroad. Dr Farjo explained: There’s a growing number of ‘unethical’ hair restoration clinics — both here in the UK and abroad — mostly operated by non-doctors. In the worst of cases, patients attending these run the risk of becoming disfigured with an unnatural looking hairline or wasting priceless donor hair for future use.  However, we hear procedures can be sourced for as little as pound from some clinics, with many cheap operators typically located in Turkey. That may sound tempting, but it really isn’t worth the risk. In the UK, any clinic offering a hair transplant surgery must register with the Care Quality Commissionand will therefore be inspected. If a doctor operates on a patient in a non-CQC registered hair transplant clinic then they are breaking the law. Additionally, doctors in the UK must abide by strict ethical guidelines set by the General Medical Council , and must be covered by regulated liability insurers. If they breach this guidance, a patient can report them to the GMC.

title: lost caravaggio masterpiece goes display
story: NewsLost £m Caravaggio masterpiece goes on display after being discovered in atticThe painting of a beheading of a man by a woman has undergone a two year restoration and is set to be sold at auction in JuneShareCommentsByTanveer Mann:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe famous painting was discovered in the attic of a French farmhouse five years ago "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Caravaggio painting worth at least poundmillion has been unveiled five years after it was discovered in the attic of a French farmhouse. The -year-old masterpiece, named Lost Caravaggio, underwent a two year restoration before going on display at P  DColnaghi Co art dealership this morning in St Jamess, London. The incredibly well-preserved canvas shows the beheading of Assyrian general Holofernes by Judith, from the apocryphal Book of Judith. Judith was a widow from the city of Bethulia, under siege by the Holofernes army. To save her city, she seduced the general in his tent before beheading him, which the painting depicts.   The masterpiece is believed to be the work of great Renaissance master Caravaggio and is thought to have been painted between  and  Caravaggio is said to have died from gradual poisoning from the lead in his paint at the age of  in . His use of shadows and radiant light is thought to have led to the renowned Baroque style that flourished for  more years and the inspiration behind Rembrandts artwork.   Some in the art world disputed the authenticity of the painting - believing it instead to be a fine copy produced by one of his Flemish disciples. One such artist considered was Louis Finson who was a recognised artist in his own right but owned and often reproduced Caravaggios work.  But the gallery has insisted the work is indeed Caravaggios and said it has been confirmed by a number of scientic analyses and supported by the results of a recent light cleaning of the old nish. The painting will be exhibited in London, Paris, New York and Toulouse before being sold at auction in Toulouse on June  this year, in collaboration with the art appraisal firm Cabinet Turquin.

story: NewsMan sends £, to woman hed never met - then finds out she doesnt existDave Hazel, , was devastated after being scammed by Linda Smith who he planned to marryShareCommentsByElaine McCahillAssistant News Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video builder-lost-k-fake-online-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man has been left heartbroken and thousands of pounds out of pocket after sending pound, to a woman hed never met - only to find out she doesnt exist. Dave Hazel, , was set to marry his online lover Linda Smith but ended up being scammed out of his le savings. The warehouse worker met Linda on a dating site in  and spent a year chatting online and speaking to her on the phone. After falling head over heels, Dave was convinced she was going to move from Canada to the UK to be with him. But he was soon embroiled in a web of lies with his online lover demanding more and more money from him.   Dave, from Kings Lynn, Norfolk, quickly forked out his entire le savings of pound, but soon after realised Linda was based in Ghana, Africa. She then cut all contact with him and completely disappeared. Singleton Dave, who wanted to start a family with Linda, is now speaking out for the first time about being scammed online. He said: After losing almost pound, I was heartbroken - I had been ready to start a family with Linda. I had been speaking to her online for  months but despite not meeting her or using Skype, we had spoken on the phone.   I met her on a dating site and she looked like someone Id met in London and she said she remembered meeting me. We began building up a relationship, having conversations daily - she introduced herself as Linda Smith. I even rang her and she spoke with an accent that sounded more English than Canadian. Before I knew it, I was falling for her - my heart had melted and she was lovely. She wanted to live with me and I thought I was in love. Dave made arrangements to meet Linda, but things started to unravel and she quickly started demanding more funds. The bachelor said: The first thing she asked me for was a VISA costing pound. I was ready to have a full relationship, and I was happy to help her.  She asked me to send it through Moneygram - which works almost like PayPal and two weeks after that it was another pound for a medical check. She said she would marry me and have children - she was promising everything Id always wanted. Yet Daves dream was about to be destroyed as the money requests kept coming in, eventually reaching more than pound,. Dave paid for what he believed were plane tickets, visa complications and more - fully believing she was on her way to finally meet him. Yet his suspicions were finally aroused when she asked for flight tickets from Ghana. Dave said: I thought she was coming from Canada but when I asked for proof of the tickets they said she was coming from Ghana.  I asked her to explain - and she said shed just been visiting. But then I got a phone call from immigration in Ghana after shed been detained for having a large amount of money on her person. They told me the person I was waiting for wasnt coming and was being arrested. Dave decided it was time to investigate properly, a staggering two years after hed first spoken to Linda. Upon visiting his local bank, it was quickly discovered that all the paperwork, which showed email correspondence between Dave and Linda and evidence of where Dave had sent his money to, proved Dave had been victim of a scam.  Staff also told him there was no way he could get his money back, as he had voluntarily sent it and it couldnt be traced. Dave added: It was the darkest period of my le - I asked themthey were joking, I couldnt have been conned. I didnt trust anyone and couldnt speak to anyone for months. Without Victim Support - a service which offers initial support and information to victims of crimes like mine, and assessed your needs going forward - I wouldnt be here. Ive learnt you should always ask for advice, andyoure sending money without seeing them, stop. Dont be ashamed - youre not the only one - these cons left me heartbroken and its taken me years to fix things.

In the documentary, Jayde is seen trying to convince landlord Kevin to rent her a two-bed property. What are the problems  Debt-ridden claimants must wait six weeksfor their first payment, with % waiting longer than that and % waiting ten weeks in late . They now want to warn others after their two-year-old son could have been blinded and had to spend four days in hospital last month. Lorna Hoy, , and Andy Briggs, , first noticed small red spots forming on their son Kalos face, chest and arm. After being dismissed twice by doctors, Lorna claims it wasnt until their third attempt to seek medical advice their concerns were taken seriously. Kalo tested positive for the herpes simplex virus - something doctors suggest he caught through kissing an infected adult.  The mum-of-four is now sharing her story to raise awareness for the virus, which,not treated, can be fatal in children. Thankfully Kalo has since made a full recovery after his time in hospital. Lorna, from Salford, Manchester said: I never thought this would happen to our family. Kalo had red spots all over this face, chest and arm before he was diagnosed with herpes. He had ulcers in his mouth and needed injections in his eyes to ensure the infection hadnt spread to them as this couldve blinded him. I have heard of babies dying from catching this virus which is awful and I think the only reason Kalo survived is because he was just under two at time.   I hope our story serves as a warning to other parents as it could happen to anyone. Kissing children on their mouths and sharing cutlery is a common way to catch herpes, as its spread through saliva. Kalo - who was admitted to Wythenshawe Hospital in Manchester on January  - needed an intense course of IV antibiotics in a bid to rid him of the infection. Andy, a bus driver, added: Kalo had struggled to eat days before his diagnosis which was a real worry for us as parents.  But thanks to the amazing care of the doctors and nurses he began eating yogurts as he began to recover.Lorna shared the pictures of Kalo via Facebook to raise awareness for the infection and it went viral.We want to encourage people to research the virus and look into its causes to prevent their children from going through what Kalo did. The couple who have three other children, Jayden, eight, Kaci, six and Jenson, four, and hope the pictures of Kalos face will help raise awareness. Lorna said: Since getting home has been getting along great and is finally back to his good self however the scars have remained on his face from the sores he had while in hospital.  We would all like to say thanks to the staff who cared for Kalo in one way or another at Wythenshawe Hospital. As a family never thought this would happen to us but were so lucky that Kalo pulled through after his treatment. I hope through sharing our experiences of it that we prevent others from going through the same.

She said: I will never forget the calls you made to me that day. I heard her screams in the background. That was the last thing I heard from my Bella. I will never hear her call me mommy, but I heard her cry in pain while you sat there for hours without doing anything to help her.  Katy Redondo and her husband Fernando almost did not attend -year-old Carillo-Maldonado’s sentencing, because they are furious with Carillo-Maldonado’s sentence of just three and a half years over the July  crime. Police have not shared further information on how Bella came to acquire the two skull fractures, the Stamford Advocate said. Sentencing, Judge Gary White suggested that Bella had died due to her babysitter’s carelessness, saying: Nobody is saying this defendant intentionally harmed this victim. title: age parents can expect child
story: NewsAge parents can expect their child to sleep through the night - and its bleakRelax, its not "age eighteen" - but nor is it great newsShareCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  FEB NewsJust as well babies are cute "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Youd be hard pressed to find a subject parents are more obsessed with than sleep .Sleep regression, nap schedules, sleep training and, the biggie: When will my child sleep through the night  There are, apparently, babies who do this, and thats great news for their mums and dads. However a new study brings bad tidings for everyone . Researchers from the University of Warwick studied the sleep patterns of , German parents with a child born between  and .   They found that mums lost the most sleep, reporting that this amounted to an hour of sleep in the first three months, and then  minutes of sleep every night in their childs first year. Breastfeeding mums were found to get the worst sleep. While they werent as adversely affected as mums, dads too suffer from a lack of sleep -  minutes in the first three months after birth.   But the real bad news comes in answer to the when will my child sleep through the night  question. Neither mums nor dads said their sleep recovered for up to SIX YEARS after the birth of their first child. Thats six years of disturbed, broken, shallow sleep. Six years of relying heavily on caffeine, of eye bags, grey skin, low energy levels and a general sense of always being knackered. While having children is a major source of joy for most parents it is possible that increased demands and responsibilities associated with the role as a parent lead to shorter sleep and decreased sleep quality even up to  years after birth of the first child, authorSakari Lemola ofthe University of Warwick said in a statement.

title: long lost 129m caravaggio nearly
story: NewsLong-lost £m Caravaggio was nearly stolen by burglars before it was foundThe Caravaggio painting was almost stolen years before it was found in an attic in ToulouseShareCommentsByElaine McCahillAssistant News EditorAlex Green:,  FEB NewsThe famous painting was discovered in the attic of a French farmhouse five years ago "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe long-lost poundm Caravaggio painting which was unveiled today was almost stolen by burglars years before the masterpiece was found.The -year-old work was unveiled today - five years after it was discovered in the attic of a French farmhouse.Now it has emerged the painting by the Italian master could have been lost forever but burglars didnt think it was worth anything during a break-in. Burglars broke into the home and stole items including bottles of perfume but left the painting as they thought it worthless, according to auctioneer Marc Labarbe. The work, called Judith And Holofernes and valued at pound million, sat for a century in anonymity against a wall between old clothes, family antiques and crockery.   The painting of the beheading of a man by a woman has undergone a two year restoration and is set to be sold at auction in June. Speaking at the unveiling of the work at the Colnaghi gallery, Mr Labarbe joked the burglars had not deemed the painting adequate enough to steal it. He said: One of my clients was clearing his attic and he needed two men to help him. It took a year to sell all the antiquities. Clocks, toys, pieces of religion, in good and bad condition, clothes, crockery, as well as many things of no interest. Everything was very dusty. I have to tell you that a few years before, burglars broke into the attic and stole many things, included eau de parfum bottles. Fortunately, our painting was not adequate.   He added: On the rd of April , late in the morning, my client called me again because he had found a painting and wanted my opinion on it. I went to his house and climbed the stairs to the landing of the attic where the painting was displayed. At this moment there was what was like a fog across the whole canvas. The painting was blurry and it was almost impossible to see the details, but I was impressed by the state of the composition.  According to Paris-based art appraiser Eric Turquin, the work was painted in . It depicts the biblical tale of Judith, a widow from the city of Bethulia, who breaks the siege of her home by seducing the Assyrian leader and beheading him. It will be sold without reserve on June  in Toulouse at the La Halle aux Grains, with Mr Labarbe saying: This magnicent story began in Toulouse. It has to continue in Toulouse. The painting is Caravaggios second version of the same subject, with the first painted in Rome around . The discovery means there are now  known paintings attributed to the artist, who was born in  and died in  of suspected lead poisoning from his paint. Judith And Holofernes will be on display at Colnaghi at  Bury Street from March  until March .

title: sick gangs who kidnap kids
story: NewsVile gangs who kidnap kids to sell as sex slaves - with bonuses for pretty onesThe Philippines is fast becoming one of the abduction capitals of the world with young children the latest victimsShareCommentsByJane Lavender:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video woman-reveals-how-gangs-kidnap-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Playing in front of her home, a happy -year-old had no clue she had been targeted by a sick gang hell bent on snatching youngsters fom the streets.As she enjoyed herself in the sunshine a shadow cast itself across her game. Lilibeth Bustamante asked the youngster to go with her to a shop and it was only when a neighbour stepped in to intervene as the woman grabbed the little girls arm that she was saved. The terrying incident took place in Paranaque City, the Philippines, on February .And this latest attempted abduction is one of the reasons the country is becoming known as one of the kidnapping capitals of the world.  In one year alone  people were abducted and both the US and British embassies have warned tourists travelling to the Philippines to be vigilent in light of the kidnapping threat.Bustamante was arrested after the concerned neighbour called the police and she told officers the terrying way the kidnapping gangs operate.The gangs snatch children and then sell them on the black market to become sex slaves. Bustamante, who says she was paid just pound: to carry out the abduction, claimed she worked with other women to kidnap children from the streets. She said: I only take them, they sell. They only give me one thousand pesos. I send it to my family in Mindoro.   The alleged kidnapper then claimed the gang would sell the children - both boys and girls - to foreign buyers who would often have sex with the youngsters while streaming it online anc charging people to watch. The children sell for as little as pound,. Bustamante said: We have a quota of two children per week. Our target age is -years-old and above. They require us to take good-looking children. They get , to , pesos depending on their looks. My cut is , pesos. Bustamante said that she had taken dozens of children since she joined the gang last year.  She added: We operate inManila and nearby towns. We dont stop until we reach our quota. Rudy Dimson , from the Parantildeaque Police Women and Children Protection Desk said: We are currently investigating the case. We want to look for other victims of this group. We urge the parents with missing children to come here. Several days after Bustamante was detained, police arrested a second woman after she was caught allegedly trying to abduct a young girl.  Locals surrounded her and called police who arrested her on suspicion of attempted child abduction in Batasan Hills district of Quezon City inManila.  And children are not the only victims of the kidnapping gangs. Militant groups are also targeted wealthy Filipinos as well as visitors. In June last year the New Peoples Army abducted a soldier while the militant Abu Sayyaf Groupsnatched the relatives of one of the countrys politicians. The most common place for tourists to be kidnapped is in the south of the country and travellers from China, Europe, Australia and America are the most likely targets. People are even being snatched from resorts and beaches by pirates.  Many of those abducted are ed uninjured but increasingly bold ransom and even terror demands mean some have been beheadedthese are not met. Last year  people believed to be membes of the ASG were convicted of kidnapping dozens of school pupils, teachers and a catholic priest in the militant groups worst ever abduction. Two of the teachers were beheaded and the priest also died while he was in captivity following the abduction in . Senior State Prosecutor Peter Ong said at the time: The persistence and determination of the court to give justice to the victims and those who were wrongfully arrested led to this decision, although it took more than one and a half decades to happen. In  a plot by the ASG to kidnap tourists on Bohol Island was foiled by authorities.  They hunted those responsible down in a dramatic speedboat chase and nine militants were killed along with three soldiers and once police officer. And last year a -year-old Japanese man was rescued by police after he was kidnapped in the Philippines. He was found in a house outside Manila. In  Kjartan Sekkingstad from Norway was kidnapped along with two Canadian men and a Filipina woman. This was one of the highest profile hostage for ransom cases in the country. Robert Hall was one of the three men kidnapped by the ASG. He spent nine months in captivity but was beheaded on September , .  Sekkingstad managed to escape when the Philippines military forces launched a surprise assault on the militant group responsible in the dead of night. The then -year-old fled through the jungles in the Sulu province to safety. But as he raced away from the scene of his captivity he stumbled across Canadian John Ridsdel, who he had become close to in their long months as hostages. Ridsdel was suffering from a broken rib so Sekkingstad carried him back to their captors. Just  hours later, Ridsdel, a father-of-two, was led away to be beheaded. Sekkingstad was finally freed almost a year after he was kidnapped.  The message from the embassy here in the UK is clear - there is a heightened risk of kidnapping in the Philippines. A spokesman said: There has been an increase in kidnapping of foreign nationals, including attacks targeting foreigners and tourists since late . Terrorist groups continue to plan kidnap operations against western nationals in the Philippines. However, since the ASGs leader, Isnilon Hapilon, died in October  the group has been fractured and less organised. The number of kidnappings fell last year compared to .

title: tributes paid to former dundee lord provost
story: Tributes have been paid to former Lord Provost Mervyn Rolfe CBE, who has died following an illness.Mr Rolfe, , served as Lord Provost and Lord Lieutenant of Dundee from  to .He also served as convener of the Scottish Police Services Authority and stood for Labour in Perth and Kinross in the  general election. He also served as chief executive of Dundee Chamber of CommerceAway from politics, he was actively involved in education, working with both Abertay and Dundee universities.He was awarded a CBE in  for services to local government and was a founding member of the Dundee United supporters group, the Arab Trust.Lord Provost Ian Borthwick paid tribute to Mr Rolfe’s commitment to education in the city.He said: “Mervyn served our city, both as a council member and then as Lord Provost, with distinction.“In his time in local government his main interest was in the pursuit of improvements in education, along with his late we Christine.“His keen interest in improving education is, I feel, what he will be most remembered for.“As a councillor, he was very attentive to the needs of his constituents and pursued their interests vigorously.“I respected his drive for the pursuit of improving education and although we may have disagreed in council chambers, there was always a mutual respect for his abilities as a councillor and again as Lord Provost.“He achieved success in projecting the city in a very positive way.”Abertay University secretary Sheena Stewart said: “Mervyn was a great friend to the university and remained a dedicated member of the Abertay community.“As Lord Provost, he had a signicant impact on Dundee and this rightly led to him becoming a widely respected figure in the city.“Our thoughts are with his family at this time.”

title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Disaled workers getting a raw deal new report claims
story: MANY disabled people in Scotland have been ldquofrozen out of work due to their condition, according to research by disability charity Leonard Cheshire.Three out of four said they left their jobs because they had not received the support they needed to fulfil their role, and nearly one out of five who applied for a job in the past five years felt the employer had chosen not to consider them for the post because they had a disability.Kenny Shand from Inverness who found himself in this situation, said: ldquoNot everyone is treated with respect. Whether you have additional support needs or not, the system needs to be more transparent. Workplace adjustments donrsquot need to be expensive ndash they just need to be done.Stuart Robertson, director at Leonard Cheshire in Scotland, said the findings lt the lid on a ldquotough and unwelcoming employment landscape.He said: ldquoMost people with disabilities in  remain frozen out of the world of work. All of us must redouble our efforts to challenge outdated attitudes to disability and accelerate the positive change that enables everyone to thrive in the world of work.The research also suggests more than half of all managers consider the cost of workplace adjustments a barrier to employing people with disabilities.In more promising news, Leonard Cheshirersquos research found a fth of employers say they are more likely to employ someone with a disability.The charity said the latest research shows an increased awareness amongst employers of the UK Governmentrsquos Access to Work scheme giving people grant and other support based on their needs, is up to  percent in  from  percent in .But many recipients are waiting more than three months for their application to be approved and the charity wants government action.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Family remember happy and friendly teenager after tragic accident near Inverness
story: The family of a teenager killed in a road traffic collision at Dochgarroch has spoken about their "happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly".Policehave confirmed that the -year-old who died as a result of the two-vehicle collision at around .pm on Sunday night was Samuel Foster, of Lochend near Inverness.The family said: ldquoSamuel, our darling boy, was incredibly popular and had a huge circle of friends. He attended Millburn Academy before moving to Inverness College two years ago to study engineering."He also worked at the bakery at Marks and Spencer for two years and loved his motocross biking and cars.ldquoSamuel was a happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly.ldquoSamuel was the youngest of four siblings and words canrsquot express how much he will be missed by his parents Heather and Lenny, his brother David and twin sisters Samantha and Kirsty, his nephew Reuben and niece Georgie.ldquoWe would like to thank the incredible number of people who have sent us messages of sympathy ndash your kind words mean so much and are a reminder of just how popular and well-loved Samuel was."We hope he will always be remembered this way.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Historic Inverness city centre mosaics almost completed
story: FINAL measurements have been taken for the re-installation of a well-known Inverness mosaic.Restoration work to breathe le into the historic mosaics in Invernessrsquos Academy Street started in July last year.It came after Cairngorm Taverns secured an Inver-ness Townscape Heritage grant to fully restore the former AI Welders building, which is set to have a street-level bar and first-floor restaurant.It appointed conservation specialist Laing Traditional Masonryas its main contractor although the first phase of work has been handled by sub-contractor the Mosaic Restoration Company .The mosaic of welders and foundry men at work was partially taken down last year by Northamptonshire-based MRC. Mosaics have been taken to MRCrsquos factory for restoration ndash and as one of the four original mosaics was missing, the firm has used a photograph from the s to recreate the original design.MRCrsquos Gary Bricknell described it as a fascinating project for the family-run firm and he looks forward to putting the work back in place next month.ldquoItrsquos been an really interesting job, he said. ldquoEvery one of the tiles is hand-cut for these arches which are about four or five square metres. Wersquove used tens of thousands of tiles and wersquove been working on it for over six months now.Inverness Townscape Heritage Project provided a pound, grant towards the restoration of the B-listed building which is set to open in September as a showcase for Cairngorm and Loch Ness breweries.Sam Fairclf, managing director at Cairngorm Brewery which is involved with Cairngorm Taverns, said: ldquoWe are looking to showcase as much Highland produce as possible.The building was originally the head office of the Rose Street Foundry and Engineering Company and changed to AI Welders in the s.This project is the first major investment by the Inverness Townscape Heritage Project, which is a partnership regeneration project focusing on Academy Street.The refurbishment is a collaboration of funding partners including Inverness City Heritage Trust , Historic Environment Scotland and the Heritage Lottery Fund.Alison Tanner of ICHT said: ldquoThis is not just an interesting project, it is specialist restoration, repair and reinstatement work and needs to be rejoiced.ldquoIt has been years in the planning, the local public are passionate about the mosaics and the building as a whole and this work will save them for future generations.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Hotel plan for Inverness car park site
story: PLANS which would see a city centre car park transformed into a six-storey hotel have been unveiled.The pound million proposal by developer SRP Inverness Ltd was displayed to the public at the Spectrum Centre on Farraline Park, immediately next to the two-deck Rose Street car park which is earmarked as the site for the -metre high hotel.The proposal is the latest city hotel development from SRP Inverness directors Stewart Campbell and Stuart McCaffer, who were also behind the creation of the Inverness Encore Hotel, now the Pentahotel, on nearby Academy Street.Mr Campbell is confident the -bedroom L-shaped building will attract interest from a globally-known hotel brand, bringing something new to the Inverness accommodation mix.ldquoWe have worked with a number of global brands over the years, he said.ldquoInverness has massive global tourism and a lot of people, particularly global travellers, want the comfort of a well-known global brand.ldquoInverness is a strong tourism market, but therersquos been a lack of supply over the years. Other than the Travelodge on Academy Street in , there hasnrsquot been a new hotel built in Inverness since .The proposal includes a gym, three retail units within the hotel footprint and parking for  cars.Mr Campbell believes the hotel will benefit from its proximity to Inverness bus and railway stations, while any under capacity at the car park would be compensated by the nearby multi-storey car park.Mr Campbell and Mr McCaffer also own the neighbouring Rose Street Hall, which they hope to utilise for retail or restaurant use once the hotel is completed.Between the two, they also plan to construct a new bus and taxi road, replacing the footpath linking the bus station and Rose Street retail units.SRP Inverness expects to apply for planning permission in mid-April.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness College students showcase work of Highland Hospice
story: DRAMA students at Inverness College UHI have teamed up with Highland Hospice to offer insight into the patient experience of palliative care.Third year BAdrama and performance students performed Homeward Bound, a -minute play charting one couplersquos experience of end-of-le care, after being approached by the hospice.Officials at the hospice were keen to see live drama used as an educational tool to help improve the quality of palliative care and the experience of those involved.The play was performed to staff and nursing and care students at the college, with hospice representatives providing commentary to provide context and insight into the experience.It proved such a useful educational tool, the drama students have been asked to perform the play again at the NHS Highland Highland Hospice Essentials in Palliative Care Conference at Eden Court in Inverness, on March -, where it will be filmed to be used in learning.Lesley Mickel, programme leader for the drama course, said: ldquoWe were delighted to work with Highland Hospice to develop this special performance, which really highlights the human impact of late diagnosis and the importance of quality palliative care.ldquoIt was not only a challenge for our students in terms of portraying these very raw, human emotions, it also proved an extremely useful educational tool for students studying other parts of the university curriculum, with our nursing and care students gaining a much greater understanding of the issues involved.Hospice learning and development practice lead Siobhan Neylon said: ldquoIt was such an honour to work with these wonderful students on this poignant and emotive drama.ldquoThey portrayed the characters in such a dignied way.Homeward Bound was written by playwright Brian Daniels and tells the true story of Lesley and her husband Seth Goodburn, who was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer at the age of . He died just  days after diagnosis.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness MP calls for cross party approach to secure post Brexit funding
story: INVERNESS MP Drew Hendry has issued a cross-party rally cry ahead of Brexit.He has written to the Scotland spokespeople of each of the main political parties urging them to put pressure on the UK government to prevent Scotland losing out on millions of pounds in EU funding,the UK leaves the EU.Mr Hendry, the SNPs business spokeman, has called on parties to work together to ensure the UK government delivers a like-for-like replacement for vital EU development funds in the event of Brexit.Mr Hendry said: ldquoCommunities across Scotland would be hit hard by the loss of millions of pounds in vital EU fundingthe UK government drags us out of the EU against our will."The best way to protect this funding is for Scotland to remain in the EU - as we voted overwhelmingly for - butBrexit does go ahead then the UK government must commit to replacing every single penny of the funding Scotland stands to lose."It is shocking that the UK government has already broken its own word, and failed to consult on detailed plans to replace the lost EU funding and the huge benefits it brings for Scotland.ldquoIn addition to the many other benefits of our EU membership, Scotland has enjoyed huge investment in jobs, communities and infrastructure from European funds. It is vital that this investment continues like-for-like, and that the Scottish Government continues to oversee the funding so it meets Scotlands needs.ldquoAt present, groups across the country need to make decision about their future, but have no idea what sort of funding will be available after . This must not be another power grab away from the Scottish Parliament.ldquoSome of this funding helps level the playing field of regional inequality, which is stark when comparing rural areas with urban parts. The Tories must be held to account, investment levels must be matched, and clarity must be given to communities across Scotland.ldquoThe UK government cannot continue to kick this issue into the long grass and weasel out of their responsibilities. It is time for MPs and MSPs of all parties to demand that this money is protected in full and in time to give certainty to communities across Scotland."Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness pupils donate money to city cycling charity
story: PUPILS at an Inverness secondary school have selected a charity which provides cycle outings for the elderly to receive pound in funding from the Young Philanthropy Initiative .The scheme is sponsored by the Aberdeen-based Wood Foundation and students in each school were asked to make presentations to fellow students and a  of judges who selected the winning team which had a chosen charity.Millburn Academy have donated their money to Cycling Without Age, Inverness ndash a charity with specially adapted bikes which takes residents from care homes and Highland Hospice on rides around the town and local countryside.Alice Munro, principal teacher of English, said the competition was a great experience for the pupils.ldquoThey invited people from ious charities to the school and went out to see the work these charities do in the local community. After their research, teams were asked to give a presentation and the judges were former staff members, the school chaplain and a police representative.ldquoThe winning charity, Cycling Without Age, is a fantastic organisation doing great work with the elderly in the community.Cycling Without Age spokesman Mick Heath said: ldquoIt began as an idea in the head of Dr Katie Walter of Cairn Medical Practice.ldquoShe recruited me to be her helper. It all began with a chance encounter in July .ldquoWe started networking and soon had a grant from HiTrans Active Travel to buy our first electric trike for taking the elderly and frail out for rides.ldquoWe were quickly joined by Dr Moira Finlayson and we three have been going at it flat out since then.The charity now has four trikes and several volunteer pilots and has taken more than  passengers on more than  rides.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Rethink on Inverness city centre revamp
story: COUNCIL officers are to go back to the drawing board amid concerns over an ambitious project which aims to transform a key area in Inverness city centre.A bold vision including wider pavements and reduced traffic speeds in Academy Street was unveiled in November at the start of a public consultation.The Accessing Inverness project aims to complement a pound million upgrade of the rail station plus a revamp of the Victorian Market and involves HiTrans, the regional transport partnership for the Highlands and Islands, Highland Council and other organisations.Although the project team wants to apply for Sustrans funding to take the project to the next stage, Inverness councillors have demanded further work, including an impact an assessment for people with disabilities.It follows concerns that removing light and sound-controlled pedestrian crossings plus making the street and pavements the same level will pose dangers to visually impaired people.Inverness Ness-side councillor Ron MacWilliam described the design and report presented to councillors as ldquoflawed and said something had to happen.ldquoNumber one is making sure people who are least able to navigate their way around the streets of Inverness are considered in any design, he said.ldquoI donrsquot think people who are blind or partially-sighted have been considered.Accessing Inverness team leader Fiona McInally stressed there was more work to be done but the deadline for the funding application was April .She said the proposed design was outline only.ldquoIt is not set in stone, she said. ldquoWe are trying to get to a position we can get a solution and go forward.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said people had been asking for improvements for years and there was now an opportunity which must not be missed.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Stonework to be refurbished at Invernesss Victorian Market
story: Stonework at the Academy Street entrance to Invernesss Victorian Market is to be refurbished at a cost of pound,.The sum will be coveredby grants from the Academy Street Townscape Heritage Trust andInverness Common Good Fund .The decision to push ahead with the project will mean a delay to other planned mechanical and electrical works, alongwith the installation ofnew doors at the market.pound, remains allocated towards the upgrading of shopfronts at the market, including new lighting and flooring.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Success sees Inverness Town House tours extended
story: POPULARITY has prompted the number of guided tours of Inverness Town House to double this summer.City councillors have agreed to add two more tours each week after positive feedback.The tours were introduced in June in a move which completed a so-called cultural triangle which includes the cityrsquos museum and Inverness Castle Viewpoint.Two tours on Thursdays have been run by High Le Highlandand proved logistically and financially viable ndash making a pound. profit ndash with the additional two tours on Tuesdays starting on from May .Tours have not disrupted any business in the building and visitors have found them engaging, informative and entertaining.Inverness provost Helen Carmichael said: ldquoWell done to High Le Highland and in particular their team of guides, who helped the council create a third, new, visitor attraction in the town house, which along with the museum and art gallery and castle viewpoint have created an accessible lsquocultural trianglersquo around the Castle Wynd area.ldquoAs we move towards the redevelopment of Inverness Castle as a new lsquomust-seersquo visitor attraction, the Town House Tours will complement the tourism offering in this city centre location.HLH chief executive Ian Murray said: ldquoHigh Le Highland has been delighted to work with the council to create public access to the splendid town house and we look forward to seeing visitor numbers and tour provision increasing this summer.Thursday  Feb  : PM

story: Boss Derek McInnes today demanded the Dons get aggressive in their Scottish Cup clash with Rangers.McInnes was frustrated at the lack of dig from the Reds as their dismal home form continued with a - loss to relegation- battling Hamilton.He has warned that fight mustfor the Pittodrie quarter-final with the Gers.Aberdeen go into the cup tie amid a concerning home slump with just two points from the last .McInnes warned Aberdeen’s season hinges on solving their home hurt against an in-form Rangers side that has hit  goals in three games.Aberdeen also suffered an injury blow with left back Max Lowe coming off injured and he will be a doubt for the cup tie.McInnes said: “There has to be more aggression in our game from the start.“We cannot just pick and choose when that aggression comes.“It has to be there in every game, certainly the game against Rangers will demand it.“There is no doubt our home form has to improve for us to achieve what we want to achieve.“Certainly now on Sunday going into the cup gamewe want to make sure we are in with a chance of winning a cup and get into the semi-final we have to make sure there is more aggression in our performance.“Against Hamilton while there was no shortage of effort there was a shortage of aggression and confidence, especially once the second goal went in.“We are all responsible and we should all expect better.“It looked to me that Hamilton were the team with the biggest cause.“That shouldn’t be the case as we want to do as well as we can.“That was the most disappointing thing.”Aberdeen have taken just one point from back to back home games against the Premiership’s bottom sides, St Mirren and Hamilton.They were held - to bottom outfit St Mirren in the previous match at Pittodrie.Amidst the home slump since the turn of the year the Dons also drew - with Stenhousemuir, the team bottom of League One, in cup action.McInnes apologized to fans for another home howler.He said: “I am bitterly disappointed as we should all expect more from an Aberdeen team.“The supporters should expect more from ourselves.“We expect far more from ourselves.“We can only apologize to the supporters for the level of performance.“There is a demand here and you have to deal with that and we have for the last six years.“We want players who are brave enough to get on the ball whether it is - or we are behind.“While still having the confident to make things happen and we were miles away from that in terms of taking that responsibility.“I think the players are honest enough andthey are honest enough with themselves they will say they fell way short of what is expected.”Aberdeen’s defensive jinx struck yet again as on loan Derby County left-back Max Lowe had to leave the pitch injured after just  minutes.That came less than  hours after the Dons secured Greg Halford from the free agent market as emergency cover to strengthen the defence.Halford has previously played for Sunderland, Wolves and Cardf City – he was an unused substitute against Hamilton.Defender Halford, , was signed in reaction to the injuries to right back Shaleum Logan and on loan Watford defender Tommie Hoban.Logan is out for two to three months having undergone ankle surgery.Hoban is set to undergo cruciate ligament surgery and is out for the season.On Lowe, McInnes said: “It was enough for him to come off which puts him in doubt for Sunday.”Hamilton went ahead in the first half with a magnicent goal from George Oakley from near the byline.They secured the points to move them further clear of the immediate relegation spot through Mickel Miller in the second half.McInnes said: “I have got to praise Hamilton for their part in it as they played well.“The team with the more aggression won the game.“It is a reminder to my players that while there is plenty of effort and running about you cannot just win a game based on your quality.“There are so many other factors needed to win a game.“We were unconvincing from the off in terms of defending and gave them one or two opportunities to keep them interested.“The last  minutes of the first half we played well and were unfortunate not to get the equalizer.“We asked the players to go and deliver a second half full of confidence with more aggression and intent.“We got that for spells at the start of the second half and passed up a few chances.“There were enough chances to win the game, that is clear.”

title: campaigners calling for return of gatwick flights welcome new aberdeen connection
story: Campaigners have welcomed the arrival of a new air link between Aberdeen and the south of England.Loganair will operate a new three-times-a-day service between the north-east and London Southend from May .Airline launches new Aberdeen-London Southend flights" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news local airline-launches-aberdeen-london-southend-flights embed # secretcOPyfbsO" data-secret"cOPyfbsO" width"" "" title"#Airline launches new Aberdeen-London Southend flights# # Evening Express" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"The move means passengers will be able to travel from Aberdeen into the centre of London in less than two-and-a-half hours.Val Fry, who started a petition after the city’s Gatwick service was withdrawn earlier this month, believes the new route will make the south-east more accessible.She said: “It’s great news that a new route is coming because recently it has seemed like everything is being withdrawn.“It’s fantastic to see a new destination and it’s great that someone is doing something to open Aberdeen up again.“Southend makes that side of London and the south-east accessible, and the fact it’s three times a day is great too.“I think it’s fantastic news. The more routes coming into Aberdeen the better.”The journey to Essex will take just over  minutes, with a further -minute train journey into London Liverpool Street.Loganair’s managing director Jonathan Hinckles said: “We’re acutely aware of the limited options for London air travel from Aberdeen following the closure of the Gatwick route and have responded to the Aberdeen business community’s calls for improved air links by stepping into the gap left behind.”Aberdeen International Airport managing director Steve Szalay added: “Regional connectivity to London is essential to Aberdeen for both business and leisure and London Southend offers a new alternative for our passengers.“The beauty of the new London Southend service lies in the ease of access to central London.“With train services to Liverpool Street taking less than an hour, passengers can reach the heart of London in quick time and get their trip off to the best possible start.”

title: dancing brings light and beauty amid the grief to ardfern
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Laura MaxwellWithin This Dust is an interpretive dance performance inspired by the most horrying incident of our time: the   terror attacks.A packed Craignish Village Hall held host to the Dundee-based Shaper Caper performance on Wednesday February .Inspired by photographs of the   fallout, choreographer Thomas Small has created a performance that has been seen to bring tears due to its beauty and the tragedy of this story. First performed in , Within This Dust has gone on to be staged all over the UK and internationally, including at the   memorial and museum.Especially inspired by Richard Drew#s unforgettable photograph, The Falling Man, Within This Dust details the experience of witness, Lisa Hood, and victim, Vince Virr, of the   attacks.The witness finds herself surrounded in dust, made of crumpled paper, and begins a grieving process of hunting through the papers, finding meaning in the words, as someone tries to tidy around her. The second act features the victim joining the witness, creating a connection that will inevitably be broken, when finally, in the third act, the victim is alone, caught between a choice of the smoke and fire within the collapsing building or the  metre drop to freedom.It was a very poignant performance, tenderly expressing the horror of the incident, perhaps now weakened due to overindulgence. When the lights came up everyone stayed where they were, perhaps a little too stunned to move. Chatter was in whispers, for respect to people who could not hear them.As the narrator of the show captured and pieced together from coverage of the attacks said, the dust has not settled, and never will. The losses of the people in the planes and buildings is still felt, and the wider western world is still wary, still learning, still recovering.Within This Dust manages to depict the horror of that day beautully, and more importantly, delicately. No easy task for a grieving world.PIC:Craignish Village Hall was full. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood amongst the #dust#. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Lisa Hood. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood collecting dust. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood and Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustVince Virr facing the smoke, or the window. _aWithinThisDust

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: districts week 08

One poem is set for each day, accompanied by a short explanation, a reflection, and a brief suggestion for our own thinking.Parishioners will be reading the poems at home for those who wish it there will be meetings to share thoughts and inspiration at Ardrishaig Church during the weeks of Lent and at Christ Church on Sundays. Lent begins this year on Ash Wednesday March .E.ON donated to Arrochar roof insulationVehicles used by the Arrochar Mountain Rescue Team will benefit from being garaged at a more constant temperature this winter after the E.ON Energising Communities Fund paid for £, worth of insulation to be fitted at the rescue post.The volunteers making up the Arrochar Mountain Rescue Team provide search and rescue assistance throughout Strathclyde when requested by Police Scotland and can be called upon  hours a day,  days a year.  Working across all mountainous terrain and in any weather condition, they use three vehicles which are kept in the garage attached to the mountain rescue post in Arrochar which was built in .After mechanics identied condensation and corrosion as the cause of the vehicles’ increasingly frequent and expensive mechanical and electrical problems, heating was installed at the garage last year to reduce their maintenance costs and improve their reliability.
