title: teenager-ordered-to-pay-1600-compensation-after-ransacking-house
story: A GALASHIELS teenager who damaged property at a house in Melrose has been ordered to pay pound in compensation.Greg Faris, of Hawthorn Road, wilfully or recklessly caused damage to the property in St Dunstans Road, and smearing blood on bedsheets on April .The -year-old also pleaded guilty to being in possession of ecstasy at Galashiels Police Station for which he was fined pound.Faris lodged pound at the bar as a first payment towards the compensation.

title: anniversary-celebrations-to-bring-hogg-back-into-fashion
story: NEXT year marks the th anniversary of Borders poet James Hoggrsquos birth and plans to mark the milestone are underway.And it is hoped the celebrations will bring the self-taught novelist back to the fore.Dr Adrian Hunter of Stirling University is joining forces with the Ettrick and Yarrow Community Development Companyto honour the Ettrick Shepherd.Hogg was born in the Ettrick Valley and worked almost all of his le as a shepherd.His best-known works include The Private Memoirs and Confessions of a Justied Sinner in , and two years earlier The Three Perils of Man: or War, Women and Witchcraft.The Ettrick Shepherd became internationally known during the th century.He had  volumes published during his letime and was well-known on both sides of the Atlantic.Hogg was popular amongst academics, especially in North America, with many of them circulating his books.In British and Scottish literature, he is highly regarded, however, over time awareness of his work has decreased.It is hoped the anniversary celebrations will recty this by promoting his work as well as drawing Hogg enthusiasts to the region from across the UK.Dr Adrian Hunter is a senior lecturer of English Studies at Stirling university.His role within the Hogg society is to raise public awareness of the poet.Dr Hunter told us: ldquoIt is really important to celebrate James Hogg as he is one of the great literary geniuses of the th century whose work is just as relevant now as it once was.ldquoHogg was an equal to poets in his day and by celebrating this anniversary we hope to raise him to the same level of recognition as Burns and Scott.ldquoWe are in conversation with writers and performers from across the Borders and want a big emphasise on his music, as it was a major part of Hoggrsquos work.ldquoThis event has great potential to boost local tourism by bringing people to the Borders to celebrate the le of Hogg."Hogg has many connections across the Borders that the team hope to emphasize.His local pub was the Gordon Arms hotel in the Yarrow Valley, and he was one the founders of the St Ronans Border Games which have been held every July since .The James Hogg exhibition in the Ettrick Valley, which contains many artefacts and originals donated by Lady Steel of Aikwood, and the Hogg monument at St Maryrsquos Loch have been celebrating the Ettrick Shepherdrsquos le for many years.The Borders celebrations will take place over  to mark the anniversary. No concrete dates have been set as the event is still being finalised. However, local people and businesses are encouraged to get involved to help promote Hoggrsquos Borders legacy.Internationally, the anniversary will be celebrated in Washington DC.Enthusiasts can attend an event held in the Library of Congress where they will be talking about Hoggrsquos le and Borderrsquos traditions.Stirling University is known as the world centre of Hoggs work.And they are currently doing a project to collect all the poets work and republish it. So far,  volumes of Hoggrsquos work have been collected, and  have been published.The project started in the mid s and the estimated finishing date wonrsquot be till .The programme of events is still in the planning stage and the organisers are currently raising money to hold the celebrations around the Borders and in Stirling.They are currently applying to ious sources for a six-figure sum to honour the literary great.If you would like to get involved or find out any more information, then contact Dr Adrian Hunter at adrian.hunter@stir.ac.uk or EYCDC Vicky Davidson at vicky@ettrickandyarrow.org.uk

title: glendinning-gets-fizzy-with-touring-science-show
story: MINI scientists from Glendinning Primary School grabbed their safety goggles last week to make their own fizzing potions.Primary one to three pupils got an introduction into chemistry when Generation Science visited their school on Thursday.They took part in the Get Fizzy workshop and served up some mysterious mixtures.Generation Science is a touring programme of fun science shows for younger children.And is delivered by Edinburgh Science, the international educational charity who aim to deliver the wonder of science to people around the world.The workshop was sponsored by EDF Renewables who are supporting a iety of Generation Science events across Scotland.Leanne Watson of EDF Renewables said: ldquoWe are proud to support Generation Science.ldquoThese fun and interactive workshops are an engaging way to encourage a new generation of scientists, who will be at the forefront of developing renewable energy and new technologies.Get Fizzy is a chemistry workshop for beginners where pupils learn about solids, liquids, gases and fizzes and how they can react.Acting Head Teacher of Glendinning Primary School, Nichola McCall, told us: ldquoWe were delighted to welcome the Generation Science tour to the school.ldquoGet Fizzy is a hands-on workshop that makes science fun and enjoyable."For some of our pupils, it was very exciting as it was their first ever introduction to chemistry.Over the last  years Generation Science has reached over one million pupils in Scotland.This year the tour will visit over  schools in  local authority areas from the Borders to the Shetland Isles.Get Fizzy is one of  educational shows and workshops provided by Generation Science and powered by EDF Energy.They are designed to make science exciting and easy to understand to help teachers cover the school science curriculum.

title: mp-mundell-muscles-up-ahead-of-brexit
story: TWEEDALE MP David Mundell is muscling up ahead of the final Brexit battles in Parliament.The Scottish Secretary landed a one-hour training session recently during a silent auction at the Eastgate Theatre in Peebles.And this week Mr Mundell pulled on his trainers for the session with Gillian Wrigley of The Health Rooms studios and treatment centre.The -year-old believes the initial pilates and general fitness hour was beneficial.He told us: "Despite the time pressures of politics, Ive been considering setting a little time aside to improve my physical fitness."Thats why I was delighted when the opportunity came along for some tuition from an expert like Gillian, who was a brilliant coach."As well as having a reputation for easing some aches and pains, it is also becoming increasingly popular as a general form of exercise."Mr Mundell, who also enjoys cycling, quipped: "I hope my fitness pledge to myself is easier to deliver than Brexit."Gillian, who runs The Health Rooms with husband Stephen, offers a range of services including physiotherapy, sports injury massage and podiatry.She said: "David was an enthusiastic and attentive student, who appreciates the benefits of exercise."I wish him well with his training and hope to see him back again soon."

title: 26-year-old-remanded-after-alleged-shoplifting-in-selkirk
story: A -year-old Selkirk man has been remanded in custody at the towns sherf court after being accused of stealing alcohol from a shop he was already banned from.James Birchall is charged with stealing three bottles of spirits from the Co-operative store in High Street, Selkirk, on Tuesday and breaching his bail conditions.He appeared from custody and pleaded not guilty to both charges.A trial date has been fixed for next month and Birchall was remanded in custody by Sherf Peter Paterson after no application was made for bail.

title: theyre-game-for-a-laugh-at-sainsburys
story: SHOPPERS are in for a laugh when they visit Sainsburys in lead up to Comic Relief.Throughout much of March customers will have the opportunity to join staff in sporting a red nose.And it has nothing to do with catching a cold.Comic Relief is ing to the supermarket chain to celebrate a  year partnership.The milestone will be marked in the Peebles branch with a number of fundraising events in the run-up to Red Nose Day.As well as a tombola, fancy dress and customer car wash, staff will be selling red noses to raise money for the charity.Customer trading manager Margot Swanston said: ldquoWe in Peebles Sainsburyrsquos love to be involved in Red Nose Day."We have a whole week of activities planned to raise money in store."We kick off with a quiz night and we are also holding a bake sale which all the budding bakers amongst our staff are helping with. Tombola and lsquoguess the weight of the cakersquo are also planned in.And customers wonrsquot see staff in their usual unorm on the main Friday either, as they will be decked out in a colourful array of fancy dress costumes.Margot added: ldquoWe are holding a car wash and a lsquobeat the manager challengersquo which will involve an Xbox gaming competition which Irsquom sure will be eagerly contested.Store Manager David Duncan added: ldquoWersquore really passionate about supporting this great cause and hope our customers continue to get involved and help support our exciting fundraising activities.

title: prominent-cockenzie-campaigner-larry-tomlins-remembered
story: Larry Tomlins, who was chairman of Cockenzie West Tenants and Residents Association, was involved in campaigns to reduce speeding and upgrade local park facilities in his community.The grandfather-of-two was an active supporter of the recent fight to implement speeding restrictions outside new housing at The Chimneys, Cockenzie, and helped oversee the trial and subsequent introduction of  miles per hourspeed limits in the Whin Park area of the village.Mr Tomlins, , grew up in Ayrshire and moved to Cockenzie more than  years ago, where he raised his family with we Ann.A consultant engineer, he ran his own successful business and still found the time to be an active member of his local community.He was a founding member of the tenantsrsquo and residentsrsquo association, which helped improve Whin Park for local families.Ward councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell said: ldquoLarry made a huge contribution to the tenantsrsquo and residentsrsquo association and the wider community. He understood and clearly articulated the interests of local people. He will be sorely missed.Laura Bishop from the campaign to reduce speeding at Avenue Road, outside The Chimneys, said: ldquoLarry was a lovely man who helped us with our campaign to make Avenue Road pelican crossing safer for the children using it to cross to get to school.ldquoSending condolences to his family.Mr Tomlins is survived by his we, his four children, his daughter-in-law and his two grandchildren.

title: man-caught-drink-driving-for-the-third-time
story: John Mercer was stopped by police in a Musselburgh street, where he was found to be nearly five times over the drink-drive limit.Mercer, from Dalkeith, was found to have mg of alcohol in ml of breath when he was pulled over last June ndash the legal limit is mg in ml of breath.Defence solicitor Nigel Bruce told Edinburgh Sherf Court on Monday that Mercer, , turned to alcohol as he ldquoreacts badly to pressure.Sherf Adrian Cottam was also told this was the third time Mercer had been caught drink-driving.Sherf Cottam told Mercer he was being sentenced to carry out  hours of unpaid work and placed on  months of supervision as a direct alternative to custody.Mercer was also banned from driving for the next  months during Mondayrsquos hearing.Mercer admitted to driving a vehicle with mg of alcohol in ml of breath at North High Street, Musselburgh, on June  last year.

title: single-primary-school-plan-for-prestonpans-to-go-ahead
story: The proposal to close the two schools and establish a new primary school covering nursery to P, operating from the existing school sites, followed a public consultation.Councillors agreed to progress the plans at a meeting of East Lothian Council on December .This decision needed to be ratied by Scottish Ministers.The new school will follow a single curriculum and a single headteacher will be appointed to oversee its management.The school structure in the town currently has nursery to P children attending the infant school before transferring to the primary school for P to P however, both schools operate their own curriculums independently.Fiona Robertson, the councilrsquos head of education, said: ldquoPrestonpans is the only area in East Lothian where nursery to P and P-P are taught across two schools.ldquoWe believe having one primary school, working under a single management structure, will benefit pupils at all levels of their learning as it does where in the county by ensuring a smoother progression through school and better coherence across the curriculum at all ages and stages.ldquoEducation Scotland has recognised the potential educational benefits and opportunities for greater coherence in the curriculum.ldquoWe have written to staff and parents to advise them of this decision. Our priority now is to work with the headteachers and the parent council chairs in both schools, and to support staff, parents and pupils during the move.

title: strikes-called-off-at-queen-margaret-university
story: Agreement between the University and College Union and QMU will ensure there will be no compulsory redundancies and no plans for further staff cuts.They are committed to work together on a number of other workplace issues.A joint statement also addresses how workloads will be managed and notes the trade union voice as being "valued and integral to the university".Oonagh OrsquoBrien, the universitys UCU spokesperson, said: "This has been a dficult time and staff have been deeply worried about their jobs and frustrated at the way changes have been made."This agreement means there will be no compulsory redundancies and ensures that changes due to reduced staff will be managed."It also allows us to move forward and work together to improve our workplace policies for the future."A spokesperson from Queen Margaret University said: "QMU management and UCU have reached an agreement to resolve the trade dispute between UCU and QMU."Strike action and action short of a strike have been called off with immediate effect."Both parties are pleased to have reached an agreement and are fully committed to rebuilding positive collective bargaining."A series of strikes, including one on Wednesday, were planned over job losses at the university after union bosses said talks had "ended without a satisfactory resolution".UCU members previously said they were angry at the loss of about  jobs, which represented a loss of seven per cent of the universityrsquos total workforce.In a recent strike ballot, two-thirds of UCU memberswho voted had backed strike action on a turnout of  per cent.

title: five-per-cent-rent-rise-in-east-lothian-is-approved
story: An annual rent rise of five per cent, approved by East Lothian Council this week, on top of the decision to increase council tax to the maximum . per cent, will see tenantsrsquo costs increase.SNP councillor Neil Gilbert claimed on Twitter the decision would hit tenants in Band D housing with additional bills of pound in the coming year.His claim came after the SNP Group called on the councilrsquos administration to reduce the proposed rent increase for the coming year to . per cent ndash inflation plus one per cent.The annual rent review proposed continuing with the yearly five per cent rise, which has been approved at every budget since , for another five years.Putting forward an amendment to the rent increase, Councillor Stuart Currie, leader of the SNP Group, argued that a lower increase was fairer given peoplersquos current wages.Mr Currie said: ldquoIt takes into account what people are seeing in wages and other payments they receive. It still maintainsthe surplus in housing accounts.East Lothian Council carried out a public consultation among residents who were asked whether they agreed with a five per cent increase in the coming years. Of the  per cent of council tenants who responded, a massive  per cent backed the increase.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, housing convenor, said tenants had given their support to the increase.He said: ldquoIt will still mean East Lothian will remain one of the lowest rents in Scotland.He also pointed out it would allow for poundmillion to be spent on modernisation and extensions of council properties in the coming year and poundmillion for new council housing.Councillor Jane Henderson, Conservative Leader of the Opposition, said that while the SNPrsquos proposal was a ldquovery reasonable representation, she would support the administrationrsquos five per cent increase.

title: residents-able-to-apply-for-electric-car-charging-points-near-their-homes
story: Residents who live in rural communities and do not have their own driveways can apply for a public charging point to be installed near their home.The pound, scheme, funded by the Department of Transportrsquos Office for Low Emission Vehicles , has seen additional charging points placed in smaller communities including Stenton, East Linton, West Barns and Aberlady.The council has also identied potential sites for new charging points in Pencaitland, Ormiston and Macmerry, and has asked any residents who have or are considering an electric vehicle to contact themthey want one in their communities.The council said the number of registered electric vehicles in the county was  times what it was just six years ago, when there were fewer than .Now there are nearly  registered vehicles and the county has installed  public chargers to date.It received pound, to install town centre charging points this year and pound, from the Scottish Government to expand the scheme to key locations.The funding from OLEV is for people living in residential areas where there have been inidual requests from an electric car owner or potential owner.A council spokesperson said: ldquoIniduals without their own driveways who wish to use an electric car are encouraged to request an on-street EV chargepoint close to their home, and we will apply for the grants available from OLEV to support this where possible.To request a charging point, email evcharging@eastlothian.gov.uk. A map of charging points available in East Lothian is atchargeplacescotland.org

title: mans-driving-ban-after-refusing-to-give-breath-test
story: Adrian Magee was staying at Seton Sands Holiday Village when he was pulled over by officers on suspicion of drink-driving at about midnight on September  last year.He was taken to Dalkeith Police Station, where he twice refused to take part in a breath test and stated: ldquoI do not give my consent.Magee, currently of Sutton-on-Trent, Nottinghamshire, pleaded guilty to the offence during an appearance at Edinburgh Sherf Court on Monday.Sherf Thomas Welsh was told that twice previously Magee had been caught over the drink-driving limit, including an offence in England which took place just four days before the latest case.Defending solicitor Kenneth Woodburn said that Magee did not comply with the request to take the test due to ldquohistorical matters between him and the police.Mr Woodburn said that -year-old Magee ldquono longer drinks and no longer drives and had sold his car following his latest arrest.The solicitor asked the sherf to deal with the matter that day instead of deferring for reports as his client had a -hour round trip to get to court in Edinburgh.Following a short adjournment, Sherf Welsh agreed to the request and banned Magee from driving for three years and fined him pound.Magee pleaded guilty to failing to provide two specimens of breath at Dalkeith Police Station on September  last year.

title: building-work-in-full-swing-at-new-fraser-centre-in-tranent
story: Construction work is now under way to create the new Fraser Centre, with a target for the facility to open in October.The building, on the townrsquos Winton Place, is at the heart of a pound. million project, with the former Winton Cinema becoming home to a multi-al, attractive arts and cultural centre, complete with cafe.Demolition work started in April last year and finished in November.Since then, construction work has started on the site.Jonny Russell and David Orr, from The Fraser Centre Community Trust, gave the good news to the townrsquos community council last month.Mr Orr was delighted to see work progressing and said: ldquoI think I was on site when the first steel lorries arrived and it was definitely an exciting moment.ldquoWe have been working on this for so long, so many years, and finally to see the new building begin to take shape ndash it was a fantastic feeling.ldquoTo actually see that, even though work has been going on very hard for a long time, just seeing that happen showed to everybody there is a lot of progress going on.ldquoYou get that level of interest and excitement in the public is increasing as well.The ambitious plans for the site date back to the end of .Since then, research has been carried out and funding found to transform the building.Plans for the major upgrade were lodged with East Lothian Council in the summer of  and given the green light in February the following year.Mr Orr, who is the community trustrsquos project and development manager, told the Courier: ldquoI do feel the finish line is in sight.ldquoI said in October that it seemed a long way away but it will fly through the speed the building is going up.ldquoIt just makes you realise we will be in there very soon and we cannot wait [after] so many years planning this and preparing for it.ldquoEven when we entered , we realised it was the year we were going to be opening.ldquoIt is a good feeling then and, as it goes up, it is beginning to take shape and it is becoming very real.Community councillors thanked Mr Orr and Mr Russell for their hard work on the project.David Forrest, the grouprsquos chairman, said he had spoken to a number of people in the town who were looking forward to the facility opening.He added: ldquoThere is a crane on the site.ldquoI think the steelwork must be getting ready to go up.ldquoIt is going to be a big benefit to Tranent, especially the bottom end of Tranent.

title: pupils-about-to-start-life-at-new-wallyford-primary-school
story: They said a fond farewell to their former school at Salters Road, taking to the stage with a final drama production Robin and the Sherwood Hoodies.The final lessons were taught last Friday before headteacher Mhairi Stratton led a procession out of the school to the gates.The size and scale of new house building in the area meant the school was no longer able to meet the needs of the community.Land was secured on the east side of the town as part of the St Clementrsquos Wells development to create a new campus to offer room for modern educational facilities for a growing school population, surrounded by plenty of outdoor space.East Lothian Councilrsquos development partner, Hub South East, was responsible for delivering the project and appointed Morrison Construction as the contractor. The project received a pound.m grant from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Scotlandrsquos Schools for the Future programme.The finished building offers ldquoa light-filled and airy space which has been planned to maximise childrenrsquos opportunities for learning.A ldquomuted palette of colours has been used throughout the school, providing ldquoa calm environment for learning while echoing the landscapes that surround it.Open-plan spaces enable shared learning alongside quiet and more private spaces and meeting rooms.The building provides  classrooms and a further four nursery playrooms offering up to  spaces.Retractable bleacher style seating has been included in the large sports hall for whole school assemblies, events or performances. The outside space includes all-weather pitches, basketball hoops, landscaping and grassed areas. The school also includes resources for wider use by the community, including a new library which is currently being completed internally.The nursery area has its own entrance and features four large playrooms, each equipped with a kitchen, and toilet facilities are built around a shared space that can be used for dining or parent events. Each room has access to the outdoor space.Fiona Robertson, head of education at East Lothian Council, said: ldquoThis is an exciting time for children, families and staff at Wallyford Primary School.ldquoThe new school offers great scope for shared learning and community use, offering benefits to the wider area too. Great consideration has been given to every aspect of the design to maximise the opportunities for children and I look forward to seeing all of the children settle in to their new space.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet spokesperson for education, said: ldquoWallyford is undergoing a period of change with signicant investment in the area.ldquoThe council has rightly secured contributions from housebuilders towards new facilities and infrastructure.ldquoThe new school building brings together the primary, nursery and library in a single, modern space providing a focus for the whole community. As well as the spacious and welcoming interior, Irsquom also pleased to see the large amounts of outdoor space that the children have to explore ndash from sports pitches to planted courtyards.ldquoIrsquod like to thank Mhairi Stratton, her staff, pupils and the parent council for their input and support throughout the project. I wish them all many happy and successful years in the new Wallyford Primary School.Ms Stratton said: ldquoThis building will bring so much joy and opportunity to the Wallyford community. It is all we could of hoped for and more.ldquoI have been very impressed at how project designers have taken on board the childrenrsquos ideas and turned them into a reality. This is a very special place.The school also got the thumbs-up from pupils, who are excited at settling into their new environment.Alex Hill said: ldquoEveryone will be very happy here. It is so colourful.Rory Paton said: ldquoI really like our new school. It was very exciting to see our classrooms and the cool furniture.Tayla Paton added: ldquoIt is amazing. I love everything about it. Lots of people are excited about the playground. There are lots of fun things to do.No decision has yet been taken on what will happen to the former school

title: council-budget-in-musselburgh-interesk-cafe-to-close-workers-at-musselburgh-east-community-learning-centre-to-move
story: Three Community Learning and Developmentworkers, who currently use office space at Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre , are also to be relocated, with a potential saving of pound, in  , and additional options for use of the building are to be explored.The budget, put forward by the minority Labour administration and backed by the Conservative Opposition, was agreed at Tuesdayrsquos meeting.Withdrawing the Inter.Esk Cafe facility at Bridge Street will result in cost savings of pound, a year and it is envisaged that the building, a small retail office space, will be offered for lease to interested parties in due course.The facility was set up in  to provide a computer-focused youth project that works with young people mainly aged  to  from the local community. Activities will be relocated where in Musselburgh.A spokesman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe building on Bridge Street, which currently houses the cafeacute, is used for a small number of hours each week. The initiative was launched in  when internet access was less readily available at home, school or in other settings.ldquoIn recent years, visits to the building have tended to be for generic youth activities. There is limited space for such activities within the building which can be accommodated where, enabling access to a wider range of activities and resources. This will allow us to make increasingly effective use of assets in a challenging financial climate.Turning to the MECLC, he stressed that the centre, a council building managed on its behalf by FES, would not close and there would be no displacement of current activities. It was, he added, about ldquomaximising use of the building in the delivery of services.The spokesman explained: ldquoIt is proposed that a small number of CLD staff who currently work out of office facilities within the Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre, relocate to office facilities at an alternative location. These staff are not involved with the day-to-day running of the building or the activities which take place there, as it is managed by FES under a separate contract. This arrangement continues.ldquoWe are always keen to maximise the use of community buildings and are exploring whether it might be possible to establish additional provision within the building in the future. This will be discussed in detail with the management committee and stakeholders in due course. The proposal relates to year two of the budget ndash  .Councillor Andy Forrest, Labour, a ward member and Depute Provost of East Lothian, said: ldquoWith the current restraints on council budgets due to cuts in funding from the Scottish Government, moving the Inter.Esk Cafeacute to a new venue where it will not be a stand-alone facility will enable staff to promote digital inclusion to a wider number of people and therefore service a wider range of the community.He added: ldquoWith regard to MECLC, this facility has been on the rise since it was opened. Relocation of staff will not have any effect on activities that are run from or at the centre. The management group will continue to work with and support East Lothian staff with projects and activities.Councillor Stuart Currie, a Musselburgh member and leader of the SNP Group, said: ldquoThe whole point of the Inter.Esk Cafe was to provide facilities for young people in a safe place. We donrsquot have a community centre in Musselburgh. We have got the Brunton Hall but not a drop-in community centre.He added that there had been no discussions about the proposal with the Musselburgh Common Good Committee which he chaired although the building was in the Common Good portfolio. He added that Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council or the wider community had not been consulted.He described the decision to relocate CLD staff as a ldquocash grab.Mr Currie said: ldquoMy concern is that the centre was built in the heart of the community and the whole point of having people working for the council is that they should be based in the community. It is a cost-saving exercise, not about improving things. If they are not based in the community, where are they going to be  There is no point in having people in John Muir House in Haddington. pound, is a huge amount of money for dferent options around office space.Councillor Katie Mackie, Conservative, said: ldquoWith a pound.m reduction in core revenue funding for the council as a result of the SNP government budget, some dficult decisions had to be made. The East Lothian Council budget consultation findings showed that where hard choices had to be made ndash the rationalise and review of council assets and office provision was preferred over other options.ldquoWhilst the Inter.Esk Cafeacute will be ed to the Common Good the activities that take place at the cafeacute will be relocated to another building such as the Fisherrow Community Centre. Relocating the CLD staff from MECLC allows other options for this building to be considered including use by East Lothian Council departments or sub-let to a third sector organisation.Councillor John Williamson, SNP, commented on the closure of the Inter.Esk Cafe, saying: ldquoFor the sake of pound, a year the Inter.Esk Cafe is going to close following decisions made by Labour and Conservative councillors at the East Lothian Council budget meeting on Tuesday. The cafeacute provides a safe place for young people aged - to meet, have access to computers, make friends and get support for any issues they are having to deal with.ldquoIt is centrally located in Musselburgh and on a main bus route so is easily accessible to users. It is also currently being used as a venue for the  Adult Learning Programme. It does great work with young people andthe provision is not continued where in the town it is our young people who are going to suffer ndash is a saving of pound, worth that.

title: ormiston-woman-celebrates-turning-100
story: Isabella lsquoIsarsquo Raeburn reached the milestone on Saturday at her home on Ormistonrsquos Tynemount Road.The mum-of-one grew up on Tranentrsquos Lammermoor Terrace before marrying Willie Raeburn.The couple, who were married for  years, moved to Elphinstone before settling in Ormiston along with son Billy.Wendy Raeburn told the Courier her gran, who previously worked as a cleaner at the villagersquos primary school, loved making cakes.She said: ldquoShe loved making her family and friends cakes in the village. She would make wedding cakes, big birthday cakes, th anniversary cakes and for the miners welfare as well.Willie passed away at the age of , with Isa having four granddaughters, four great grandchildren and one great, great grandson.

title: tom-kitchin-and-nbc-cameras-head-to-brand-family-farm-at-east-fortune
story: VisitScotland teamed up with US network NBC for an episode of st Look, where host Johnny lsquoBananasrsquo Devenanzio travels to popular destinations in search of the best food and entertainment the area has to offer.Filming began at chef Tomrsquos new pub The Bonnie Badger in Gullane, which opened in December.The production team travelled to East Fortune Farm after it was decided that a first-hand look into who supplies some of the meat for the pub was required for the episode.Jane Brand, , mum and the farm administrator, said: ldquoWe had a brilliant morning on the farm showing the team all the dferent breeds of lamb.ldquoTomrsquos passion for his food is incredible, he takes the whole carcass and makes a dish out of everything he is brilliant at what he does. We have supplied lambs to Tom before and have started supplying to The Bonnie Badger ndash our first order was last week.The Brand family relocated in  to East Fortune Farm, where three generations currently reside.The farm has won multiple awards over the years, as well as opening a successful farm shop last July.Neil Christison, regional director of VisitScotland, said: ldquoWersquore delighted to be working once again with NBC to show what makes Scotland a dynamic and unique destination, from our history and heritage to our food and drink.ldquoAs part of the trip, we welcomed st Look host Johnny Bananas to East Lothian, where he chatted about Scottish produce with Michelin-starred chef Tom Kitchin and the Brand family of East Fortune Farm.The episode will be aired on NBC in March.

title: section-of-busy-dunbar-road-closed-for-two-weeks
story: Drainage works are being carried out on a -metre section of Brodie Road, to the west of the junction with Steadings Crescent.The works mean a y ersion, with drivers advised to turn on to Yosemite Park, the U, the A and then Spott Road. The roadworks are due to finish on March .A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe works are undertaken by Advance Construction on behalf of Persimmons. The drainage works require extensive excavation and therefore traffic cannot be maintained safely.ldquoThe road closure has been put in place at the request of Advance Construction and it was their responsibility to do a letter drop to inform residents. Additionally, advance information signage was put up at the location on Friday, an advert was in the Courier on Thursday, the notice has been on TellMeScotland since the beginning of February where all the council information is notied, and Dunbar Community Council put up the legal document on Facebook.

title: win-a-share-of-10000-funding-for-your-group
story: Now in its third year, the scheme aims to provide support to a wide range of organisations and community projects.Since , pound, has been awarded ndash with this yearrsquos donations set to take that total to pound,.Last year saw an amazing  causes apply to the East Lothian bursary ndash with  local organisations benefitting.Donations were made to groups ranging from Muddy Buddies in Dunbar to the John Bellany Day Centre in Port Seton.Philip Hogg, sales and marketing director with CALA Homes , said: ldquoCALA has always been committed to making a positive and lasting contribution to the communities in which it builds, through an active programme of local charity donations, community support and sponsorship.ldquoThis is the third year that we have ran the bursary in East Lothian, and each time we have been blown away by the number of groups who are making a positive impact in the area.ldquoThe bursary scheme gives us the chance to see what is needed locally and where funding would be best placed to support the community.ldquoWe are looking forward to hearing from more local charities and causes, large and small, about the great work they do and how CALA can lend a hand.A selection  will decide recipients of this yearrsquos funding.Robbie Scott, Courier editor, added: ldquoWe look forward to another successful year and seeing how this money will help greatly benefit communities in East Lothian.ldquoSadly, wersquore unable to support every applicant but there is no doubt this fund is having a hugely positive impact on our groups and good causes.Apply for a share of the community bursary by downloading an application form from the CALA website here.The closing deadline for entries is Friday, March .

title: musselburgh-pub-staggs-voted-best-in-the-lothians-by-camra
story: The hostelry on North High Street beat the Dean Tavern at Newtongrange into second place, while third was the Grey Horse at Balerno.CAMRA members in Edinburgh and South East Scotland announced the winners for Lothian, Borders and Edinburgh City this week.The overall Edinburgh and South East Scotland winner will be announced in mid-March.In Edinburgh City, the joint winners were Dreadnought and Stockbridge Tap, while Cloisters was third. The Bridge Inn at Peebles came first in the Borders section, with runner-up Rutherfords at Kelso and the Plough, Leitholm, in third place.Staggs, also known as The Volunteer Arms, is no stranger to winning accolades. Last year it was named the best pub in Scotland and Ireland for the third time, having won the title in  and .It was also named Pub of the Year for the UK in  and has scooped the Best in the Lothians award  times, and the Edinburgh and South East Scotland title eight times.Last year was The Volunteer Arms th anniversary of being in the same family after opening in . Nigel Finlay and his brother Ian are the current owners.Nigel runs the pub with the help of his we Donna and daughter Katie McKenzie.He said: "Once again we are delighted to be voted Lothianrsquos Pub of the Year."We look forward to the year ahead and will continue our mission to serve great-quality ale."

title: group-not-in-favour-of-blanket-20mph-speed-limit-in-north-berwick
story: A mph speed limit was adopted on most roads in Dunbar last summer, but, at a recent meeting, North Berwick community councillors were not in favour of something similar happening in their own town.Judy Lockhart, North Berwick Community Councilchairwoman, said the lower limit in Dunbar had been ldquoineffective.It was, though, generally agreed that there were roads in North Berwick which would benefit from the speed reduction ndash however, a blanket reduction would not be beneficial to the town, community councillors believed.A road safety campaign which would include reminders for people to drive to the road conditions was suggested as a solution.Bill Macnair, community councillor, said: ldquoA speed reduction covering the whole town is unworkable. Each inidual town should sit down, identy and review the real problems instead of over-simplying with a mph blanket speed limit.However, Mr Macnair did feel that High Street and Forth Street would benefit from becoming mph instead of mph.There are currently  roads in North Berwick with a mph speed limit, including Lochbridge Road.

title: funding-first-for-new-primary-school-in-haddington
story: Work on the new -class school is set to get under way this month at the new Letham Mains housing estate on the western edge of Haddington.But while future residents of the estate, which is earmarked for more than  homes, will send their children to the new school, pupils moving into the neighbouring new Haddington Manse and Moncrieff Meadows estates at Gateside face up to a .-mile walk past it to the townrsquos established school.Morrison Construction, which is working on the new Wallyford Primary School and the East Lothian Community Hospital, will build the school after being awarded the pound.m contract.The county is undergoing a surge in building after the Scottish Government ordered it to provide land for , new homes.And housing developers are being ordered to contribute towards the cost of new school buildings and extensions as part of the deal.The new Letham Primary School is the first which will be entirely funded by money from developers in East Lothian however, that is not the reason for the exclusion of neighbouring pupils.Education chiefs insist that decision came down to timing, with plans for the school site made before the developments at Gateside were approved.The decision to restrict the new schoolrsquos catchment area means that children living just a few streets away will walk past the building to the centre of the town and enrol in the recently merged Haddington Primary School ndash which saw the townrsquos main infant school and primary school brought under one umbrella last year.East Lothian Council said the cost of extending the Letham Mains school site to accommodate the neighbouring families would have been ldquosignicant, telling parents the existing school could be adapted to meet their needs.Ward councillor Shamin Akhtar, who is also the local authorityrsquos cabinet spokeswoman for education, said: ldquoWork is well under way at Letham Mains to provide  new homes, including affordable houses, for our community.ldquoIrsquom pleased that the contract has been awarded for Letham Primary School and this important part of the development can move forward.ldquoI look forward to following its progress.The new school is expected to be ready for the start of the school year from August .The school will have  classrooms suitable for pre-school and primary teaching, a dining hall, social space and a two-court PE hall with retractable seating for performance and community use.Until now, new schools and extensions have been funded by a combination of developersrsquo contributions, council funding and Scottish Government grants.

title: 21-musselburgh-area-projects-vying-for-funding-vote-for-your-favourite
story: Members of Musselburgh Area Partnership, which is organising the initiative, are hoping the whole community will get involved to decide how to spend a pound, cash windfall to address the issues.Voting takes place online or at a series of drop-in roadshows, some with breakfast on offer, where volunteers will be on hand to help. There are also displays at outlets such as community centres, Musselburgh Grammar School and the Hollies Day Centre.The area partnership received pound, as part of the Scottish Governmentrsquos Community Choices Funding for   to give people a direct voice in how funds should be invested on priorities in their local areas as part of Participatory Budgeting .This was supplemented by funding from the area partnership, which allocates a budget from East Lothian Council to a iety of local priorities and initiatives.A total of  projects have been shortlisted after meeting the initiativersquos criteria ndash  applications were received and an independent  considered them to ensure they met the guidelines and aims.Iain Clark, area partnership chairman, said: ldquoThey had to be a brand new project or completely separate addition which would have a dferent value. We were delighted with the response. There are a lot of good and erse projects.The Democratic Society of Scotland is hosting and funding the online vote which runs for three weeks to March .All those aged eight and upwards with an EH postcode are eligible to vote. Each person is allowed six votes for their chosen projects.Mr Clark said: ldquoThe highest scoring project will get its money and we will just go down the list until the money is used up.ldquoThere were only two projects which applied for the full pound,. They get what theyrsquove applied for.ldquoWe could fund six projects, we could fund  projects, it depends on the score and what theyrsquove asked for.ldquoWe will have an afternoon announcement event at The Brunton on Saturday, March , from pm to .pm. The announcement will be made on a big screen, one by one.He said the area partnership would also look at the unsuccessful projects to seethey linked into the Musselburgh Area Plan.Janice MacLeod, vice-chairperson of the area partnership, added: ldquoWe really want to make sure we want to reach people that poverty and inequalities are affecting.The roadshows include: February , Gate House, Stepping Out, noon to pm February, Tesco, am to pm First Step Project, am to noon Brunton Hall, am to pm February , Whitecraig Community Centre, pm to pm, and again on February , am to pm March , am to noon, Fisherrow Community Centre and March , Wallyford Community Centre, am to .am and .pm to .pm.The vote is live at eastlothian.gov.uk musselburghapThe projects are:Musselburgh Kindness Fund ndash to provide social workers, family workers, health workers and community staff with access to small amounts of funds to support families in crisis with items like power cards, telephone credits, essential items such as nappies and vouchers for public transport.Mobile Fruit in Musselburgh area ndash to put a mobile van on the road one day per week to go around Wallyford, Whitecraig and Musselburgh East, including Pinkie, selling fresh produce to customers.Silver Surfers ndash the Hollies Day Centre is looking to help older people stay safe online and make the most of the internet.The Big Impact Project ndash Black Diamond Thai Boxing Club makes learning for adults and young people, re-engaging them through programmes and activities involving combat sport and alternative approaches to education and development through partnership working.Summer Holiday Playscheme Provision for Wallyford  Whitecraig ndash a free programme of extracurricular summer activities including lunch for primary school aged children. To engage families through stimulating activities, directly addressing the importance of play and attachment. Run in local community centres.Play on Pedals  Big Read Project ndash highlighting that reading to young children sets them up to succeed and riding a bike improves physical fitness, a childrsquos learning development and mental health.Connect ndash reaching out to vulnerable women who have experienced trauma to offer structured arts activities and give respite and rehabilitation to the people who need it most. The group will help offer a pathway into community activities and society for those who have been excluded.Putting Money in Your Pocket ndash to help people to maximise their household income through benefit uptake, accessing affordable credit and switching to cheaper contracts.Wallyford P Transition Programme ndash a series of adventurous outdoor activity days to develop self-esteem, self-confidence and social inclusion.Musical Memories ndash to provide a regular weekly group for people suffering from memory loss strokes and mental health issues to enjoy listening to music.Wallyford, Whitecraig Tool Library ndash reducing the need to purchase costly new tools and helping to build a Musselburgh Tool Library to save on costs and storage.The Big Family Food Garden ndash bringing family and friends together to have fun growing healthy, fresh food free in a welcoming local community allotment.Wallyford Gets Active ndash multisport equipment for Wallyford families to get active. This project will create a working group of children, families and professionals to introduce more physical activities to Wallyford, providing the equipment and facilities to make it accessible to the community.M-PACT Musselburgh ndash Parent And Child Together ndash connecting young people, parents and carers and schools to create a stronger community. Working together to develop family connection and openness to education, learning and employment.The Heavy Sound Community Music Project ndash changing lives through music by bringing young people together who have faced signicant challenges, helping them to re-engage through a range of electronic music and alternative creative arts-related activities in the community.Eat Better Live Better ndash helping young people who are care experienced to eat in a healthy way on a challenging budget by offering cooking sessions and encouraging fun and flare in the kitchen. Ingredient bags to replicate at home will be provided.Margaret Oliphant Community Garden ndash to allow pupils to explore and understand the growth of plants and where food comes from. Pupils and volunteers will work together to grow crops available for the whole community through a food shelf in the Margaret Oliphant Library, part of the new building of Wallyford Primary SchoolMusselburgh Community Kitchen ndash to provide a sociable environment to learn new cooking skills which are affordable and healthy, for all ages and all abilities.Campie Cares ndash to help families reduce the cost of the school day and learn without worrying about money. To give children financial help towards attending one school trip and P camp. Help run free family events to offer help to protect against poverty.Summer Community Cafe at First Step ndash providing a community cafe for all to enjoy that is free. The cafe will provide a breakfast and warm lunch to people through the summer holidays and will be a chance for people of all ages to socialise and eat healthily.Families of the Future ndash to provide new opportunities and experiences for parents and families, increasing skill and knowledge, and promoting positive relationships between parents and professionals through the local community. To promote positive health and wellbeing in parents and children through a free and accessible programme.

title: starbucks-eyeing-up-site-in-haddington
story: Euro Garages Ltd, which is transforming the former Raceland karting site near Gladsmuir into a roadside services hub, has applied to East Lothian Council to develop land at Gateside West.The site, off the B West Road, is next to Persimmon Homesrsquo Haddington Manse development.It was previously earmarked for a pub restaurant but could now become home to East Lothianrsquos first Starbucks.The coffee shop giant is not named on the planning application itself but drawings of the proposed development submitted to the local authority by Euro Garages Ltd are labelled as the lsquoStarbucks sitersquo.Says the planning application: ldquoIt is considered that the development will provide both a modern food and drink facility, which will offer an accessible lsquothird placersquo to the surrounding residential areas, for social gatherings and as a meeting place for local community groups.If approved, the coffee shop would employ about  people and be open seven days a week from am to pm, with parking for  vehicles, including two disabled spaces and two electric car spaces.Paul Darling, of the townrsquos community council, had mixed feelings about the project.He said: ldquoIrsquom happy to see some sort of infrastructure but you can already have a cup of coffee every day of the week in Haddington without going into the same establishment twice.Euro Garages was given the green light by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee earlier this month for the former Raceland site.More than  jobs are expected to be created at that site, which will become home to a -hour petrol station and fast food drive-thru, with additional fast food and coffee shop drive-thrus open daily.Euro Garages already has  Starbucks operating out of its sites, which stretch across the UK and beyond.Three of Haddingtonrsquos ward councillors ndash John McMillan, Brian Small and Tom Trotter ndash sit on the local authorityrsquos planning committee, which could make the decision on the plans.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, who also represents the town, is not part of the committee and said: ldquoFirstly itrsquos important that whatever plans are put forward that they support our town centre. So, in that respect, I will await to see the ideas that are being put forward by the developer, and will be asking the question as to how they will support this aim.In , planning permission was given for the creation of a pub restaurant on the site, along with  houses and business light industrial units.Although the housing has been completed, neither the industrial units nor pub restaurant have been built.Instead, an unsuccessful bid was made to create  more houses on the site earmarked for the pub restaurant. That was rejected, with the council keen to see the land retained for employment.After being contacted by the Courier for a comment, a spokesperson for Starbucks said: ldquoUnfortunately, we donrsquot have anything to share at the moment.

title: east-lothian-mp-shares-his-views-on-eight-labour-mps-resigning
story: Martin Whitfield, who was elected as MP for East Lothian in , has spoken following eight fellow Labour MPs resigning from the party.Seven MPs ndash Luciana Berger, Ann Coffey, Mike Gapes, Chris Leslie, Gavin Shuker, Angela Smith and Chuka Umunna ndash announced their decision on Monday, which comes in protest at Labour leader Jeremy Corbyns leadership, as well as the handling of allegations of anti-Semitism in the Labour Party.They were joined on Wednesday by an eighth MP, Joan Ryan, as well as three Conservative MPs who resigned from their party.The  MPs will now sit in Parliament as the Independent Group.Commenting on the Labour resignations, Mr Whitfield said: ldquoThe MPs who have resigned are good colleagues and friends and I am very sad that they felt they had no other option but to leave the party.ldquoMy own position is that I was immensely proud to be elected as a Scottish Labour MP here in East Lothian and have never considered leaving."I am Labour through and through and will continue to fight my corner within the party.ldquoHowever, the departure of these seven colleagues highlights the importance of the party leadership urgently addressing issues like anti-Semitism and the behaviour of a minority of members, as well as listening to members and supporters on Brexit.ldquoHistory shows us that it is only when Labour is operating as a broad church, open, inclusive and tolerant of a range of opinions, that it can unite to deliver the change working people need.

title: musselburgh-man-given-interim-asbo
story: Jordan Buchan, , of Goose Green Avenue, has been banned from shouting, swearing, or using aggressive, abusive or intimidating language or behaviour within his property or within Goose Green Avenue, or permitting or encouraging others to do the same.Mr Buchan is also banned from engaging in acts of physical violence or permitting or encouraging others to do the same in or near a property at Goose Green Avenue.The interim ASBO also bans Mr Buchan from generating any kind of excessive noise such as the repeated banging or slamming of doors and having more than two visitors to his property, except those there in the course of their employment.A council spokesperson said: ldquoEast Lothian Council will take the appropriate legal action against those who persistently behave in a way that causes alarm and distress to others."Anyone in East Lothian who is affected by anti-social behaviour can call the councilrsquos dedicated  hours a day helpline on  .

title: couples-quick-wedding-after-brides-dad-given-weeks-to-live
story: Bex Wood, neacutee Cunningham, was not even engaged when she found out that her dad, George Cunningham, had just weeks to live.Bex, along with boyfriend Ali Wood, quickly got engaged and got married just six days after the doctors broke the bad news to her dad.She told the Courier: ldquoThe wedding was brilliant.ldquoIt was quite bittersweet but from looking back at photographs, everybody commented on how happy everybody was.ldquoWe could have made it a sad day but we did not want that.ldquoIt was a still a celebration it was perfect, the weather was great ndash everything.ldquoThat was how it would have gonewe took a couple of years to plan it.George, , of Longniddry, had been suffering from stomach pains last year.Bex told the Courier: ldquoHe was diagnosed with lymphoma last June.ldquoThey said they were putting him on a curative plan and said to him he could be home and cured by Christmas.ldquoHe was getting treatment but then in October he started to get more treatment.ldquoThey did tests and just found out it was not working and he only had weeks to live.Ali and Bex had been together for five years and had spoken of getting married but had never really put any plans into motion.However, after the diagnosis, Ali went shopping for an engagement ring and proposed on the Sunday.The couple, who live in Prestonpans, tied the knot on the Thursday at Longniddry Parish Church before a reception at Archerfield House.Despite the short timeframe, Bex said the couple were not overly stressed by the occasion, with Alirsquos sister-in-law Lyndsay putting things together.Bex, , said: ldquoYou need a team of people to help. We hardly did any of it ourselves ndash Alirsquos sister-in-law pretty much did all of it.ldquoShe was the events planner at Archerfield and she did pretty much all of it.ldquoFamily did bits and pieces but Lyndsay did most of it so we cannot take any of the credit.The happy couple were married on November , with George walking his daughter down the aisle in front of  guests.Medical sales rep Bex said: ldquoHe was absolutely fine on the day.ldquoHe was a bit tired and went for a lie down but he walked me down the aisle no bother.ldquoHe did his speech and the first dance together and then he just sat and everybody chatted to him.George sadly passed away on November , with the funeral taking place in the same church.Bex and Ali, who works as a field sales manager, decided to hold off on a honeymoon, with the couple jetting off to Dubai and the Males next month.Bex added: ldquoWe wanted to spend as much time with him as possible.ldquoWe had no idea in terms of timeframes so we spent everyday with him.An online fundraising page has also been set up to raise money for Bloodwisego to justgiving fundraising alastair-wood

title: substation-plan-at-former-cockenzie-power-station-site-approved
story: The site, which is owned by East Lothian Council and had been earmarked as having the potential to bring more than , jobs to the community, has been at the centre of a battle between the community, the council and windfarm company Inch Cape.Ministers called in the planning application from Inch Cape,which wants to bring energy from a planned offshore windfarm onshore at the site, before East Lothian Council had made any ruling on it.The call-in was controversially made while First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was visitingChina, where she met representatives of the Chinese state-owned Red Rock company, which owns Inch Cape.Issuing their decision, Scottish Ministers said they agreed with the Scottish Government reporterrsquos findings that the substation was of ldquonational importance.East Lothian Council and local communities had argued it would ldquosterilise the site for future economic development.However, the reporter noted that the substation would take up less than  per cent of the former power station site.

title: new-cemetery-at-dunbar-gets-the-go-ahead
story: A total of , lairs,  ashes-only lairs and an area of woodland burial space will be created at Newtonlees, on the eastern edge of the town.The announcement brings to an end fears that the town would be left without any burial space.Deer Park Cemetery, opposite the newly-approved burial ground, is nearly at capacity.Now, the new cemetery is expected to serve the people of Dunbar and surrounding area for at least  years.The announcement was welcomed by ward councillor Norman Hampshire, who was keen to see the new cemetery opened quickly.He said: ldquoIt will take time for people to do the work they have to do to get the facility into a place that can be used.ldquoI know Stuart Pryde [council principal amenities officer] and his team have been ready and waiting for this to happen.Deer Park Cemetery, which has , lairs, opened in  and is expected, according to the council, to reach capacity by the summer of next year.Plans to extend the cemetery fell through, with the council then forced to look for land for a new cemetery.Currently, the new site is being used as agricultural land but work is expected to begin in the near future on transforming the .-hectare site off the A.According to the planning officerrsquos report: ldquoThe supporting information submitted with the application states that the burial site is required to meet both the immediate needs of Dunbar town but also to serve the needs of the wider cluster of communities for the next - years in accordance with the councilrsquos approved Burial Ground Strategy.ldquoThe general layout of the Newtonlees Cemetery reflects best practice in terms of modern burial ground provision.ldquoThe layout affords a degree of choice from traditional coffin interment through interment of cremated remains and an allocation of space for natural burial within a meadow woodland area which will, as it develops, also provide an enhanced setting for the facility.The cemetery is part of larger plans for the site, which were first discussed by councillors in .At that time, plans for more than  houses on land at Newtonlees Farm were approved, despite the area of land being outwith the sites identied at that stage by the councilrsquos Local Development Plan and recommended for refusal by the local authorityrsquos planning officers.At that time, the vote was tied at -, with Mr Hampshire given the casting vote.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said details were still to be finalised before a date could be confirmed for the cemetery opening.She added: ldquoHaving secured approval and agreement to purchase the ground, we can now ensure that local burial space supply will continue for the area without risk of a break in service.

title: tims-tales-the-kings-chair
story: IT HAS been a time of lsquoborrowed daysrsquo recently. Such days are ones which have been borrowed from another month, and I think given the temperature and weather we have had recently the days have been borrowed from May.In , May will have borrowed Februaryrsquos days, so we can expect some unseasonal weather in that month as well, but in a dferent way.Sunday was a borrowed day for sure it was so mild and the later part sunny with a feeling of spring in the air. It was a perfect day for a discovery.We set off to find a place Irsquod only recently heard about. A friend had asked me what I knew about the lsquoKingrsquos Chairrsquo by Gullane. I had to admit that Irsquod never heard of it. He told me one of the holes at the golf course there has this name, but it seems it is named after a location nearby.This set me investigating. Sure enough, I found it marked on the map and searched for an image, which I found on a website called Ancient Stones: a large boulder, shaped like a throne, guarded by two other stones either side. It intrigued me and so our quest began.The starting point of our adventure was Gullane Beach car park. I knew roughly where to look but purposefully hadnrsquot brought the map so that we had a challenge to find the lsquochairrsquo. We knew what it looked like and that we needed to walk along the upper path, not the one that heads for the beach.We went the wrong way at first and got stuck in a mass of sea buckthorn, but on reflection that just added to the sense of adventure and achievement. We soon found our way and then suddenly there it was, up on Gullane Hill. The kids ran excitedly towards the stones, shouting: ldquoFound it, found it.I felt quite exhilarated at the discovery, and to be honest impressed by the sight of the Kingrsquos Chair. I can see how it got its name, as it looks something like a majestic reclining armchair. The two boulders on either side of it look like sentries keeping watch.The kids sat on it, of course, and I had to wait my turn after my we, who reckoned it could just as easily be a lsquoQueenrsquos Chairrsquo.When I finally got a chance to seat my majestic posterior on the chair, I realised the view was majestic as well, with Gullane Beach very visible in the near distance.I reflected on the fact we had recently visited Edinburgh Castle and seen the Stone of Destiny or Stone of Scone, along with the crown jewels. This rather uninspiring stone in Edinburgh Castle may be the coronation stone used for  years in England, but it is not, I am sure, the coronation stone used by ancient kings of Scotland, despite official claims that it is.I think itrsquos pretty clear that Edward I never got his hands on the real Stone of Destiny and I am convinced it has remained in Scotland, hidden somewhere, ever since. It occurred to me that this stone actually better fitted the early description of the original coronation stone at Scone than the one in Edinburgh Castle.ldquoImaginethis is the real Stone of Destiny and has been here all the time, I said fancully out loud. I know it isnrsquot, of course, but I have to saythis Kingrsquos Chair was on display at Edinburgh Castle it would certainly look more authentic.But sadly there seems to be no recorded tradition connected to this Kingrsquos Chair. I could find no story, or reference to the origin of its name. Perhaps some local people have some information on this There is an entry from the s that records the name, citing locals as the source, so there is some historic veracity in its title. But no suggestion is offered for the origin of the name, or any tradition associated with the stone. Its geology I could not say but it doesnrsquot seem to be a glacial erratic.And so we are left to wonder. We discussed how the stone got here and how it got its name. Maybe some children played here many generations ago and gave the boulder its title. Perhaps a Viking king who landed on Gullane Beach sat himself down on this natural throne to survey his warriors at their bloody work.Whatever the origin, the name, the location and the nature of the stone make this a worthwhile and fun discovery, even without a firm legend attached to it.And as I sat on the chair I watched smoke billowing from the coastline a little further to the west, close to the edge of Aberlady nature reserve. What caused the fire I didnrsquot know, but even from a distance it seemed destructive.It was a prophetic sight to witness from the Kingrsquos Chair. It looked like a burning coastline from a Viking raid. Thankfully the distant screech of fire engines told us help was on the way. The children wanted to go see the fire, but we kept our distance from the flames and let the firefighters do their job.So the trip to the Kingrsquos Chair had been an adventure in more ways than one. On our way back, the children advanced dferent theories about the origin of the name. It was universally agreed that a story must be made, but no agreement on the actual tale.ldquoPerhaps, I said, ldquowe should leave it to the imagination of those who search for and discover it, so they can sit and feel the power of the place and get ideas.My imagination was certainly ablaze. I saw the leader of the ancient Gododdin tribe, King Loth, sitting on the stone, looking out to the Firth as he watched his terried daughter in a small coracle being taken out to the open sea, his brutal punishment for her defiance of his authority.The story would fit as her journey began at Aberlady Bay, and so her small craft would have been seen from the Kingrsquos Chair as it passed by, being pulled out to sea by one of the kingrsquos boats.Itrsquos all a fancy of my imagination, of course, but thatrsquos my story. Go find the Kingrsquos Chair for yourself and see what your imagination comes up with!

title: double-cash-boost-for-our-community-kitchen-project-in-haddington
story: Our Community Kitchen has been awarded more than pound,, which it will use over the next year.The bulk of the money has come from Big Lottery Scotland, with pound, awarded to see the group expand to three days a week from next month.Already, the project meets on a Tuesday at Haddington Bowling Club.In the coming weeks, it will also meet on a Wednesday and Thursday, hosting dozens of people at each session and serving a hearty three-course meal for a donation of pound.Elaine Gale, spokeswoman for the project, felt Our Community Kitchen was well on the road to being a success.She said: ldquoIt is so exciting for the area and just to see where we go next. There is hard work in the next six months as we build these two new days up.ldquoWhat I really love, what comes across very clear to everybody, is that there are no barriers at all.ldquoIt is people coming together, having something to eat, and natural things happen when people come together to eat. That, for me, is really special.ldquoThere is nobody specic invited ndash no age limits or ability ndash it is just people.ldquoIt is amazing people coming together, having some food and everybody is laughing their head off and having a blast.A further pound, was awarded by the Walk With Scott Foundation.Scott Glynn, who founded the charity, visited Our Community Kitchen last month and was impressed with what was on offer.A post on their social media said: ldquoIt was such a joy to see a project in action, people from all walks of le getting together to have lunch and a blether.ldquoThe smiles as they walked in and the contentment of a full belly after they had been served by wonderful volunteers was a joy to see.ldquoNothing was a trouble, and everything was done with a smile and a kind word.ldquoIt was decided to help this project with funding and we are proud to have offered them pound,, with the provision of having a couple of themed days: a Burns lunch, a Wimbledon day, a bowling day and, of course, their Christmas dinner ideas were suggested.For more information on the group, which meets at .pm at the bowling club on Wemyss Place, email elainegale@gmail

title: east-lothian-the-backdrop-for-budding-directors-movie-at-glasgow-film-festival
story: Connect was written and directed by Marilyn Edmond and premiered at the Glasgow Film Festival on Saturday.The film, which stars Kevin Guthrie, of Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them and Dunkirk, also features a number of East Lothian residents.Marilyn, who is originally from Prestonpans, was looking forward to the moviersquos first screening.She said: ldquoIt is really cool, amazing actually.ldquoIrsquom really excited about it and really happy the world premiere is in Scotland.Marilyn, who now lives in Glasgow, has been involved in film and television for nearly  years.She has worked as an assistant director on programmes ranging from Waterloo Road and Lovesick to Sunshine on Leith.However, Connect is her first time as writer and director, with the film also getting a second showingduring the -day festival. Both screenings are sold out.Marilyn revealed it was a tragedy that had moved her to create her first feature- film.She said: ldquoWhen I was working on one of the previous jobs, there was a guy that was an extra and he ended up committing suicide.ldquoIt just totally threw me.ldquoHe had posted on Facebook about how his le was brilliant and he was so happy and four months later he committed suicide.ldquoI was just gobsmacked with it.ldquoHe was only  and that really sticks with me.ldquoI feel his le had only just really started and I was really saddened by the news.ldquoAccompanied by all the stories in the media, it is quite a big subject.Writing on Connect began in November , with filming getting under way in May last year.That was wrapped up by November, with the film now finished and ready to be seen by the public.Thirty-seven-year-old Marilyn, who lived in North Berwick at the time of the filming, said: ldquoConnect is about a young man who is struggling and he is feeling suicidal.ldquoHe gets saved by a stranger and then is encouraged to live his le and reconnect with his family and friends ndash all the while he is battling his dark secret.Steampunk Coffee and Turnbullrsquos Home Hardware, both North Berwick, are among county locations used in the film, with Gullane Day Centre and Dunbar also featuring.There are also a handful of familiar faces as well, with Lynne Turnbull and Kenny Ainslie, who has carried boxer Josh Taylorrsquos Commonwealth super lightweight title to the ring, among those starring in the film.

title: only-17-per-cent-of-vehicles-going-to-coastal-car-parks-buying-a-ticket
story: A review of East Lothian Councilrsquos coastal car park ticket system has revealed that only  per cent of those who go there pay for a ticket.It points out that a high number of those not paying can be attributed to season ticket holders but admits: ldquoThere remains substantial leakage within the system.The review, which will be presented to the local authorityrsquos policy and performance review committee this week, says that ldquofurther measures to control parking and gather the parking charge are being considered.It does not give details of what those measures are.The council first moved towards introducing the charges in  of its beach car parks in  and finally introduced the pound a day charge in .A pound season pass is also available.The review acknowledges that the income from the car parks is well below the original estimate, when the business case suggested it would bring in pound, in its first year and by   would be generating income of more than pound,.The report to councillors revealed that since its introduction in July  to January this year the total income after VAT was pound,.Of that it was estimated pound, came from season ticket sales.However, the review also revealed that when the charges were first introduced, surplus cash generated was earmarked for coastal improvements.This changed when the council applied to bring in its own parking wardens and decriminalise parking offences in the county in .The review revealed that pound, of annual income from coastal car park charges was included in the business case for the new wardens.And it warned that this sum was now ldquocategorically necessary to ensure the future of the parking wardens which were introduced as a result, suggesting the charges could not be scrapped now, evencouncillors wanted to do that.It said: ldquo[The pound, was not originally anticipated within the original coastal car parking business case but does clearly make a positive contribution impact upon wider parking enforcement.

title: cousins-team-up-to-help-paddle-boarder-near-dunbar
story: Emergency services were called out on Saturday afternoon following reports of a paddle boarder in dficulty near Thorntonloch.Both Dunbarrsquos RNLI and Coastguard teams were involved, alongside North Coastguard Rescue Team and Civil Nuclear Constabulary.The callout marked the first time that Alan Blair, an RNLI volunteer for nearly  years, had been on a call-out alongside his cousin, -year-old Lewis Blair, who joined the Coastguard in January.UK Coastguard paged for the inshoreand all-weatherleboats at .pm after a member of the public raised the alarm.The crews launched minutes later and both boats were on scene by about .pm to begin a search.The person was spotted on rocks near Thorntonloch Beach before it was established the casualty had managed to make their own way to the shore.The paddle boarder, who had got into dficulties after being blown away from shore, did not require medical treatment.An RNLI spokesman said: ldquoStand-up paddle boarding is fun in flat water or surf and can be enjoyed by the whole family but this incident highlighted the potential risks.

title: children-settling-into-life-at-new-wallyford-primary-school
story: They celebrated their first day in the building last Wednesday.Mhairi Stratton, headteacher, said: "Irsquove been really impressed at how quickly the children have settled into their new school."Theyrsquore enjoying the outdoor space and the freedom it gives them."The more open classroom layouts area also great and very flexible for learning and play."They absolutely love the dining hall ndash itrsquos a really nice space.
