title: parking-time-limit-restrictions-at-musselburghs-old-town-hall-tightened-up
story: A new Traffic Regulation Orderwas introduced on Monday. Although the location had been subject to a -minute limit in the past, the council created additional spaces to which the time restriction needed to be enforced.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoThe previous TRO made reference to the size and shape of the old road layout and therefore couldnrsquot be enforced following the construction of the new road layout.She said that a -minute waiting restriction would remain from St Peterrsquos Church, past Loretto School.The spokeswoman added that parking issues with motorists leaving their vehicles all day were compounded following the removal of Police Scotlandrsquos traffic warden service in  as there was little chance that vehicles would be ticketed.The council was then granted powers on January , , to carry out parking enforcement and undertook a series of reviews on town centre parking.A new parking layout, including additional spaces and new parking for bicycles has since been introduced by the Town Hall.The spokeswoman said: ldquoThe restrictions were  minutes before but had been ignored as no enforcement could be carried out.ldquoThe council then got enforcement powers and a Traffic Regulation Order has brought in -minute limited waiting within the new road layout near Musselburgh Town Hall and on the section of High Street opposite.ldquoThe disabled parking spaces will also be enforced, ensuring blue badge holders can park close to a busy town centre.ldquoThe -minute restrictions will create a turnover of vehicles and stop all-day parking, which should assist the needs of businesses, visitors and residents during peak times. These timed restrictions will operate between the times of .am to .pm, Monday to Saturday.ldquoThe issue of increased car ownership is a major contribution to the parking problems found in Musselburgh and in other towns throughout East Lothian and, whilst this is a dficult problem to address, the council is committed to tackling such issues by improving the quality of transport infrastructure across East Lothian, promotion of sustainable transport options and identying opportunities to create more car parking spaces such as the new parking provision in Musselburgh High Street.ldquoIn addition the councilrsquos parking strategy includes extending and introducing residents parking schemes throughout East Lothian.

title: politicians-disappointed-with-apology-letter-from-scotrail
story: Martin Whitfield MP and Iain Gray MSP had written a letter to ScotRail in January outlining the problems that East Lothian constituents were facing after complaints of late trains and too few carriages.ScotRail responded by saying: ldquoWe know that train performance hasnrsquot been good enough in recent months and I am sorry for how that has impacted our customers.ldquoWhen the railway doesnrsquot work as it should, it causes immense inconvenience and disruption for those who rely on us to get to work, or to see family and friends.ldquoThe level of cancellation has reduced steadily over the past month and we will continue to cut cancellations to improve the service.ldquoAs more staff are trained, our performance is improving, and our most recent performance results continue to show an improvement.Both Parliamentarians have branded this letter ldquodisappointing, with Mr Gray saying: ldquoEast Lothian rail users are rightly fed up with ScotRailrsquos litany of excuses and hollow apologies for their ongoing service failures.ldquoActions always speak louder than words. I will not let up in highlighting the problems experienced by constituents and demanding change until we see sustained improvements in the way ScotRail delivers local services.Mr Whitfield added: ldquoOnce again, ScotRailrsquos reply to our service challenge says all the right things about delivering more staff and investing in new and upgraded trains to improve performance.ldquoThe problem is that we have heard it all before, but things never seem to get better.

title: fresh-bid-for-houses-new-clubhouse-and-course-at-dunbar-golf-club
story: Between  and  new houses could be built on two sites next to the -hole golf course, as well as a new clubhouse, a new nine-hole course and practice facilities.The proposals come  years after the club applied to East Lothian Council to develop a new clubhouse, nine-hole golf course, golf academy and driving range, short practice facilities, greenkeepersrsquo shed, housing and hotel to complement the existing course.In October , the scheme was given the green light.Now, a fresh application has been made by Dunbar Golf Club and CALA Management Ltd.The majority of the homes would be built around the existing Deer Park Cemetery, to the south-east of much of the existing golf course.A smaller number of houses is earmarked for land at the current clubhouse, off Golf House Road.Plans suggest that the nine-hole course would be created opposite the housing development being built off Bowmont Terrace.New documents lodged with the councilrsquos planning department, referencing the previously approved plans, state: ldquoThis permission also included a Section  legal agreement which seeks to control the timing of the delivery of new homes alongside the delivery of the new clubhouse and associated facilities, commits the golf club to contributions towards education provision, as well as a commitment to a collaborative approach in promoting the site for a future hotel development [and as per the masterplan].ldquoAs Dunbar Golf Club undertook further work, including marketing the site under the terms of the planning permission, it became clear that the layout proposed in the masterplan accompanying the planning permission in outline did not reflect the best option for future development, mostly with regards to the proposed mix of housing and the balance of the quantum of development between the clubhouse site and Deer Park. Clear feedback highlighted that more units should be proposed at Deer Park, with a limited development of larger homes on the existing clubhouse site.ldquoIn detailed discussions with East Lothian Council, it was agreed that fresh planning permission would be required. Given the size of the site and scale of development, it is considered a major development and therefore triggered the requirement for this formal pre-application consultation process.A public exhibition is to take place on April  at the Dunmuir Hotel, -pm, to reveal the new plans to the public for the first time.The number of houses planned are estimated to be between  and , compared to  in the previous application. The golf club will also maintain a site for potential future hotel development. Councillors Norman Hampshire, Paul McLennan and Sue Kempson, who represent the town, will also be made aware of the plans, as will the townrsquos community council.Dunbar Golf Clubrsquos East Links has played host to many national and several international championships, as well as being a final qualying course for the Open when it is played at Muirfield. The club was founded in .

title: mps-to-enjoy-above-inflation-27-pay-rise-bringing-basic-pay-to-almost-80000
story: The pound, hike, effective from April ,is well above the current inflation rate of .% on the main CPI measure.It follows a .% boost to MPsrsquo pay last year, .% in , .% in  and a big increase from pound, to pound, in July .MPsrsquo pay is linked to average rises in the public sector, as determined by the Office for National Statistics.The .% figure was announced by the ONS on an interim basis in December and confirmed last week to the Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority , which made the final announcement.Following reforms to the way MPsrsquo pay is calculated, the rise is automatic and not subject to a vote in the House of Commons.Chairs of Commons committees will enjoy a .% increase to the additional salary they receive on top of their basic pay, taking it from pound, to pound,.Ministersrsquo salaries are determined separately.TaxPayersrsquo Alliance grassroots campaign manager Harry Fone said: ldquoA lot of taxpayers are going to be annoyed by this announcement.ldquoIn the private sector, pay rises and bonuses are rewarded based on performance, not for just turning up. Ipsa are once again out of touch with the public.Mark Serwotka, general secretary of the Public and Commercial Services union, said: ldquoIt is an outrage that MPs are rewarding themselves with an above- inflation pay rise while civil servants, who do some of the most vital jobs in society, are still subject to a cruel % de-facto pay cap.ldquoPCS are balloting , members for strike action over pay this summer and todayrsquos news will only anger them further.Garry Graham, Prospectrsquos deputy general secretary, said: ldquoOur members will see more than a whf of hypocrisy and double standards in todayrsquos announcement.ldquoProspect has long argued for an independent review of pay to cover our members working in the Civil Service and wider public sector. This has been repeatedly turned down.ldquoThere has not been a government in peacetime so reliant on the hard work and dedication of the Civil Service and its agencies.ldquoFor MPs to be awarded .% when pay rises for those who serve them are held down at .% or less demonstrates a remarkable level of contempt.ldquoAs we prepare for pay discussions with the Cabinet Office and Treasury, this announcement will only add to the anger and frustration held by members.

title: Iain Macwhirter  Get over it - cis women are just on the wrong side of history
story: This, apparently, is to educate heteronormative women about their ldquoprivilege ndash the fact that they can use the toilets, sorry ldquowashrooms, of their choice and access healthcare. Irsquom not sure who exactly has been preventing transgender women using public conveniences. So far as I know, you donrsquot have to show a birth certicate, or undergo a medical exam to have a pee. But what do I know as a pale, stale male.What I do know is that ldquocis-gender is an ugly neologism which many women find offensive. They are content with their present sexual terminology. ldquoCis is in the same linguistic ballpark as ldquoTERF ndash trans exclusionary radical feminist, which is a term of abuse used against women who believe persons with penises are, er, male. I should be careful here because a number of TERFS have been banned from social media for saying that a person with a penis is a man. So I wonrsquot say that.Instead, letrsquos just take it as read that in future we are going to have to accept that the concept of sexual dferentiation with which we have been living for thousands of years is finally being exposed as a malign transphobic hood. At any rate, the Scottish Government appears determined to press ahead with reform of the Gender Recognition Act, which will allow trans people to assign themselves legally and biologically female. Hitherto, trans people have had to undergo medical examination and get a diagnosis of ldquogender dysphoria. No more. From now on, anyone can change their birth certicate to whatever they wish.Earlier this month, Holyroodrsquos culture committee warned that ending binary ldquoMale or Female questions in the Scottish census will render much of the results meaningless and, willy nilly, import an unscientic definition of sex into the law. But the Scottish Government is not listening. Nicola Sturgeon told a UN equalities conference last week that the concerns of feminists about the GRA are ldquomisplaced.Women ndash sorry, ldquomenstruators ndash who say that self-ID erases their sexual identity will be told: just get over it. They can complain that ldquosex is a protected characteristic under the  Equalities Act, and that women therefore have a right to their own unique spaces. But now that men can actually become women under the law, this right will be impossible to articulate. Trans women with male anatomy will be entitled to enter womenrsquos changing rooms, girl guide troops or womenrsquos prisons. Women who complain will be guilty of transphobia, and are likely to be visited by the police recording a ldquohate incident.Now, I have nothing against adults changing their gender, or identying as women, queer, non-binary, intersex or whatever. It seems to be reinforcing outmoded concepts of gender to suggest that, because someone wants to wear dresses, play with dolls and put on makeup, they must have a lady brain in a male body. I thought we had left pink-for-girls gender stereotyping behind. But never mind. No-one wishes trans people any ill ndash certainly not me. But now that we are abandoning the very biological definition of sex, there are some anomalies that need to be addressed.Last week, a British transgender man, who had IVF by sperm donation and gave birth, won a court battle to prevent his child having ldquomother on its birth certicate. It will be the first child in history to have no mother. The The AIRE Centre, a human rights charity, contested this on the grounds that it would make le dficult for the child in future, when they apply for visas or anything which enquires about family background. The Government said simply that this isnrsquot a problem. From now on, fathers can give birth ndash end of.But Irsquom not sure this is the end of the matter. Children have not been included in the gender recognition debate thus far, even though they have rights too. It could be psychologically disturbing for a child to find, one day, that its mother has decided to become its dad. That song ldquoSometimes I feel like a motherless child takes on a whole new meaning.Of course, the trans parent will still be present, but is it OK to expect a child to suddenly start calling her natural mother her father  I would have thought that a child has a continuing right to a legal motherthey were born with one. If misgendering a trans person is unacceptable, surely demothering a child should be too. This is going to be confusing to say the least.Then there is the question of sport. The controversy over athlete Caster Semenya, a woman with high testosterone, raises the question of how to regard trans womenrsquos participation in women-only sport. Athletes who have testes, and therefore posses greater body mass, muscle strength and bone density, have an unfair advantage over old-fashioned women who have genetically female bodies.Next week, the International Association of Athletics Federations will argue in a hearing in Switzerland that people like Semenya should take testosterone-suppressing drugs before competing. Not only would this drive a coach and horses through the anti-doping protocols, it surely poses problem for transgender athletes who, of course, also take drugs like testosterone to help them transition to their ldquocorrect male sex. I hope the sporting authorities can get their heads around that because I canrsquot.Yet this is a very live issue in many sports. In the US, the ban on trans women taking part in power-lting events is being lted to prevent accusations of discrimination. You might have thought that having beefy, male-bodied women participating in these contests is discriminating against women athletes. Though, of course, only transphobes would say that, so we wonrsquot go there.The logical solution to this conundrum is to end sexual segregation in sport. Andwomen who are born biologically female never win any medals, tough. Strangely, there doesnrsquot seem to be the same issue about female-bodied trans men participating in male-only sport . Irsquom sure that has nothing whatever to do with the fact that they wonrsquot win anything.So welcome to the brave new world of post-sexual dferentiation, where men become women and fathers have children. It is one of the most radical and abrupt cultural changes in human history.Women have had a pretty bad deal in previous centuries, when they were regarded often as chattels without rights. In some Muslim societies theyrsquore still second-class citizens. Now, as women are finally emerging from the shadow of patriarchy, they are being told, by men, that they no longer have exclusive rights to their sexual identity.Itrsquos a weird turn of events. It seems women are just on the wrong side of history. But somehow, I donrsquot think theyrsquoll go quietly.

title: Marianne Taylor  Last chance for Mundell to put country before party
story: The majority of these demands are perfunctory, of course, made in the knowledge and expectation that they will be ignored by the target, while playing well with the initiatorrsquos supporters.The craziness of the last few months has precipitated a flurry of genuine and warranted resignation demands, however, which under normal political circumstances would have resulted in multiple ministerial heads rolling in any other era the Prime Minister would have been forced out long ago.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysAnother case in point is Scottish Secretary David Mundell, whose stubborn insistence on being ineffectual in the face of the biggest crisis this country has faced in generations is matched only by that of Jeremy Corbyn. Mr Mundellrsquos wan smiles and empty words about doing the best for Scotland as the Government he is a member of readies itself to push us off the no-deal Brexit clf, is as astonishing as it is appalling. He, too, should have gone months ago, not least over the manner in which his party has arrogantly steamrollered over the views and interests of the country he supposedly represents.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitRemarkably still in post, Mr Mundell now has one last chance to make a meaningful contribution to the ridiculous and dangerous situation the Westminster parliament has created for itself. The SNP is right to call for Mr Mundell to show some mettle and make clear that he will not serve in a Government that is willing to take us out of the European Union without a deal, a situation that would put the already fragile Scottish economy on the road to ruin. As the Scottish Secretary is well aware, businesses will fail, jobs will be lost and real people will suffer the sort of real hardships that will be dficult to recover from.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysSNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford has written to Mr Mundell, laying out the gravity of the situation and calling on him to back growing cross-party demands to halt the Brexit process by extending Article  and making clear to his boss, Theresa May, that he will resign unless she faces up the extremists in her party and takes no-deal off the table.At this critical juncture, the least that the people of Scotland deserve from the man who represents them at Cabinet level is honesty about where his loyalties lie: will he put country or party first  Mr Mundell, it really is that simple.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitOf course, Mr Blackfordrsquos letter also highlights the bleakness of the dilemma facing the SNP. If Mrs May gets her way and Parliament is faced with a last-minute binary choice between her terrible deal - which deprives us of the key benefits being in the EU - and an even more catastrophic no-deal, it leaves the party in a dficult position. How should Nicola Sturgeon instruct her MPs to vote in this scenario  Backing Mrs Mayrsquos ldquomy way or the highway deal would be criticised by many as a U-turn of epic proportions and a sign of weakness. Not voting for it, and thus facilitating a no-deal Brexit, would likely be viewed by many voters as unforgivable, leaving the party open to allegations that this is the outcome it has been secretly hoping for all along, in order to boost support for independence.Ms Sturgeon and her colleagues will be hoping the growing number of Tory ministers and backbench MPs ndash including Cabinet secretaries Amber Rudd, Greg Clarke and David Gauke - poised to revolt against their leader should she refuse to rule out a no-deal Brexit, will come to their rescue in the frantic days and weeks to come.Marianne Taylor: BBC is better off without Neil and HumphrysThe emergence of the The Independent Groupmay also end up helping the SNPrsquos predicament, at least in the short term. Formed last week when eight MPs resigned from Labour unhappy at Mr Corbynrsquos disastrous leadership, it did not initially appear to be an important development. But when three Tory MPs also resigned and joined up, using the moment to launch a blistering attack on Mrs Mayrsquos disastrous Brexit strategy and their partyrsquos lurch to the right, it started to feel more signicant.What binds these MPs from dferent sides of the House of Commons is dismay at the drt of both parties to the extremities. And despite not being a proper party - yet - or having any actual policiesit seems many voters quite like what they see.Read more: Mundell should resign there is no-deal BrexitMomentum has grown over the weekend, with polls already putting the group on  per cent, just one behind the increasingly irrelevant Lib Dems.Many are asking whether TIG has a future. Surely, however, whatrsquos most important is the future of the country, andthis new movement serves only to facilitate the halting of Article , so that a new road out of the current mess can be found, then it will already have done more for the UK than Mr Corbyn. Or indeed Mr Mundell for that matter.

title: energy-giant-plans-hefty-investment-in-windfarms-and-car-chargers-in-scotland

The increase will mean its standard plan for duel fuel customers will cost on average pound,.Other members of the big sixhave increased prices for customers on SVTs recently sinceOfgem decided to raise the typical limit for UK default and standard iable gas and electricity tarfs by pound to pound, a year from April .ScottishPowerrsquos parent group, Iberdrola, said yesterday it would invest eurobnby  to speed growth. It reckons the plan will provide a major boost to the irreversible transition to a low carbon-energy model.

title: herald-diary-key-to-a-successful-marriage-is-letting-things-go-ive-started-with-myself
story: THAT great American singer songwriter Joan Baez was sounding as fresh as ever when she appeared at Glasgows Concert Hall this week at the age of . As reader Barry Wilson from Paisley who was there tells us: "There was a standing ovation ndash from those of us who could stand, as we are all getting older. At the start of her second encore, a voice shouted out, You can stay all night! Joan quickly replied, Its a while since I heard that proposition."Plain speakingWE asked for your strict parents stories and Robert Gardner recalled: "I went to the Scout Jamboree in Greece when I was , camping on the Marathon Plains. I sent a long detailed postcard home telling my parents what was happening. When I arrived back I found my Mother had marked the postcard out of  with a very low score and left it on the mantelpiece. From that day on any cards sent home only had one word. Fine in the centre of the writing space."Flight of fancyWHAT is it about older folk that they want to get to the airport earlier and earlier  A Glasgow reader heard an exasperated middle-aged son explain: "My parents want to go to the airport so early for their holiday flight that I couldnt stop myself from asking themthey had ever got the Wright Brothers as their pilots."Bow to the inevitableWE read in The Herald that an Ayrshire lawyer is to challenge the now widespread practice of schools charging fees to teach the children musical instruments. We cannot forget for instance the Lenzie mother who confessed to us that she told her daughter that the garage had the best acoustics for her trombone practice. Anyway, we always liked the story of composer John Lunn, Emmy winner for his Downton Abbey theme tune, who said he wanted to play the cello at his Stirlingshire school but they were all taken and he was given a double bass instead. Said John: "So few people played the instrument, and very quickly I was dragooned into playing for every orchestra in the county even though I could barely play it, so I was forced to learn very quickly." And thus a career was born.Shabby adviceTRICKY things marriages. A reader phones to tell us: "The key to a successful marriage is letting things go. Ive started with myself."THOSE WERE THE DAYS - : Timely advice for student nursesOut of stepOUR tales of the chaos that children cause remind Willie Mclean in Dumbarton: "Years ago I attended the Boys Brigade Display at Cathcart Old Parish Church with my we and daughter to watch our two sons. The boys were lined up and the Captain gave the order, Company will advance in review order, by the centre, quick... Before he could say the next word, my four-year-old daughter shouted out, March! There was utter chaos. Half of the boys started off. The audience erupted, but our daughter just sat there swinging her legs asnothing had happened."May timeSO who can help explain Brexit to us today  Up steps football commentator Michael Stewart who says: "If Brexit is pushed back and it is the end of May, that would be rather ironic."SweetTODAYS piece of daftness comes from Kent Graham who declares: "Young people today have it so easy. When I was a kid, cereal didnrsquot come loaded with sugar ndash we had to shovel it on ourselves."

Recent expansion has included a pound million PE facility on the schoolrsquos playing fields at Pollok Park.Read more: Glasgow headteacher quits private schoolIn recent years pupil rolls have fallen. In   there were nearly  pupils at the school, but this fell to  in   and  in   and  this year.Earlier this month, financial experts warned the independent sector in Edinburgh was facing a stark future with the financial security of many schools under threat.The report blamed the impact of the partial removal of business rates relief, rising teachersrsquo pay and spiralling pensions contributions.The report, by Edinburgh-based independent economic consultancy BiGGAR Economics, said the financial implications are severe with a poundm increase in costs for all schools, which it calculates would result in a hike in fees of seven per cent - or pound per pupil on average.Beaconhurst private school in Bridge of Allan closed last year after running into financial dficulties.

title: tv-review-debate-night-making-sense-of-the-news-or-just-a-snooze
story: Particularly so after it emerged the man at the centre of the row, failed UKIP candidate Billy Mitchell, had not just appeared on Question Time four times, in breach of the showrsquos rules, but he had also taken part in a pilot for Debate Night.Five hurdles for new BBC channelWith Mr Mitchell seemingly able to do a Paul McKenna on researchers, it was not impossible that he would turn up again last night when the show made its official debut.Debate Night producers were on the case, however. As a look at the audience application form showed, the love grandchild of Senator Joseph McCarthy and a top Stasi agent is now in charge of selection. There are more questions, requiring a greater level of detail, than the regular QT form, with applicants asked how they would vote in an indyref, how they voted in the Scottish Parliament elections , and whether they are members of a political party. If it is yes to the latter, they need to specy which party, and whether they have ever held an elected position or worked for a party. Phew. They might as well ask for an armful of blood while they are at it.Last nightrsquos programme came from Edinburgh. In place of Fiona Bruce there was Stephen Jardine, son of Dumfries, ex-GMTV and Scottish Television. As a frequent stand-in host on BBC Radio Scotland morning shout-fest, Call Kaye, you could see why he had been given the gig.Magic or mince  You decideDebate Night made the news before last night when it emerged the budget for the show was so small it could not afford to move around the country, like QT. Whatever they have spent the money on, it is not the set. With its purple chairs and faux art it looked like the business class lounge of a cheapo airline. The audience were in cinema-style banked seating which made the audience look tiny. Worse, some of the seats were empty.But never mind the standard of the seating, what about the quality of the debate  The audience, Jardine informed us, came from all across Scotland, ldquofrom Ayrshire to Paisley, Perth and Edinburgh. In other words, from a bus ride away.On the  were three politicians, Deputy FM John Swinney, Labourrsquos Monica Lennon, and Murdo Fraser for the Scottish Conservatives, and two civilians, the poet Jenny Lindsay and the entrepreneur Sir Tom Hunter. Two women to three men, or two to fouryou count Jardine: some things never change. No Greens or LibDems will it be their turn next week Marks out of  for The Nine The job of the new show, Jardine said in his introduction, was not just to get answers from politicians but to raise the standard of debate, no less. Within a minute, however, Murdo Fraser was talking over Monica Lennon and she was raising her own voice in response. So much for new standards of discourse. It was not long, either, before the politicians on the  began answering the questions that suited them rather than the ones they had been asked. Jardine pulled a Paxman now and then, possibly to shake himself awake. ldquoWhat does any of this mean, what are you going to do about it  he asked Lennon at one point.Half an hour was spent on Brexit, far too long. The next questions, on sectarianism and a possible teachersrsquo pay strike, were not matters that would have been raised on a QT from London, so in that respect Debate Night showed its worth, evennothing new emerged in the discussion.I would like to say the hour was packed with penetrating questions and illuminating answers, a show that showed QT how such programmes should be done. There were one or two moments worth catching, most of them coming from plain-speaking Sir Tom Hunter, but by and large this was a punishing watch, not least because of the late slot. An .pm finish, on a school night  Why bother committing to a serious programmeit doesnrsquot have a credible chance of building an audience By the time Jardine said goodnight it was time for this Cinderella to head to bed. Cinders at least had her slipper ed those  minutes spent watching Debate Night are never coming back.

title: brian-beacom-does-brendan-rodgers-celtic-exit-prove-loyalty-is-an-outdated-concept
story: And already the Parkhead faithful are throwing adjectives such as ldquobetrayal around like pennies at a Sixties scramble.:Rodgers legacy in danger of being reframed as the Brendan Fraudgers era by the Celtic supportBut what of loyalty  Should we hold it up to be a virtue, or an anachronism thatrsquos headed right for the lexicon bin marked Outdated The past two decades has seen the concept tested to the limit. New Labour introduced the notion of a wandering minstrel society, where workers were free to ply their trade wherever. If poets and pop stars could do it, why not the rest of us  The problem was as economies constricted so too did employment contracts of any real value.Try telling a delivery bike rider out there right now they should show company loyalty and theyrsquoll force a  inch Hawaiianndash with fries ndash right down your throat. Yes, there was a time when trades unions had the power to look after their charges. But that day has passed, public sector apart.Is loyalty about reciprocity  Yes, it should be part of a two-way process. Sadly, however, the public has for decades shown blind faith to banks and energy companies who have refused to pass savings onto those who built up their business. So itrsquos only right we have become promiscuous, learned to compare the market because the truth is wersquove been so royally shafted in the past.The concept of loyalty has long been fostered by elites, by way of control, at times, to protect institutions that are morally corrupt. Itrsquos been bred into us, from days in the Brownies or Boys Brigade, to respect and support a higher order. Thatrsquos not to say order is a bad thing but that order has to co-exist alongside morality of purpose. Herersquos a good rule of thumb:loyalty demands the swearing of an oath or any weird ritualistic practice, then walk away.:Brendan Rodgers leaves Celtic for Leicester CityItrsquos not hard to see why Scots MP Ian Murray MP wonrsquot sign a loyalty statement to his boss. Politics now is defined by continuous acts of disloyalty. Agreements, to party and electorate are reconfigured almost on a daily basis. Andloyalty is being redefined in terms of allegiance to solid principle, thatrsquos not a bad thing. However, the opposite is also true we can only wonder and worry whatrsquos going on in Jeremy Corbynrsquos mind that allows him to block plans to ban Hezbollah from Britain. Whatrsquos going on in Theresa Mayrsquos head that allows for disloyalty to the truth, which is that we wonrsquot walk away with a deal on March  We can only wonder what is going on the head of Pope Francis, given his close confidante and Vatican No was allowed to practice evil for many years. What of the notion of loyalty between friends  Irsquove long thought this to be an essential, an unconditional. Unless friends bring with them new conditions under which you struggle to operate but we should see loyalty as the perpetual ideal.Yet, the Pope and politics apart, were moving towards a society whereby the core value of loyalty has less importance. Wersquore living in a world where Cha goalkeepers can refuse to be substituted, which begs the question: where do we draw the line in refusing to take orders  Should a soldier be jailed for refusing to listen to an officer, no matter how unhinged they appear to be. But are you betraying yourselfyou donrsquot do what you think to be best at the time, for career and perhaps your familyrsquos future  Yes, you will argue this suggests principles. But what are they  Groucho Marx once declared ldquoThose are my principles, andyou donrsquot like them... well, I have others. He was joking, of course, but his words sit perfectly with the modern climate.Which means itrsquos hard to argue the moral principle as regarding Brendan Rodgers. He operates in a free market economy which employs transients. Itrsquos not fair to say this is the worst act of disloyalty since Judas took up cheek kissing.Yet, itrsquos not wrong to see why Hoopsrsquo fansrsquo green blood is boiling. A football club isnrsquot called a club for no reason.The th-century philosopher Josiah Royce spoke of the relation between the conscious inidual and the universal thought ndash ldquowhich will be decided in the sense of their own inclusion, as elements in the universal thought. It says you are part of somethingyou believe it to be so.The Celtic fans bought into the universal thought with their hard-earned season ticket cash.Absolute inclusion should at least buy you the final ten league games of the season.

title: brexit-labour-to-back-second-referendum-when-theresa-may-brings-her-deal-back-to-commons
story: Shadow chancellor John McDonnell said Labour would take the first opportunity to test whether MPs will back a public vote.But he stressed that Jeremy Corbyns party would also continue to press for its own Brexit vision and was still calling for a general election.Labours Brexit blueprint was defeated by  votes to  in the Commons on Wednesday night and Mr Corbyn confirmed Labour would now back a referendumfaced with a "damaging Tory Brexit" or a no-deal departure from the European Union.:Jeremy Corbyn urged by MPs to swing party wholeheartedly behind Peoples Vote after its plan rejectedBut he insisted that Labour would also continue to support "other available options" to prevent either the Prime Ministers deal or the UK crashing out without an agreement.On ITVs Peston, the shadow chancellor set out Labours approach, saying the move would be made when Mrs May next risks a meaningful vote on her Brexit deal."Thats the time when we will have to put the amendment up," he said.But he added: "We are still going to argue that we want a general election, we are still going to argue we think our deal that we have put up was the best option."He suggested "either a deal will go through which will protect jobs and the economy or, to get some deal through, it will be conditional on going back to the people".Labour MPs Peter Kyle and Phil Wilson have put forward a compromise plan to back Mrs Mays deal with the condition that it is then put to a confirmatory public vote.Mr Corbyn has come under pressure from the Labour ranks to throw the partys full weight behind a second referendum.After the result in the Commons, shadow Brexit spokesman Matthew Pennycook said it was "now time to wholeheartedly get behind efforts to facilitate a new public vote that includes the option of staying in the EU".:Theresa May insists SNP Government is betraying Scotland with higher taxesOwen Smith, who was sacked from the shadow cabinet for calling for a second referendum, told the Press Association: "Now that Labours version of Brexit has been rejected by Parliament, I expect Jeremy Corbyn to throw his full weight behind campaigning for a public vote."But former minister Caroline Flint warned that a second referendum would be opposed by a number of Labour MPs, as well as members and voters who "want the Labour Party to stand by its promise, and the promise was to respect the referendum".The Prime Minsters dramatic announcement on Tuesday that she would allow MPs to vote on delaying the UKs EU withdrawal beyond March  took the sting out of Wednesdays Brexit votes which had been expected to trigger a number of ministerial resignations.An amendment tabled by Labours Yvette Cooper, designed to pin the PM down by placing her promise in a motion approved by Parliament, was passed by a majority of  - with  Tory hardliners opposing it and scores of Conservatives abstaining.Just  of the partys  MPs who were eligible to vote backed the measure.Any more signicant Conservative bust-ups have now been delayed for up to two weeks, as Mrs May prepares to bring her Withdrawal Agreement back to the Commons for a "meaningful vote" by March , although there have been hints the showdown could be as soon as next week.Meanwhile, Health Secretary Matt Hancock again insisted that medicine supplies would be unhinderedthere was a no-deal Brexit, following warnings from the Royal College of Radiologists that some cancer treatments may have to be delayed.He told BBCs Newsnight: "My message, very clearly to those who have cancer, is that we have arrangements in place to ensure that whatever the Brexit scenarios and circumstances, we can get the medicines in that are needed."Thats something that we have to plan for, whether we want no-deal to happen or not, because it is something that could happen."

title: msp-calls-for-scottish-law-commission-review-of-undue-leniency
story: The comments were made by Liam Kerr during a Scottish Labour debate on sentencing guidelines at Holyrood on Wednesday.It followed the sentencing of Christopher Daniel, , who wasfound guilty of repeated sexual assaults on a six-year-old girl but was granted an absolute discharge by Sherf Gerard Sinclair for ious reasons includinghis perceived emotional naivety.The decision means that Daniel, who was between  and  at the time, will not be on the Sex Offendersrsquo Register or have any criminal record.Prosecutors decided that the sentence could not be appealed by the Crown Office on the grounds of undue leniency because the case does not meet the high legal test required.Mr Kerr has called for the Scottish Law Commission to review the test of lsquoundue leniencyrsquo, suggesting that the Crown is restricted in its ability to appeal sentences.ldquoWe all agree that politicians should not interfere with the independence of the Judiciary, said the MSP.ldquoBut politicians do set out the parameters for sentencing. Indeed, the SNP will shortly seek to implement a presumption against sentences of less than  months and thus it does accept that politicians have a role in how sentencing, and therefore appeals, operate.ldquoThere is a role for politicians in ensuring our justice system meets the needs of victims and society, and it is crucial that victims understand and have faith in our system.ldquoWe would be failing, surely, in our dutywhen a perpetrator has walked free, having been found guilty of sexually assaulting a six-year-old girl, we do not empower the Scottish Law Commission to review whether the undue leniency test is overly restrictive.Labour justice spokesman Daniel Johnson said that the ldquojustice system still has a distance to travel in both consistency and transparency.The party has called forsentencing guidelines for sexual assault to be changed, particularly for young people.Mr Johnson said: ldquoHow can it be fair or just to sentence someone on the basis of the le chances they have had to date.ldquoIt can not be right that two iniduals receive dferent sentences for the same crime because of whether or not they were lucky in the lottery of le.ldquoThe reality is we have been discussing the need for sentencing guidelines for more than  years.ldquoIn the three-and-a-half years since it was created, the Scottish Sentencing Council has only produced one guideline.ldquoOf course guidance on sentencing must not be rushed and must be subject to careful consideration and reflection, but I think it is right we ask questions as to whether this progress has been adequate.Justice Secretary Humza Yousafstressed that the Scottish Sentencing Councilhad a wider roll than just producing guidelines, adding it was also responsible for matters such as promoting greater awareness and understanding of sentencing policy.He said: ldquoOne of the reasons why guidelines can take a bit of time to come to fruition is because public consultation is a key part of that.ldquoAt the first meeting of the Sentencing Council it was determined that every single guideline they produce will then go to public consultation, so there is a consultation for guidelines as there would be for legislation.The Justice Secretary alsospoke about the need for guidelines to be ldquoright and not rushed.

title: independent-scotlands-entry-into-the-eu-would-be-easy-says-mep-elmar-brok
story: Known as the Father of the House, Elmar Broke has been an MEP since  and is credited with writing the constitution of the EU by many.:Herald poll: Scotland should have independence referendum after BrexitSpeaking to former first ministerAlex Salmondon his RT programme, the MEP, who went to Edinburgh University,saidthatBrexitwill lead to Scotland thinking again about independence.He said: ldquoThis is one of the nations closest to my heart ... this country is so wonderful, this is so pro-European ... and therefore I wish Scotland all the luck for the future and I know that the membership in the European Union is of the utmost importance for the future economic and social development of Scotland.Asked about the EUrsquos attitude to a future Scottish application for membership, Brok said: ldquoIf that is done in a referendum under the rules of the United Kingdom, andyou decide so then it would be then easy to have membership negotiations because Scotland fulfils all the needs for membership, because all the standards are already there, and therefore I am not pushing for iding the United Kingdom, hopefully the United Kingdom could together be a member together of the European Union butthe United Kingdom goes out of the European Union I can imagine that the Scottish people will think a second time.Brok told Salmondrsquos latest show that he still ldquodreams that Britain will stay in but sees this as unrealistic and the worst fear is a ldquohard Brexit by default.He expressed his ldquogreat regret about Brexit saying that he ldquonever believed that the United Kingdom would have no interest in its own interests.:Theresa May insists SNP Government is betraying Scotland with higher taxesHe also used the  to describe Brexit negotiationsas ldquostupid and warned that a hard Brexit is now a very real danger.ldquoI think there is a very good chance of the hard Brexit," he said.ldquoFor sure itrsquos a lose-lose situation for both of us and for economic reasons, as trading power but also for security policy we would like to have Britain in, but Britain is in this marketplace  times smaller than the market of the European Union so you know who will be the stronger part.A member of the German Christian Democratic Unionparty, Brok sits in the European Parliamentrsquos European Peoplersquos Party bloc. He has had a number of positions in the CDU and its fellow groups and is seen as a committed European federalist.This story originally appeared in our sister paper, The National

title: what-a-difference-a-year-makes
story: As temperatures topped C on Monday ndash making it the warmest winter day since records began ndash it was a far cry from this time last year when the Beast from the East brought cold weather and heavy snowfall.Glasgow was as hot as Madrid on Monday as the city basked in temperatures as high as C.Photos captured across Britain this week tell a very dferent story from the same week last year when Glasgow was buried in the white stuff.

title: uk-immigration-plan-would-reduce-number-of-scottish-workers
story: The Scottish Government commissioned research said Scotlandrsquos working age population could fall by up to  per cent over the next two decades, while it grew in the rest of the UK.The Independent Expert Advisory Group on Migration and Population said new rules for EU nationals after Brexit could reduce halve migration to Scotland.This would have a direct impact on the economy, public services and population growth, with remote areas and Scotlandrsquos poundbn tourism industry particularly hard hit.:One of the last Scottish private schools for girls to shutThere could also be signicant staff shortages in the social care sector, adding to the strain on services for the elderly caused by a shrinking taxbase.Business leaders said the study showed the worrying impact of the plans and urged the UK government to change course.The report coincided with official statistics showing EU net migration at its lowest level since , and more citizens from Central and Eastern European leaving the UK than arriving.Under the UKrsquos immigration plans, EU workers currently able to enter the UK through freedom of movement, would be stopped unless they earned more than pound,.The advisory group estimated % of workers in Scotland currently earn below the threshold, and imposing it would disproportionately affect women and the young.:Independent Scotlandrsquos entry into the EU would be lsquoeasy says MEP Elmar BrokSNP migration minister Ben Macpherson said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has been consistently clear that freedom of movement has enriched Scotland and should be allowed to continue."The UK Governmentrsquos focus on reducing immigration will damage Scotland and does not reflect the needs of our economy, our public services or our communities.Professor Christina Boswell of the University of Edinburgh, the chair of the advisory group, said: ldquoIf the UK Governmentrsquos proposals are enacted, we are likely to see a substantial fall in net migration to Scotland over the coming decades. But importantly, the effects of this reduction will y across dferent sectors and local areas."The report considers the particular challenges for sectors reliant on non-UK workers who earn less than the proposed pound, threshold - such as accommodation and food services, manufacturing, and social care.ldquoIt also considers the particular challenges for rural and remote communities, which are especially reliant on in-migration to sustain economic livelihoods and public services ndash but which will be most affected by the proposed salary threshold."The proposed transitional arrangements for short-term migration are also likely to lead to higher churn and integration challenges in local communities.:Herald poll: Scotland should have independence referendum after BrexitAndrew McRae, of the Federation of Small Businesses in Scotland, said: ldquoThis thorough report... chimes with feedback from our membership and reinforces the case for an alternative approach to be developed.ldquoFewer working age people in Scotland will make it more dficult to run a business, especially in rural areas and in a number of key sectors."We need to see UK policymakers reflect on this studyrsquos findings, as well as the message theyrsquore getting from business, and take a more measured approach.Reacting to the latest official migration figures,Matthew Fell, CBI Chief UK Policy Director, said theywouldexacerbatelabour and skills shortages across multiplesectors.ldquoBusinesses cannot succeed without access skills and labour, which is why itrsquos so important the Government delivers a post-Brexit immigration system which is both open and controlled," he said."Employers of all sizes right across the UK will hope the Government acts on evidence from business carefully before taking decisions that will influence the UKrsquos competitiveness for decades to come.Scottish Labour MP Ian Murray, a supporter of the pro-Remain Best for Britain group, said: "This is further evidence that Brexit has made EU nationals living in the UK feel unwanted."Thats the opposite of what our country needs right now. Our hospitals need nurses and doctors, our schools need teachers, our universities need the best academics and researchers, and our isions need healing.ldquoAs Parliamentary paralysis continues, more and more people are packing their bags and leaving."The power to decide our future must be given back to the British people, giving them the final say on the Brexit deal, with the option to stay and build on our current deal with the EU firmly on the table."

title: belladrum-2019-whos-headlining-when-is-it-and-how-to-get-tickets
story: Scottish music fans are gearing up for a summer of live music, with Belladrum following TRNSMT and Electric Fields in revealing a star-studded lineup.The newly announced actsjoin Lewis Capaldi, CHVRCHES, Jess Glyne and Elbows in the th annual show in Beauly.Heres everything you need to know about this years Inverness festival:The Belladrum Tartan Heart festival takes placein August each year, and sees thousands of music fans head to Beauly near Inverness for a weekend of live music.Read more:Tartan Heart festival boss on how it all beganThe stage has welcomed the likes of Paloma Faith, Frightened Rabbit and Franz Ferdinand in past years.The festival holds an annual fancy dress parade, with each event promising a unique theme every year. The  theme is sci-fi, with prizes available for the best dressed.This years festival will see acts such as Jess Glynne, Elbows and CHVRCHES headline the three-day gig.Smaller stages will welcome Tom Odell, Lewis Capaldi, Jonny Marr and The Coral to the forefront.Bathgate singer Lewis Capaldi and founder of The Smiths Johnny MarrOther acts appearing at the festival this year include Hawkwind, Glasvegas, Richard Thompson, Julie Fowlis and Lucy Rose.And singer songwriter Dodie justy couldnt contain her excitement on Thursday morning when she was revealed as one of this years performers:WELL THIS IS A BIT EXCITING https:t.co QSRAFlVdNow in its th year, acts are set to take to the stage from August  to August .On Friday and Saturday, some stages will begin at around .am, with the Garden Stage starting at around pm.The main stage ends at pm each night, with other stages staying open until around am or .am on Friday and Saturday.Belladrum offer a number of camping opportunities, from pitching a tent to full-on glamping.There are options to bring your own facilities or rent in advance, and revellers can also take advantage of reserved spots for campervans or caravans.The festival are offering a bunch of ticket deals this year, which are available for purchase now on their website.A threeday adult ticket gives you access to both the headliner and support on the main stage on Thursday night, and early access to the campsite from am on the Thursday. A five-month payment plan option is also available.Read more:Belladrum : The Charlatans pay tribute to Frightened Rabbits Scott HutchisonA two day adult ticket gives the same access to camping on the Thursday, however ticketholders will not gain entry to the headliner and support acts on the main stage on Thursday night.Saturday adult tickets are available, and gives holders access to arenas and campsite from am on the Saturday and pm on the Sunday.ThursdayorFriday only ticketsare not available.For prices, information can be found on their website.Festival organisers have compiled a comprehensive list of easy ways to get to the event. Trains run from Inverness to Beauly, and their website has details on hiring coaches directly to the festival grounds.

title: moves-by-msps-to-ban-smacking-condemned-as-patronising-and-elitist
story: Dr Stuart Waiton, a senior lecturer at Abertay University, accused MSPs of failing to listen to public opinion.He argued criminalising all smacking would ldquologically lead to other forms of discipline, such as grounding, being outlawed.His comments came as Holyroodrsquos Equalities and Human Rights Committee examines the ChildrenScotland Bill.Giving evidence to MSPs, Dr Waiton said the idea of childrenrsquos rights was ldquoa bit of a nonsense concept, and insisted those who viewed smacking a child on the hand as a form of violence were ldquoliving on another planet.He said: ldquoChildren donrsquot have rights. They donrsquot have the same framework of rights as adults. They have protections, and essentially when we talk about childrenrsquos rights, what we are really talking about is the right of professionals to make decisions on their behalf.ldquoSo itrsquos a confused concept. It goes against the framework of how we have historically thought about rights in terms of freedoms."He added: ldquoYou are undermining the autonomy of loving parents to decide how to raise their children with a sense of privacy and also a sense of support from society.ldquoAnd in the process you are degrading something which is done as a form of discipline that should not be understood as a form of violence.He insisted children and adults should be treated dferently, adding: ldquoWe would not expect to ground our partners ndash refuse to let them leave the house.ldquoThat would be seen as a criminal offence, whereas we ground our children ndash or perhaps in a few yearsrsquo time, you will be making that criminal as well.He later continued: ldquoI would like to ask how you can dferentiate the upset a child feels at being grounded for a week, for example, compared to having their bottom or hand smacked.ldquoBecause I cannot see how, in the future,yoursquore going to be logically consistent, you will not eventually say that that should be banned as well.ldquoBecause the lsquolevel of vulnerabilityrsquo that you understand children to have is so high, and their lack of resilience is so profound, that I canrsquot see how this canrsquot eventually in five, ten yearsrsquo time, end up problematising almost any form of discipline whatsoever.Earlier, Dr Waiton told MSPs the Bill was ldquotragic and depressing and ldquoyet another one which appears to represent the aloof, elitist nature of politics and professional le, that treats parents in a very patronising and degraded way, uses all sorts of weird, legalistic talk about violence, equating children with adults, that makes no sense at all to ordinary people, and criminalises parents despite, again, people trying to claim that it doesnrsquot.He added: ldquoPeople talk about all the evidence proves that any level of smacking children damages them. Thatrsquos absolutely untrue and the opposite of the truth.ldquoBut I presume Irsquom just wasting my time because this Bill is already passed.The academic, who was the only one of eight witnesses to speak out against the legislation, argued banning smacking risked serious abuse cases getting lost in a ldquosea of complaints.But Diego Quiroz, policy officer at the Scottish Human Rights Commission, said it was ldquoshocking to argue children donrsquot have rights, and compared it to treating them like property ldquoor as wives were treated a century ago, or slaves even.Dr Waiton said this characterisation of his argument was ldquoquite despicable.Meanwhile, Professor Jane Callaghan, director of child wellbeing and protection at the University of Stirling, argued smacking does not have a place in a civilised culture.Public health researcher Dr Anja Heilmann said  countries around the world have now banned physical punishment.She said the UK was one of only three countries in the EU not to have outlawed the practice, while there is no evidence prosecutions have increased as a result of new laws where.

title: reducing-co2-is-simpleunderstand-the-solution-our-forestry-sector-can-offer
story: Fact one: The planet is getting hotter. The Met Office predicted recently that  is likely to be one of the warmest on record and that would mean  of the hottest-ever years have been since .Fact two: Planting trees and making timber products is one of the cheapest, simplest methods of capturing and storing atmospheric carbon.These two facts are not unrelated.Thankfully, the Committee on Climate Change , official adviser to the UK and devolved governments, has made the link. It says tackling climate change is no longer about limiting emissions we must remove carbon from the atmosphere to meet our targets ndash and forestry and wood is one "simple, low-cost option" to make real progress.Environmental organisations are getting the message too. Friends of the Earth has called for a doubling of UK tree coverto make a real impact - and as the body representing forestry and wood-using businesses across the UK, Confor has made forests, wood and climate change its priority for .When people hear the phrase Carbon Capture and Storage, I want them to think tree planting and using wood. Other optionsare often unproven and costly. Tree planting is simple, proven and cost-effective the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation calculated it was less than US per tonne of CO.A report for Confor looking at forestry in southern Scotland estimated that a hectare of woodland delivered carbon benefits of . tonnes of CO every year, slightly more than a personrsquos average annual emissions of . tonnes.Locking up carbon in wood products is not just good in itself - it also replaces far more energy-intensive materials. The Forestry Commission estimated that between . and . tonnes of carbon dioxide are saved because of the lower energy consumption involved in the manufacture of wood products, compared with materials like concrete or brick.Wood also gives us warm homes. In terms of thermal insulation, it is  times better than concrete,  times better than steel and  times better than aluminium.A hectare of woodland can offset more than the CO of an inidual for one year.Growing more of our own wood is also imperative around  per cent of UK wood products are imported, making us the second highest net importer in the world after China! We must take more responsibility for our supply chains, growing trees here under the worldrsquos highest sustainability standards, not exporting our environmental footprint to fragile global forests.Planting modern forests also gives us more than carbon-sequestering trees that will produce renewable supplies of carbon-storing timber. We also create green jobs , enhance bioersity, help reduce flood risks and increase recreation and tourism opportunities.We demonstrated these multiple benefits to Scottish Government Minister Mairi Gougeon when she visited the Jerah planting site in central Scotland last week - especially the way trees planted on the hill can reduce flooding in the community below. A study is being carried out by Heriot Watt University to learn lessons for future large-scale planting sites.Im encouraged by the progress Scotland is making on new woodland creation. Confor worked hard to streamline bureaucracy and create a positive message about modern, multi-purpose and mixed-species forestry - and Fergus Ewing, Cabinet Secretary for the Rural Economy, is a passionate supporter of modern forestry and the economic, environmental and social benefits, which can go hand in hand.A positive partnership between the Scottish Government, forestry and wood processing sector and wider rural interests has created a much better climate for productive tree planting. Last year, Scotland planted around  per cent of all new UK forests and has much more ambitioustargets for woodland creation than the rest of the UK.Scotlands Forestry Strategy, published earlier this month, re-affirms that positive approach to delivering multiple benefits by planting more forests. Encouragingly, it calls for tree planting and woodland creation and maintenance to become a "shared national endeavour".This approach fits perfectly with Scotlands desire to lead the way on climate change - setting a high bar for reducing emissions and leaping over it. If tackling climate change has been a golden thread of policy over the last decade and more, then forestry is the green gold in that thread - an environmentally and economically friendly industry which can help Scotland deliver on its climate change ambitions.Yet our climate change ambitions and responsibilities are not, and can not, be limited to our shores. Our approach has to be international. To make a real dference on climate change, lets think global - and plant local.Stuart Goodall is Chief Executive of Confor, and The Heralds Climate for Change guest editor. This article appeared in The Herald on the th February . For more information about the role Confor play in climate change, you can visit their websitewww.confor.org.ukThe Heraldrsquos Climate for Change initiative supports efforts being made by the ScottishGovernmentwith key organisations and campaign partners. Throughout the year we will provide a forum in The Herald newspaper, online at herald.scotland and inBusinessHQ magazine, covering news and signicant developments in this increasingly crucial area.If you are interested in contributing editorially or interestedin becoming aClimate for Change partner,please contactStephen McTaggarton  or emailstephen.mctaggart@heraldandtimes

title: george-eustace-resigns-over-brexit-saying-uk-is-on-path-to-final-humiliation
story: Mr Eustace, who becomes the th minister to resign over Britians withdrawal from the EU, insists that Britain must summon up the courage to be ready to ldquoface down the European Union here and now and ldquoreclaim our freedom by leaving without a deal,necessary, and then talk to Brussels afterwards.In a letter to Theresa May, the Cornish MP, who campaigned to leave the EU in the  referendum, explained he had resigned because of her decision to open up the path to putting back Brexit Day from March .Read more:Theresa May offers MPs Article  delay voteHe wrote: ldquoSince Parliament is now in direct control of events, I want to be free to participate in the critical debate that will take place in the weeks ahead.Mr Eustace made clear he would vote for the Prime Ministerrsquos Withdrawal Agreement when it s to the Commons and said he very much hoped Geoffrey Cox, the Attorney General, succeeded in securing final changes to the backstop.ldquoAlthough I campaigned to leave, I have always supported compromise to achieve a reconciliation in our country. Leaving the EU would represent an historic change and it is natural that some people will feel apprehensive.The MP for Camborne and Redruth said he had been open to the idea of using the UKrsquos existing membership of the European Economic Area as an exit mechanism and pointed out how he had supported Mrs Mayrsquos approach outlined at Chequers when others did not.ldquoI have stuck with the Government through a series of rather undignied retreats, he declared but noted: ldquoHowever, I fear that developments this week will lead to a sequence of events culminating in the EU dictating the terms of any extension requested and the final humiliation of our country.Read more:Brexit deal within our grasp, claims Theresa May as she sets her face against extending Article ldquoI appreciate that you have been terribly undermined by those in Parliament who refuse to respect the referendum result. You have shown tenacity and resilience over the past year. However, what our country needs from all its political leaders at this critical juncture is courage and we are about to find out whether Parliament has it.Mr Eustace said, as a minister, he had enjoyed good relations with the European Commission and with ministers from other member states.But he then noted: ldquoI do not believe that the Commission has behaved honourably during these negotiations. They have deliberately made progress slow and dficult. They have stated in terms that they will refuse to even hold substantive negotiations on a future partnership until after we leave.ldquoIf the position of Parliament is now that we will refuse to leave without an agreement, then we are somewhat stuck. This is uncomfortable for everyone but we cannot negotiate a successful Brexit unless we are prepared to walk through the door, insisted the former minister.Read more:We must support Government through Brexit, insists Micheal MartinHe went on: ldquoWe must therefore have the courage,necessary, to reclaim our freedom first and talk afterwards. We must be ready to face down the European Union here and now. The absence of an agreement poses risks and costs for them too. We already know that in the event of lsquono-deal the EU will seek an informal transition period for nine months in many areas and settlement talks could continue within this window.Mr Eustace added: ldquoI will do what I can from the back benches to try to salvage this sorry situation and I hope that, when the moment comes, Parliament will not let our country down.In response, Ian Blackford, the SNP Westminster leader, tweeted: "Another day another resignation from the UK Government. Any illusion to strong and stable ended before it began but this is beyond parody."This is not a ing Government it is the Tory Party at war with itself under a prime minister who cant give leadership."

story: A. title: james going for gold in gordon
story: The Liberal Democrats have selected their next candidate to be in the running for Gordon#s MP seat.The party has chosen James Oates, the nephew of long-serving former Gordon MP Malcolm Bruce.After graduating from Aberdeen University  years ago, he became a campaigner for human rights in Central and Eastern Europe.Multi-lingual, he later worked in the region for large investment firms such as JP Morgan, Robert Fleming and UBS, and for the past ten years he has been working with technology businesses in Tallinn, Estonia and building investment across the region.Commenting Mr Oates said: “I’m running to be Gordon’s MP because our country needs and wants to change. “It’s time to bring new energy, after the negativity of the past four years. It’s time for us to look the prosperity of the future and let go of the failed politics of the past.“It’s time for a new commitment to make sure that the opportunities in Gordon and in all of Scotland are recognised by the whole of the United Kingdom. Our contributions are not appreciated and our needs have been ignored for far too long.”He added: “I will not be one of those MPs that sits in London ignoring the people who put him there in the first place.“If I learned anything from Malcolm, it’s that cooperation, effective representation and respect for our communities are the most important traits I could have. My door will always be open.“I will bring Gordon and the needs of the Northeast to the Government, not the other way around.“It’s time our voices were heard again.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Mackies Managing Director and co-owner Mac Mackie"  Firm’s ice cream sales heat upviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The partnership will see Inverurie Green Grocer, Inverurie Smile Care, and Inverurie Foodbank working together for the community"  Partnership for dentist and foodbank viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: msp to host surgery for eu nationals amid brexit uncertainty
story: Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin will be holding a drop-in surgery for EU citizens concerned about the impact of Brexit on their settled status.It comes as the UK Government continues to negotiate its exit deal from the European Union before the expected leave date of March .Ms Martin has invited EU citizens living in her Aberdeenshire East constituency to join her at two separate events in Inverurie and Mintlaw this Saturday .Figures obtained from Spice, the Scottish Parliament’s research and information centre, show that there are around , EU nationals living and working in Aberdeen City and , in Aberdeenshire.People who want to stay in the UK must apply for settlement status through the EU Settlement Scheme.The first session will be held in Inverurie at the Garioch Community Education Centre from am till noon.The second session will be held in Mintlaw in the afternoon from pm till pm at the Macbi Centre.Commenting, Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin said: “I would encourage any EU citizens living in my constituency who have questions and are concerned about what applying for settled status means to them, to come along to the drop-in surgeries.“This is a very concerning time for everyone, not least for the huge number of EU nationals who have moved to Scotland and made our country their home.“The UK Government continues to cause uncertainty and there is a huge lack of reassurance available.“While many of the powers regarding EU citizens are reserved to Westminster, we will do all we can to help those living here in the North-East.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! title: oldmeldrum publican loses 2am licencing bid
story: An Oldmeldrum publican believes others in the trade are #wasting their time# applying for a am drinks licence after a failed bid by his own premises.Robin Philip, owner of Morris’s Hotel, was unsuccessful in his application for an extra hour on a Friday and Saturday for his public bar in a bid to boost dwindling trade.Dficult trading times in an economic climate hampered by increases in business rates and operating costs had prompted his application to extend weekend drinking times.However Aberdeenshire Central Licensing Board stuck to its policies which limits pubs and hotels to a am licence but which offers nightclubs am licences Sunday to Thursday and am on Fridays and Saturdays.The board had earlier heard objections to the later opening element of the application from Sgt Kim Wood on behalf of Police Scotland who said there was clear evidence that the longer and later on-sales licensed premises operate, the “higher the likelihood of incidents of crime, disorder and anti-social behaviour occurring”.But the Oldmeldrum publican stressed he had not experienced trouble in the  years he has run his business.He said the public bar only held  patrons who merely wanted to enjoy a slightly longer night out on a Saturday.Mr Philip said the crime figures presented by the police were for Ellon and Inverurie and had no bearing on Oldmeldrum.A motion by Cllr Marion Ewenson to approve elements of the application, including an outdoor drinking area, with the exception of the am Friday and Saturday extension, was unanimously approved.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: summer return for kintore fountain
story: The fountain in Kintore Town Square will be operational once again later this year.The granite feature had been damaged by vandalism and vehicle strikes, resulting in the loss of its top pillar.Repair work was undertaken in  to secure and stabilise the fountain, including a water tightness test, to ensure a full repair was viable.Funding to fully repair it was recently provided by the Garioch Area Committee and the Kintore Common Good Fund. A £, contract has now been awarded to Aberdeen-based KW Contractors Ltd to bring the fountain back to working condition. The work will include upgrading the plumbing and electrics to current standards, stone repairs and works to improve the existing road surface.Once complete, the fountain will operate -hours a day from May to September. Garioch Area Committee chair and local councillor for East Garioch, Fergus Hood, said: “The fountain is located in front of the historic Town House, occupying a prominent location in the Square and adding to the setting of nearby historic buildings.“It has always been a popular feature and we are aware the community has been keen to see it brought back into use, so I’m delighted we’ve been able to find the means to repair it and look forward to people enjoying the fountain again later this year.” Vice Chair, Dominic Lonchay, also a councillor for East Garioch, added: “Bringing the fountain back into operation has not been an easy thing for the council to do, but we feel it will ultimately be worth it. “This has traditionally been an attractive feature of the town centre and it will be great to see it working again after such a long time.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The former IK Motors yard on Inveruries Blackhall Industrial Estate"  Inverurie Screwfix shop is approvedviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Christine Graham pictured with some of her team members at The Barn"  Year of success for Foveran business viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: year of success for foveran business
story: A popular Foveran business celebrated its first anniversary last month.The Barn marked its first year of business on Friday, January .The cafe and beauty salonis owned by husband and we team Mark and Christine Graham.Since opening just one year ago the business has exceeded both their expectations as Christine explained: “We have been really busy and didn’t expect to be at this stage so early on.“We recently extended into the next building here and moved our kitchen so we have more seating for our customers and the potential for much more possibilities in the future.“We’ve added  extra seats but there are times where we could still do with more, and we have also created four new jobs.”She added: “We now have a team of  including two full-time chefs and two kitchen porters. A lot of our team members are also celebrating their first anniversary with us which is lovely.”Commenting on business so far, Christine believes their customers have been the key to its success as she said: “We’ve got an amazing following and the new AWPR has made a dference too as we have had customers up from as far as Stonehaven and Banchory.“We have -star reviews online and people have found us via TripAdvisor and Google.“The support has been overwhelming and we would be nothing without our customers, clients and team.”Looking to the future Christine said: “There are more exciting projects to come, but we are really excited about the warmer weather coming so people can enjoy a seat outside.”She added: “We recently received our licence so we are now open on Friday and Saturday evenings, people can stay a bit longer and enjoy a couple of drinks.“We are looking to organise comedy nights and race nights, and we are now fully licenced for private events including birthdays, weddings and christenings.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.deesidepiper webimage ..! title: Delay to Wick 20 mph speed limit plans
story: THE brakes have been put on plans to introduce a  mph speed limit on the majority of roads in Wick.The proposal was mooted by Highland Council as a way to improve road safety and encourage walking and cycling.However, Wick members of the Caithness committee this week described the scheme as "a blunt instrument" and said other measures to reduce speed would be more effective. They also felt the consultation period should be extended by three weeks to allow the public more time to respond to the plan.Speaking at the meeting in Wick Town Hall on Wednesday, Councillor Nicola Sinclair said she was "very much in favour" of improving road safety but was concerned about the scale of the  mph limit and claimed there should be a longer period of consultation."The consultation took place over the Christmas period and I dont think people got enough opportunity to get their views heard," she said.Full report in Fridayrsquos John OrsquoGroat Journal.Thursday  Feb  : PM
