title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Roadworks to be carried out at four Caithness locations
story: ROAD improvements costing pound, are to be carried out at four Caithness locations, starting next week.The work, to be carried out by Bear Scotland, will begin at Hempriggs on the A on Monday and will conclude at Thrumster in April.A spokeswoman for the company said: "We have a pound, programme of road improvements planned across four locations in the Caithness area on the A and A in March and April."Starting on Monday, surfacing improvements will first take place on the A at Hempriggs for  days to address the worn-out road surface and localised rutted sections. Works will then move to the A south of Georgemas for  days from Monday, March , to carry out surfacing improvements on the route."A three-day patching project will then take place on the A Berriedale south brae which will address defects in the road surface, followed by an eight-day surfacing project for a stretch of the A at Thrumster in April."The spokeswoman said the projects will take place during the day, from am to pm, with no work planned at weekends to keep disruption to a minimum. A mph convoy system will be in place during working hours to escort traffic past the works areas at each location."Teams will do all they can to complete the projects as quickly and safely as possible. However, we encourage people to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date journey information," the spokeswoman added.Wick and east Caithness Highland councillor, Raymond Bremner, has been pressing for the road improvements on that section of the A and is "absolutely delighted" they are going ahead."The northbound side of the road has been in a deteriorating state of repair for some time and it certainly looked as though we were needing more than a pothole repair approach," he said. "I reviewed the road with an engineer in the spring of last year. As a result, and after a lot of discussion between the agencies, Bear and Transport Scotland, Irsquom delighted the remedial works are about to start."Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Scottish Government urged to help secure future of Caithness Horizons
story: A CALL has been made for the Scottish Government to "play its part in securing a future for Caithness Horizons".It was made by local MP Jamie Stone in a letter to First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and comes after talks between representatives of the museum and gallery and Highland Council.Horizons chairman Craig Brown said: "The meeting was positive in discussing possible options for long-term financial stability to allow Caithness Horizons to reopen. Further meetings are scheduled over the coming weeks."Regarding widespread concern about the future of the museum collection, Mr Brown said it "remains complete and in the same safe condition while the next steps are discussed" with the local authority.Mr Stone, the MP for Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross, described Horizons ndash which closed unexpectedly last week ndash as part of "a string of pearls" to entice visitors to the area, the others being the Castle of Mey and Dunrobin Castle.He urged the First Minister to help identy a way "to keep this vital facility open".Mr Stone said: "I was appalled to hear of this closure ndash not least because it doesnrsquot seem that long since it was first opened. Caithness Horizons has been a great success in interpreting the geology, wildle and history of the far north for local people and visitors alike. It is up to date, visually striking, full of information and everyone who has been has come away much enthused."The closure of Caithness Horizons is precisely what we cannot allow to happen and it is for this reason that the Scottish Government should play its part in securing a future for the facility."Councillor Struan Mackie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, is concerned about public statements on dispersing the collection and says that is "contrary to the founding principles of Horizons".He said any part of the permanent collection not on loan "must remain in Caithness, regardless of the future of the Horizons facility. And in the event of closure the permanent collection would revert to the Highland Council."Councillor Mackie says the local authority should explore alternative operating models and wants "a cast iron commitment to ensure our countys heritage stays in Caithness for future generations."Ian Leith, chairman of the Wick Society, which runs Wick Heritage Museum in the townrsquos Bank Row, described the closure of Caithness Horizons as "a great loss"."From a heritage point of view it is certainly important, particularly its collection which should not be broken up and dispersed," he said.Mr Leith emphasised that the heritage groups in Caithness are not in competition "but telling parts of the same story". He said: Caithness Horizons had its part to play. Now its gone it is a great loss, but hopefully it can be retrieved."He said the Thurso museum and gallery had "very dedicated and very experienced staff".Mr Leith added: "It is too important to lose, particularly its heritage collection which has a national signicance. If it was broken up it would dilute the story. Whatever the future holds, the collection must be retained."Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Urgent action needed after twins are born 52 miles apart
story: A CALL has been made for the Scottish Government to act on maternity provision in Caithness after a mother gave birth to twins at hospitals  miles apart.Local MP Jamie Stone described what happened as "a fiasco" and "shameful" and said it was time First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and her cabinet took action to deal with the situation.Highlands and Islands MSP Rhoda Grant raised the matter in the Scottish Parliament, while Caithness Health Action Teamsaid the case highlighted the maternity problems in the far north.Mr Stone, the Liberal Democrat MP for Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross, said: "No woman should have to face this when giving birth. It is shameful that it has taken a fiasco like this for the Scottish Government to sit up and take notice."Thankfully, the mother and both babies are healthy and we must thank the local NHS staff for their excellent work."However, this is a situation that neither the mother nor the staff should have been put in and we desperately need action from the Scottish Government."Geography and distance should not be something expectant mothers have to deal with and the government must accept that no-one should lack access to health services simply because of where they live."He spoke out after the womans ordeal was made public. She went to Caithness General Hospital in Wick in November after her waters broke when she was  weeks pregnant.It was decided she should go by ambulance to Raigmore in Inverness, over  miles away, to have her babies.But as she was near Golspie, her contractions became stronger and she was taken to the local community hospital, the Lawson Memorial, where she gave birth to a boy.A helicopter was then to take the woman to the Highland capital but was unable to land due to frost on its propellers so she made the rest of the journey by ambulance and gave birth to the second twin.Labours Rhoda Grant raised the case in parliament and claimed the air ambulance should have been called when the woman went into labour.She asked: "It begs the question why was the air ambulance or emergency retrieval team not tasked initially to airlt the mum from Caithness "Will the First Minister investigate this and will she make sure that the air ambulance treats situations like this as a priority "Nicola Sturgeon promised to investigate and asked Scotlands health secretary, Jeane Freeman, to look into it.Bill Fernie, the chairman of Chat, said the case highlighted the groups concerns about mothers having to travel to Inverness to give birth."Fortunately, we have not had a tragedy yet and hopefully we never will ndash but this underlines the fears we have had since the changes were made to the local maternity unit. There has been no risk assessment for the people who have to travel to Raigmore to have their babies."There has never been a problem with care at Caithness General or Raigmore, but mothers here should get the same kind of access to treatment as they get in the cities and we used to have here. Why in an emergency cant the experts be on call to come to Wick rather than the other way round "I hope this Scottish Government investigation comes up with some solutions to this whole problem."NHS Highland said an internal review will be carried out to consider the specic circumstances of this case.Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Thursday  Feb  : PM

title: accessibility top of the agenda for northlink
story: Changes are being made by NorthLink Ferries to make their services more accessible to all.On board information workshops and the introduction of new website software are the latest efforts being made by the company to improve services for those with additional support needs.The ferry operator implemented its new Recite Me accessibility tool on its website, this month, to make it more suitable to folk#s needs. The new software — which can be used on desktops and mobile browsers — allows website visitors to customise what they see and hear, from changing the contrast settings, language, font size and more.In the UK, there are estimated to be . million people with a learning disability and . million people who have English as a second language. ‘Recite Me’ has the ability to translate the NorthLink Ferries website into more than  languages — including Scots Gaelic . It can also translate text-to-speech to help visually impaired users and focus screen areas for those with dyslexia.On Monday, February , teams on board MV Hamnavoe hosted an Access Panel Orkney session, where staff were provided with disability awareness training. During the two-hour session, staff were able to experience what it’s like to have a disability by wearing glasses that simulated blindness, used wheelchairs and crutches and had their hearing dampened.Carolyn Grfiths of Access Panel Orkney said: “The aim of our session was to let staff experience disabilities first-hand so they can empathise with passengers’ needs.#All of us running the training have a disability so we were able to provide first-hand examples of what accessible travel is like for us. We were delighted to be welcomed on board to provide this training and it’s great to see a company like Serco NorthLink Ferries take accessibility for passengers seriously.”The MV Hjaltland will also host a Making Connections workshop today, Friday, February . The workshop will look at how passengers navigate potential barriers when changing from one mode of transport to another. Making Connections brings disabled people together with transport operators to discuss, address and plan how travel connections can be made easier.Seumas Campbell, customer service director at NorthLink Ferries, said: “Catering for passengers with ying degrees of disability is an important part of our service provision. Whether they are using our website to book their journey, making a connection from other forms of public transport or coming on board one of our vessels, we believe that passengers should experience a service that caters to all their needs.“The new website software will allow visitors to customise what they see and hear and as more and more visitors from around the world choose NorthLink Ferries to travel to the Northern Isles, ‘Recite Me’ is a great tool to help them plan and book their journey.“Our workshops are also a great way in training our staff on how they can best help and understand passengers’ needs. We pride ourselves on having a great team that always provides the best service so it’s important that we’re constantly refreshing their training.”For more information on accessibility for passengers on NorthLink Ferries, you can visit www.northlinkferries copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: alfred takes to the water in vietnam
story: PENTLAND Ferries and Strategic Marine Vietnam have announced the successful launch of the new vessel Alfred.At pm Vietnam time on Friday, well-wishers, invited guests, shipyard workers and Pentland Ferries team members lined the slipway as the completed hull of the ship rolled down the slipway and into the warm waters of where the vessel was built, Vung Tau, Vietnam.Since the keel was laid, approximately , tonnes of steel hull and aluminium superstructure have been welded together in a large workshop to create the flagship vessel for Pentland Ferries operations, named after Pentland Ferries managing director Andrew Banks# father Alfred Banks.The ship will carry  passengers and up to twelve lorries combined with  cars, or  cars in total.The final fit out of the interior will take place prior to a complete series of sea trials in Vietnam before Pentland Ferries crew sail Alfred back to home base in St Margaret#s Hope.Joseph Azran Alemberg SMV chief operating officer said: “Today’s a big day for Strategic Marine Vietnam and a proud moment for everyone that contributed to the vessel build. Strategic Marine and Pentland Ferries worked tirelessly in co-operation to bringing the project to fruition.”Andrew Banks said: “We are delighted to announce Alfred has been launched successfully and we are looking forward to getting the ship home to Orkney and into service.#The vessel, which had a breadth of m, and a draft of .m, has a top speed of  knots.The expected handover of the vessel to Pentland Ferries is at the end of March, with the delivery voyage set to take around six weeks weeks. It is hoped that the new vessel will be in service in June.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur calls for action on astronomical fuel poverty
story: Liam McArthur has responded to new data showing that Orkney has, once again, the highest rates of fuel poverty in Scotland. The Orkney MSP has today, Tuesday, urged the Scottish Government to #pay heed to the realities of fuel poverty.#The figures, published by the Scottish Government, showed that the fuel poverty rate in Orkney was  per cent — compared to  per cent in the City of Edinburgh.“Fuel poverty levels are shameful Scotland-wide in this day and age,# said Mr McArthur.#However, these figures underline that rural and island communities are disproportionately badly affected.“I have consistently made the case for recognition of this alarming disparity, and I am glad that the Housing Minister has now agreed to look at options to recognise that ahead of Stage Two of the Fuel Poverty Bill.“Orkney and other rural and island communities urgently need targeted action to reduce the astronomical rates of fuel poverty and extreme fuel poverty. title: new vice lord lieutenant named
story: Her Majesty The Queen has approved the appointment of Elaine Grieve as Vice Lord-Lieutenant of Orkney with immediate effect.Ms Grieve takes over from Keith Johnson, who retired recently having reached the statutory retirement age. She is the first woman to fill this post since the Orkney Lieutenancy was established in .The -year-old, is a Masters graduate of Glasgow University, a former head teacher and an honorary sherf, and was previously an assistant chief executive of Orkney Islands Council.The new Vice Lord-Lieutenant will assist the Lord-Lieutenant, Bill Spence, during the last year of his Lieutenancy duties. Living in Firth, she has Rousay, Longhope and Kirkwall family connections, having attended Kirkwall Grammar School before teacher training in Aberdeen.Ms Grieve  has wide interests in music, the arts and the voluntary sector. She is presently involved with the Orkney Folk Festival, the Pier Arts Centre Trust, Orkney Housing Association and Voluntary Action Orkney — where she is vice chairwoman.“It’s an honour to have been considered for this role,# said the new Vice Lord-Lieutenant.#I have family connections with the Orkney Lieutenancy and it’s such a great privilege to have been appointed Vice Lord-Lieutenant. I very much look forward to supporting the Lord-Lieutenant in his duties.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: scapa 100 call for descendants
story: Plans are developing to mark the centenary of the scuttling of the German High Seas Fleet in Scapa Flow, with a call for descendants to become involved in the programme of events.The deliberate sinking of the vessels on  June  remains one of the greatest losses of shipping ever recorded in a single day.One hundred years later, commemorations will be held on Midsummer’s Day  to remember the  German lives lost as a result of the internment and scuttling of the fleet.A programme of community events held around the time of the anniversary will reveal the historical signicance of the scuttling and mark its impact and continued legacy in Orkney.The events in  were witnessed by a large group of school children from Stromness, who were on an outing in Scapa Flow aboard a local vessel, the Flying Kestrel.Antony Mottershead, arts officer with Orkney Islands Council, said: “We are working with partners in Germany to seewe are able to identy and contact any descendants of the  sailors who sadly lost their lives.#Closer to home, we would like to hear from descendants of the children who were aboard the Flying Kestrel or have a close family connection to the events that unfolded that day.”Antony can be contacted at antony.mottershead@orkney.gov.uk or on   extension .copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: scottish government deliver lfass loan update
story: Farmers in Orkney should now have received an offer of a loan for the National Less Favoured Area Support Scheme from the Scottish Government.With the offer of the government#s loan — which offers  per cent of the anticipated  payment — due to have reached over , Scottish farmers and crofters as of yesterday, payments are due to commence in early April.Rural economy secretary Fergus Ewing said: “With the on-going uncertainty surrounding whether we will leave the EU at the end of March with a deal in place, it is vital that we provide as much financial support and stability as possible to those operating in our most remote and rural areas.“I can, therefore, confirm that loan offer letters have now issued to more than , farmers, which will inject up to £ million into our rural economy, safeguarding jobs and local businesses, with payments beginning early April.“Having listened to stakeholders on the ongoing impacts of the last eighteen months, I am acutely aware of the continuing importance of LFASS to our hill farmers and crofters, which is why I would encourage all eligible farmers and crofters totheir opt-in acceptance loan offer as quickly as possible.”The farmers union in Scotland welcomed the update saying, with the loan, the government is acknowledging just how important the payment is to the whole rural economy.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: work to restore cemeteries set to get underway
story: Work to reinstate headstones laid flat in Orkney’s cemeteries is due to get underway shortly.Work will begin in Stenness, with the initial focus being on headstones that are under one metre tall, and were put up after .These will be reinstated at no cost to the family, according to Orkney Islands Council.Harvey Johnston, convener of Orkney Islands Council, said: “We apologise again for the upset and distress that has been caused to local families, and hope that they are comforted that appropriate action is being taken to put this right.#As a caring organisation, responsive to public concern, we will restore kirkyards to the condition people would expect.#The move follows a public outcry at the state of the county#s cemeteries and accusations that the authority had not informed relatives of their intention to lay a headstone flat.The council later issued a full apology.Interim work will also be carried out across a iety of cemeteries in the coming weeks, to infill the holes left by the headstones that have been laid flat.Councillor Johnston added: “As we look to the future, local folk’s safety will remain an important concern for us, and we will be resuming our headstone inspections at an appropriate time.“Be assured, though, that we’re taking steps to make sure that our actions are proportionate to the risk posed, that we mark stones identied as being unsafe and highlight these to local community representatives, and that we give relatives the time they need to discuss with us any work they might wish to carry out themselves.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Ambitious plan sets goals to end fuel poverty
story: PEOPLE across Ross-shire could benefit after the Scottish Government incorporated changes into its own draft legislation to ldquoend the scourge of fuel poverty.An earlier barrage of criticism claimed the Fuel Poverty Bill missed the target when it came to delivering for the ldquoworst affected areas.Fuel poverty is defined as when households spend  per cent or more of income on domestic fuel ndash reckoned to account for one in four homes in Scotland.The figure is understood to be signicantly higher across swathes of Ross-shire, hitting homes which are not on the gas grid and reliant on oil and low-income households.Minister for local government, housing and planning, Kevin Stewart, promised to include ldquoa rural, remote and island minimum income standard in poverty calculations as well as what he called ldquoa rural uplt.He was speaking at the first stage of a Holyrood debate of the Bill which aims to cut fuel-poor households to five per cent by  from the current national average of almost  per cent.The move was welcomed by rural housing associations and local councillors but Highlands Tory MSP Jamie Halcro Johnston vowed to maintain pressure on the government to deliver on what was promised.He said: "The minister announced that a new rural, remote and island minimum income standard will be included in their fuel poverty calculations alongside a rural uplt. We will be looking to strengthen the Bill as it progresses through the Scottish Parliament and ensuring that the Scottish Governmentrsquos pledges are met."Before Wednesdayrsquos debate Mr Stewart said: ldquoWithin this ground-breaking legislation, not only are we one of the few countries in the world to define fuel poverty, we are also setting a goal towards eradicating it.ldquoBy changing the definition of fuel poverty so itrsquos more closely aligned to relative income poverty and taking steps to ensure it works for remote rural and island communities, we are ensuring our support is focussed on those who need it most."He added: "In this day and age, it is unacceptable that any Scottish household should have to choose between having the heating on and cooking their dinner.Councillor Ian Cockburn, who represents the Wester Ross, Strathpeffer and Lochalsh welcomed the Bill as "something has to be done about fuel poverty" while arguing it is also time to rethink infrastructure like the national grid."It is ambitious but has to be tried to get fuel poverty down in rural areas. We are one of the most energy rich countries in the world so we should be able to get something done. Too many people take it as just being part of the landscape up here so we need to change that thinking as well to get people the assistance that they need."Scotland should not be in this state. But you have to look back, the National Grid was set up at the end of the war, the Highlands is considered off-grid despite supplying much of the rest of the country through hydro and wind power. It is time for a rethink."Calum Macaulay, chief executive of Invergordon-based Albyn Housing Society, said: ldquoWe welcome this development in the Scottish Governmentrsquos approach to addressing fuel poverty in rural areas. The push to include minimum income standards feels like a signicant step forwards. This is something that the Rural and Islands Housing Association Forum has been promoting for quite some time."This has included research undertaken with the support of Highlands and Islands Enterprise and others into minimum income standards in rural communities. The results of this highlighted the pressures of lower average household incomes and higher average fuel costs across the northern parts of Scotland."What do you think  Share your views by emailing newsdesk@spp-groupThursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Call for flexibility over closure of Rosemarkie toilets
story: FEARS are intensying over the future of public toilets in Rosemarkie after Highland Council revealed that it would only keep them open until the end of March.The th hour news appears to fly in the face of assurances given to local community leaders at a meeting last November and has sparked a petition that has already got more than  signatures from worried locals calling for the council to keep the facility open.It had been hoped a charitable trust could be set up to take over the running of the facility, a process anticipated to take months, but time for that is running out and in the meantime it is feared harm could be done to the villagersquos appeal as a visitor destination.The well-loved and well-respected Groam House Museum could be impacted as well, with staff and visitors both needing to use the public convenience as there are no facilities on the premises.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoA draft temporary lease is being drawn up to enable the planned Community Development Trust to be taken forward. If the facility is not taken on by the community then it will close on March as per report to the Highland Council [on] October .ldquoNo survey will be undertaken, the facility will transfer in lsquoas seen, as isrsquo condition, the facilities will transfer in their current operational condition. The position of toilets remaining open whilst negotiations are ongoing is for this financial year only. There is no budget to retain facilities... which is why we want to get the leases sorted out before the end of March.Despite that the director of the Groam House Museum Doug Maclean, who recently attended a meeting of the community council where the future of the toilets was on the agenda remains hopeful.ldquoWe are confident that by some means or other, through a charitable trust taking over the running of the toilets and the good services of the local people, we will be able to keep the toilets open, he said.However, Mr Maclean was in no doubt about how serious an effect the closure would have on Rosemarkie as well as Groam House Museum.ldquoFrom the museumrsquos point of view it is absolutely vital for our existence. We have groups of school children that come here and of course children need to go to the toilet, he said.ldquoWe also have groups of mainly elderly American tourists and they are not in a position to make their way to the beach cafeacute. And we would lose both those groups without the toilets which put the museum in jeopardy.Black Isle ward councillor Gordon Adam said: ldquoI am in discussions with the council over the time limit of March , my view is that the council needs to be flexible. Savings have to be made, but sticking rigidly to a timetable leaves little time to form development groups.Thursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Thursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Conon Bridge pupils injury sparks community discussion
story: AN accident at a Ross-shire school which left a child with a badly broken leg will be discussed by Conon Bridge Community Council.Max McPhee was five when a large stone fell from a boundary wall at Ben Wyvis Primary School in May , crushing his leg.After months of treatment the youngster, now seven, has been left with one leg cm shorter than the other. This week it emerged that the boy had won legal action against Highland Council.The local authority, whose former chief executive Steve Barron had to apologise to parents for a series of faults with the building after its completion, had denied liability throughout the civil action.But it backed down when the boyrsquos solicitor Digby Brown proved it knew of an earlier debris fall one year before Max was injured.Secretary of Conon Bridge Community Council John Bruce said the matter will be on their agenda at their meeting next Wednesday.At the time of Maxrsquos accident, the chairwoman of the community council, Fiona MacKintosh, said there had been a catalogue of repairs to the pound million school since it opened in  including the closure of the main games hall.After the settlement was announced Maxrsquos mum Louiseaccused the council of acting shamefully over her sonrsquos injury. She said: ldquoItrsquos shocking that Highland Council didnrsquot have the decency to hold their hands up and just help a little boy who was hurt by their own failings.A Highland Council spokeswoman said: ldquoIt is the councilrsquos policy not to comment on insurance claims.Thursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Dingwall story circle is first of many
story: A HIGHLAND councillor hopes that a new story circle which uses books to tackle prejudice and intolerance will be the first of many across Scotland ndash following its successful arrival in Dingwall.Heartstone, which has been based in Dingwall for the past  years and works to build understanding across cultures and nationalities, has enjoyed success where in the UK with exhibitions in the likes of London and Edinburgh.And they brought the message lsquohomersquo last week with a new story circle in Dingwall library, reading the fantasy tale The Heartstone Odyssey.The novel is aimed at nine to -year-olds and sees the fantasy aspects interwoven with deeper issues such as prejudice and intolerance.The story circle was opened by John West from High Le Highland along with Highland councillor Andrew Jarvie and Sita Kumari, the director of Heartstone.Cllr Jarvie said working on the project had been a privilege, adding: ldquoI really do hope that this is the start of many of these story circles and that we can work with the Scottish Government to give this home grown organisation the  it deserves across Scotland.The story circle was lead by Ms Kumari who took on the role of storyteller and dancer as she brought to le the heroine of the story, Chandra.Ms Kumari, said: ldquoThis book deals with the issues through the imagination, without lecturing or preaching, changing hearts and minds to see beyond stereotypes and prejudice and to recognise a common humanity.She was inspired to create the organisation when she was first told the story over  years ago.ldquoIt was first told to me as an oral story on a three-day train journey from Mumbai to Chennai in the rsquos from which everything has followed, she explained. ldquoIt was a le-changing experience leading to the formation of Heartstone.Carmen Garcia-Pagan, library supervisor at Dingwall Library, said the library were delighted to be involved in the launch: ldquoThe Heartstone Odyssey is a thought-provoking tale which tackles some powerful issues.Thursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Family remember happy and friendly teenager after tragic accident near Inverness
story: The family of a teenager killed in a road traffic collision at Dochgarroch has spoken about their "happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly".Policehave confirmed that the -year-old who died as a result of the two-vehicle collision at around .pm on Sunday night was Samuel Foster, of Lochend near Inverness.The family said: ldquoSamuel, our darling boy, was incredibly popular and had a huge circle of friends. He attended Millburn Academy before moving to Inverness College two years ago to study engineering."He also worked at the bakery at Marks and Spencer for two years and loved his motocross biking and cars.ldquoSamuel was a happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly.ldquoSamuel was the youngest of four siblings and words canrsquot express how much he will be missed by his parents Heather and Lenny, his brother David and twin sisters Samantha and Kirsty, his nephew Reuben and niece Georgie.ldquoWe would like to thank the incredible number of people who have sent us messages of sympathy ndash your kind words mean so much and are a reminder of just how popular and well-loved Samuel was."We hope he will always be remembered this way.Thursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Funding blow to Ross shire alcohol support service
story: ALCOHOLISM support in Ross-shire has been dealt a blow after a group that helps people fight addiction announced its closure ndash amid funding cuts and increasing red tape.The board of Alcohol Counselling Services Ross and Sutherland , which has been supporting people in the region for more than  years, has ldquosadly and regretfully decided that the service will close from April .News of the closure has been greeted with dismay by recovering addicts, one of whom, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that without the service their ldquooutcome could have been very dferent.Explaining the reasons for the closure, the servicersquos co-ordinator, Chris Cochrane, said: ldquoThis decision has not been taken lightly. There are many reasons why this course of action is necessary, the main one being the struggle to secure sufficient finances to run the organisation.About pound, to pound, is needed annually but Ms Cochrane said that the NHS is doing a review of third sector input, and can only confirm funding up to June.Without the support of the NHS, they will find it dficult to win the support of other funding bodies.The news will be a blow to the  service users currently on the books of ACSRS many of whom faced a personal battle before seeking help and then keeping on attending to receive the support on offer.However Ms Cochrane said they will do everything in their power to ensure their clients receive alternative assistance with their dependency. Around  people with alcohol dependency are referred to them each year.She said: ldquoThe board is actively pursuing alternative arrangements for our service users and volunteer counsellors who wish to continue their support or volunteering.ldquoACSRS has been indebted to many people over the years who have given their time and expertise freely as volunteers. Some have assisted in the management of the service as board members providing governance and support for staff and volunteers.ldquoOthers have given thousands of hours of their free time as trained volunteer counsellors. There are six counsellors and not all of them will be wanting to move on though some might seek paid employment.ldquoThe training for these counsellors was previously provided free. It now requires a source of additional funding.ldquoAs for other voluntary organisations, the burden of bureaucracy has increased without the corresponding increase in income, and the task of securing additional funding has become more challenging.ldquoACSRS is the only voluntary organisation within Ross-shire and Sutherland offering a free professional one-to-one counselling service for those affected by their own or a loved onersquos addiction. Our work complements the work done by NHS Drug and Alcohol Recovery staff.ldquoWe would like to thank all those people for their extremely valuable contributions which made it possible for us to serve our community for over  years.Councillor Margaret Paterson, Dingwall and Seaforth, said: ldquoI know this group and this will be a dreadful loss as they give a tremendous service. It is quite distressing to hear this because they have given people with addiction and their families such help for so many years. Their volunteers have given such time and talent to help the vulnerable in society, butthey donrsquot have money then they just canrsquot do it. I hope that something can be done to continue their good work.Two service users who wished to remain anonymous praised ACSRS for the help they received. One said: ldquoI can honestly say that ACSRS played a major part in my recovery. If that help was not there when I needed it, the outcome could have been very dferent.The other said: ldquoHearing a voice that was willing to listen to me was a relief on one of the darkest days of my le.Thursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Landmark anniversary for Ullapool arts hub
story: ONE of the countryrsquos smallest independent art schools is set to celebrate a major milestone by marking the st anniversary of its flagship course.Bridge House Art in Ullapool has been running its Portfolio Course since the late rsquos.In that time the school has built a growing reputation and has hosted students from as far afield as Lithuania, France, Switzerland, Spain and the USA.And on Sunday will celebrate the anniversary with its annual exhibition of portfolio course work ndash following an intensive four month training in the visual arts for  people from across the UK and mainland Europe.RESONANCE opens and will run daily from am to pm to March  at An Talla Solais Gallery, West Argyle Street, Ullapool and entry is free.It promises to be an eclectic mix of drawing, painting, printmaking, jewellery and illustration. Much of the work will be available for sale.Eleanor White, founder and principal tutor said: ldquoThe ethos behind all of our courses is to encourage everybody to learn to communicate visually and express a genuine response to the environment around us. I have been delighted with the way this yearrsquos students have responded to the challenge, this promises to be an excellent exhibition.Coming from a range of ages and backgrounds, the students have one thing in common ndash a shared desire to develop as artists. The -week course covers a range of disciplines including painting, printmaking, textiles and sculpture. Each inidual spends the second term developing a themed body of work and these will be on show at the exhibition.Kittie Jones, senior tutor and award-winning professional artist, said: ldquoI am always impressed by the dedication, hard work and motivation of the students on this course, many of them have moved up here to be part of the course and the results speak for themselves.Thursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Mystery oil tank artist adds a splash of colour to Invergordon
story: ITrsquoS a site steeped in local history and a lasting legacy to Invergordonrsquos nautical history.But the disused fuel tanks which stored the oil which powered some of the Royal Navyrsquos greatest warships during World War II has been a blight on the landscape of the Easter Ross port for generations.Recently, however, a graffiti artist has been hard at work beautying some of the relics, doing a lsquoBanksyrsquo with colourful images at the giant Seabank fuel tanks near the railway line, adding to lots of mural street art in the town already undertaken by the Invergordon Off The Wall group.Now the search is on to find the mystery painter who has already made a start on a canvas of over  massive tanks to choose from.Local woman Jacqueline Brown said she wasnrsquot sure exactly when the artwork was done: ldquoBut we would love to find out who is doing it.ldquoThe site really is out of bounds to the public but people go in and walk their dogs. I think I first saw the murals last year and they are quite stunning. Whoever is doing it is obviously very talented. Itrsquos a fascinating site. We know Invergordon became a naval town and was the base for the Home Fleet in World War I. These tanks were built for the supply of fuel to warships and they were in use until the mid-s.Mrs Brown said like many street artists, the person who carried out the work may wish to remain anonymous and even be fearful of prosecution.ldquoI just donrsquot know. But what they have done is quite beautul. I am sure we could find more projects for them in Invergordon including the town house which the community wants to take back into public ownership.A website documenting historical and derelict places in Scotland reveals the depot was built in conjunction with secret oil storage tanks a few miles away.It records the underground tanks were built to hold  million gallons of oil fuel and were built into a solid rock hill to protect it from bombs.On February ,  a Junkers  is reported to have carried out a solo attack on the tank farm, dropping two lb bombs damaging two tanks. But none of the bombs exploded although they cause a major spillage of oil.Mrs Brown said she understood there were plans to remove some tanks to build houses. She said: ldquoBut it takes time for these sites to be decontaminated from their former industrial uses.In , flats built in Joss Street had to be demolished because the site, which had been formerly used as a gas works, hadnrsquot been properly decontaminated.What do you think  Share your views by emailing us at newsdesk@spp-groupThursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Ross shire MP backs calls for new access to cash regulator
story: PEOPLE in Ross-shire communities which have witnessed a string of bank closures need to have protected access to cash.Thatrsquos the view of MP Jamie Stone who is backing calls by consumer group Which  for the government to appoint a regulator to protect such access.Mr Stone, MP for Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross, says the ldquoalarming rate of bank closures has seen an increasing number of people struggling to find direct access to cash through ATMs, and as a consequence, sometimes find it dficult to pay for essential goods and services.Which  says that despite the increased popularity of digital and card payments, which have proven vulnerable to IT failures, ldquohaving access to cash is still a necessity for more than  million people across the country.It says Scotland has seen  bank branches close since , making it one of the worst affected areas in the UK. It says these closures risk having an impact on businesses and communities alike.It notes that  cashpoints have closed in a year, the majority free-to-use machines. It wants to see a regulator with sole responsibility for the cash infrastructure to ensure consumers and businesses can continue accessing cash.Mr Stone said: ldquoThe combined closures of bank branches and free-to-use cashpoints across Scotland continues at an alarming rate leaving people in my constituency without access to the cash they rely on.He says he doesnrsquot want to see people ldquoleft behind by technology.Your view  Email newsdesk@spp-groupThursday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. story: A MENrsquoS shed group in Ross-shire hopes to build on its success as it enters its third year.Dingwall Menrsquos Shed, which has celebrated its second anniversary, boasts more than  signed up lsquosheddersrsquo who work on inidual projects and share their expertise with like-minded folk who are good with their hands.Reflecting on the last year and looking ahead, the grouprsquos Andy Foley said: ldquoThe next two years are going to be at least as busy as the last two,not even busier since, in addition to more of the same, we need to raise funds to enable us to erect our own, desperately-needed custom-built premises in Dingwall.ldquoWe anticipate that this will allow us to flourish further by increasing our membership and the range of activities that we can offer.A pound grant through Groundwork UK, which manages the Tesco Bags of Help scheme, paved the way for the purchase of power tools and air filtration equipment.The group also helped a local scout group install a new window for its hall to provide some much-needed natural light.Members have also had talks on menrsquos health issues and photography, a basic first aid training session and made goods for sale from recycled wood and old oak whisky casks.Theyrsquove also helped to smarten up parts of Dingwall, such as the pathway along the canal, and knocked up a couple of picnic tables for the MOO Food project in Muir of Ord.Some members have also raised money for charities.There were just  menrsquos sheds in the UK a few years ago. title: actor chiwetel ejiofor on his directorial debut
story: Chiwetel Ejiofor, , was well aware of the challenges that could crop up with his latest project.The Boy Who Harnessed The Wind, based on the the bestselling book by William Kamkwamba and Bryan Mealer, is not only his directorial debut, but he also stars in the moving film.The inspiring true story, which premiered at the Sundance film festival in late January, follows -year-old William Kamkwamba .After he’s thrown out of the school he loves when his family can no longer afford the fees, he manages to sneak back into the school library.And he finds a way, using the bones of the bicycle belonging to his father Trywell , to build a windmill, which then saves his Malawian village from famine.Ejiofor, who was born in Forest Gate to Nigerian parents and grew up visiting his family in villages much like William’s, bought the film rights after reading the book in , developing it over the best part of a decade.Explaining what drew him to the story, he says: “The cultural history of where the subjects are from and their dynamics in and around this landscape are beautul, cinematic and fascinating.”The star was  and attending the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art when he was cast in his debut film, Amistad, by Steven Spielberg.His profile has risen thanks to roles in films such as  Years A Slave, which earned him an Oscar nomination for best actor.When it comes to the move behind the camera, he says he was always “interested in directing, but at a distance”.“And also actually with writing as well, there was something kind of recreational about the way that I was approaching writing, which was I’d written a couple of films but I hadn’t really pursued an aggressive form of development of those films,” he adds.Having only experimented with making short films previously, it felt right to take the plunge into full- features with The Boy Who Harnessed The Wind.But he didn’t exactly pick the easiest story to bring to le.In William’s community, the people speak a mixture of a local language called Chichewa and English.To make the film truly authentic, Ejiofor decided to work Chichewa into the script when it seemed most natural for the characters to speak it.This made for an intense filming process for him and the rest of the cast, as they had the task of learning a whole new language.“Sometimes you’ve just got to go for it,” he reasons, when discussing how dficult this element of the role was.“And actually it gets a bit of wind behind you. It’s harder to do things by halves, in a way... You’re not fully invested, so you get bogged down by the self-doubt and not knowing why you’re doing it and what choices you’re making.”He continues: “I wanted to have an authentic experience, but that meant shooting in Malawi was going to be really important. Andshooting in Malawi was going to be really important, then it felt like shooting it in a Malawian language was going to be very important.“Trying to find the right people to play the parts, and people and actors who are going to be engaged with all the complications of Chichewa and doing it in that way, felt a natural part of the process.”Ejiofor has worked with some incredibly successful directors throughout his career – Steve McQueen for  Years A Slave, Alfonso Cuaron for Children of Men, Stephen Frears for what was arguably his breakout role, in thriller Dirty Pretty Things, and, as mentioned earlier, Spielberg right at the start of his career.But while they have all been “deeply inspirational”, he stresses there must be a balance on set of trying to find your own voice with a film too.“If you are trying to borrow somebody , then the film is going to feel like you’re trying to borrow somebody ,” he elaborates.“In the end it is about trying to be honest, and to be honest to yourself and whatever  your strengths are but also to what your weaknesses are, and to ‘fess up to them and  try and navigate them, because all of it is very raw on screen.“It’s a very transparent medium and it really does expose the director, it exposes the writer, it exposes the actor. It’s very brutal as a format. So, you’ve just got to be as truthful to yourself as you can be.”The Boy Who Harnessed The Wind is available on Netflix from tomorrow©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

story: Over  per cent of offshore workers on the Shetland Gas Plant  have voted overwhelmingly for industrial action, according the Unite union.They were among over  staff on the Elgin-Franklin, North Alwyn and Dunbar s, operated by Aker and Petrofac, who were balloted.Broken down the votes in favour were: Shetland Gas Plant – . per cent North Alwyn and Dunbar – . per cent Elgin-Franklin – . per cent.The dispute centres on Aker and Petrofac proposing to change the sht rotation from a two-weeks-on three-weeks-off to a three-on three-off or three-on four-off rotation, and to reduce the existing terms and conditions at the behest of parent company Total.Unite members have taken the step to retain the two three week rota or be compensated for moving to the new rota.
